Also a popular area.As the park goes north towards the London Zoo, there are some more open areas that tend to be quieter if you are looking for a break from the city.

Lovely and quiet park - alternative to Hyde Park (also lovely but packed). Lovely plantings, plenty of space, people enjoying themselves but not a herd of folks. Walked many areas of the park..loved the walk from Baker Street all the way up to the Camden Canal and Camden Town.
Nice place to relax in. Fantastic place to have a leisurely walk away from the hustle and bustle of London. The park is immaculately kept and the rose gardens are beautiful.
Perfect for a long walk. Regent's Park is a perfect place for a long walk on a sunny day or a place where you can simply sit on a bench and relax. The collection of plants over there is impressive.

A Must to see. If you are in London the Rose Garden in Regents Park is a must. Try to be there when Roses are in full bloom. The whole place is just stunning. Cost nothing to walk around to visit and a eal treasure to see.
Lovely. Lovely place to go for a walk when the sun is out and even in the winter time. This is something I would be doing quite frequently when I am in the area

A Royal Park to escape to in London.. If you are looking for a little space in London I suggest you head out to the beautiful large Royal Park of Regent's Park, one of my favourites. The park is also the home of the London Zoo, there are many large sporting fields, tree lined avenues to explore and discover, but do not miss the Inner Circle where you will find the Queen Mary's Garden, the largest rose garden in all of London. The north-west side of the park borders onto the Regent's Canal Towpath a great place to take a stroll and not to be missed if you love walking as we do.

Great place for seeing cherry blossom in spring. There were many sakura trees in the park.I went there with friend in April for cherry blossom because it's a tradition in Japan to see the cherry blossom every year in spring, called 'hanami'.Got many beautiful photos at Regent's Park this year :)I will go and see the flowers again next year
beautiful. beautiful for a nice walk. i Was lucky it was a dry day. i stopped there while on a bike tour. recommended.

Try the Regents Park Sunset Safari. Regents Park is visited by many tourist, but I bet they don't know about the lovely sunset safari fest at the Zoo on a Friday evening. I used to drive through the perimeter of the park as a short cut and had no idea that the park itself was such a nice place to explore until I was invited to the sunset safari. It starts at 6.00pm on a Friday at the Zoo and there are many performers, food stalls, merry-go-round and ofcourse, the animals. The nicest thing about the whole experience is seeing all the different cultures having a great time. I like watching all the different faces from far flung places, converge in London and have a great time. It is truly amazing.

Gorgeous greenery and wide open spaces. Ideal for anyone looking for a healthy dose of fresh air and a cathartic release from the frustrations of urban dwelling. With myriad events held throughout the year even the most spoiled and difficult to please of visitors are never short of things to do.

Green lungs of London. London is a wonderfully green City. Regents Park is terrific with lots of walks. Busy in some areas particularly around the Mosque but it is very easy to find quite tranquility.Several cafes in Park together with outdoor theatre . Queen Mary' Rose Garden a real treat.

Large park with good walkways. Regents Park is a large park and has many good walkways for families with buggies or wheelchairs. There are many walks around the park and it is really good for seeing herons along with other water birds. Easy to forget that you are in central London as you can spend many hours just ambling around the park.

Grandest Park in London. Regents Park is my favourite place to relax, just lying down on the lush green bank, under a shady tree, watching the boats and birds gliding on the lake and, the wonderful colours and scents that wafts in the air as I stroll along the many beautiful flower beds where butterflies play. you may enjoy, the fountains at the end of the queen Mary's gardens , near the open air amphi- theater and mini waterfall in the Japanese garden. maybe watch a match where the young ones are practising football or cricket. Or just admire the 5ft flower vases arranged with seasonal blooms along the central Avenue.

Beautiful oasis in the middle of bustling London. I wandered into this beautiful green space and found hundreds of water birds with babies - it was just great. The park is beautifully laid out and so tranquil - there were people everywhere just enjoying a rare moment of sunshine. I would really recommend some time out walking in this gorgeous park.

Iconic London park. I love Regents Park because it has everything to make a park great. Well tended, the beautiful rose garden, great cafe with good food, the outdoor theatre, several wonderful playgrounds for children, footie on Sundays all over one side of it, the zoo ( a bit dubious establishment), near Primrose Hill, great parking on al sides....the list is endless....

Loved it!. Such a lovely park, with very smooth walkways - it would be good for anyone with mobility issues or in a wheelchair. Lots of runners likes it too. Queen Mary's Garden is especially pretty with lots of colorful beds of different flowers - roses, delphiniums, begonias, etc.
Beautiful!!. A pretty place near a lot of other places to go. Spend an hour but go. I went on a sunny day, it was great!

Excellent. If you enjoy walking around lovely gardens, then this is the place. Lots of flowers and trees. Also very friendly squirrels that you can feed if you feel inclined. They come up to you to take the food out of your hands.. Kids love this. We had four around us at one time. Great place with a cafe as well so you can get refreshments.
Always nice to stroll/run around. Plenty of birdlife, sports pitches, a couple of cafes and just a generally nice place to be. Great for runners and strollers alike!

Probably the best park in London. I love regents park because its quieter than Hyde park and has a number of hideaways making it a great place to spend a day. IF London Zoo and the gardens are not enough there are often events in one of the sections of the park which are always worth a visit. Regents park is a must see if you looking to stretch your legs and spend a day out in green surroundings in London.
Bird paradise. Lovely park, birds everywhere including herons, different ducks and geese and baby duck and goslings very close and tame

Lovely and beautiful park. The nearest underground station to get to the park is Regents Park on the Bakerloo line.I went with my family and spent almost an entire day in this beautiful park. We went for a picnic. We also went for a walk to Primrose Hill from where we got some nice views of London. It opens every day of the year at 5am. Closing times vary according to the months. In summer, it closes as late as 9.30pm. The Jubilee Gates mark the entry to Queen Mary's Gardens, on the Inner Circle in Regent’s Park and were donated by an artist Goetze who lived near Regents Park. The Jubilee Gates are made of iron and look awesome in black and gold. They were installed to mark the Silver Jubilee of King George V and the official opening of Queen Mary's Gardens.Regents Park has some nice fountains and statues.There is a large drinking fountain called the Ready Money Drinking Fountain. It is made of granite and marble and is located in the centre of Broad Walk. Ready Money was the nickname of a Parsee industrialist, Sir Cowasjee Jehangir, who donated this fountain as a thank you to the British for the protection they gave to him and his fellow Parsees during the days of the British Raj in India. There is the Triton Fountain which has bronze sculptures of two mermaids and a sea God. It is located opposite the Jubilee Gates at the end of the central walk which runs through the middle of Queen Mary's Gardens. It was given by the wife of the artist Goetze.There is a Lion Vase which is a stone bowl that is held up by four stone lions that have wings on them - hence the proper name “Griffin Tazza”. It is located in the centre of Avenue Gardens.There is another statue of note – The Boy and Frog Statue. This is located in the beautiful Queen Mary Garden. It is made of bronze and shows a boy and a frog sitting on a granite pedestal.In St. John’s Lodge Garden in the north east of the Inner Circle is the statue of Hylas and the nymph. It is a bronze statue mounted on a stone pedestal. From what I can remember of my Greek history lessons, Hylas was one of the Argonauts, who went with Jason in the quest for the Golden Fleece. Unfortunately, Hylas was kidnapped by the nymph of Spring - never to be seen again.If have time, you should visit the bandstand in The Regent's Park is located between the boating lake and the Inner Circle. The IRA bombed it in the early eighties. Seven soldiers died and many were injured when they were performing a concert.We also saw “The Hub” which is an outdoor sports area. There were people playing football and cricket. If I were living in London near Regent Park, I would be visiting this park every day.
Perfectly excellent British peace. A beautifully quiet calm in the city...wonderful for processing how London feels today, then get back to exploring for your next taste of discovery.

I loved this park. I took a tour through Regent's Park and learned a lot of history surrounding London's land rights. It is well kept, manicured, and very easy to navigate. Consider walking through the park with someone who knows its history. You will not regret it.

BEAUTIFUL on a SUNNY day!. Had a good nap on the nice soft grass that feels padded. Perfect on a chilly, sunny day. Put away the phone and simply stroll around, have a good picnic with awesome company.
Peaceful and beautiful retreat from busy London. Be sure to visit Queen Anne's Gardens for beautiful rose gardens. Park is big, and peaceful. Didn't go to the zoo, but I'm sure it is worthwhile.
Beautiful park with a gorgeous rose garden. Beautifully well maintained like all the public green spaces in London. Wonderful just to wander around or take a picnic if the weather is good.

Huge park. Nice to let your children run around.. It is kept clean and -sort of- tidy. Good to let your children run free. No gardening jewel though. A good way to make a shortcut from Soho to St. Johns wood, avoiding the noise and dust of traffic.

Great place for a business meeting!. So after a business lunch we decided to head to the park to finish the meeting. Great idea as the weather was perfect and the park was beautiful. Great place to get away from work also.

Gardens and Lawns for a nice summers day. THis is one of London's great and historic parks. it is a lovely, central spot to visit and have a walk around on a nice summer day. One problem - they could have more liberally distributed Gents loos !
a lovely place for a stroll, or even a nap!. beautifully laid out gardens, lots of shade and sunny places and lots of benches, one of which we inhabited for a quick post-jet-lag snooze.

Beautiful Park!. Regent's Park is a wonderful way to spend a morning or afternoon or a day walking around among beautiful flowers, fountains, and landscaping. Park benches are available to sit and read or just relax and enjoy the ambiance. There is a large lake with water activities available, also. A very scenic and pleasant place in central London.

Very good. Regent's Park is one of the Royal Parks of London. It lies within north-west London, partly in the City of Westminster and partly in the London Borough of Camden. .This park contain:The London Central Mosque.,Regent's Park Lake,Regent's University London, European Business School London, Regent's American College & London Zoo.The 166 hectares (410 acres) park is mainly open parkland that enjoys a wide range of facilities and amenities including gardens, a lake with a heronry, waterfowl and a boating area, sports pitches, and children's playgrounds. The northern side of the park is the home of London Zoo and the headquarters of the Zoological Society of London. it is Beautiful gardens to walk & relax in busy city London.
Nice Walk. This park was near our hotel, so we used it for nice walks. Clean and attractive, safe. Near the metro and bus lines.

Lovely Park. A very lovely large park with pockets of smaller gardens and landscaping which is enchanting. We found some mini bridges and waterfall that was gorgeous with a cafe and the Rose Garden nearby.Lots of birds, ducks and fowls that made this park their home. Great place to come as a couple of just family and friends and a good half to one day can be spent here for ranging around or for picnic too!There's also a great boating place nearby and we recommend it for the summer :Q)
Clean and calming. I love regents park and went there from marylebone station as only a short walk away. Lovely in summer monthes and perfect for a picnic

One of the most beautiful parks in London. Regent's Park is huge and wonderful with lots of great architecture. It was developed in the 19th century by the British architect John Nash for the Prince Regent.

Great. . Beautiful gardens slap bang in the city. Perfect for a romantic row boat session on a lovely sunny day. Easy to get to and free. Also hosts the wonderful taste of London festival once a year.

One of London's best.... Along with James' Park, I've always found Regent's Park to be one of London's most beautiful parks and I always try to visit when i am back in London.If you start at the Southern end the walk up the Broad Walk towards Camden is just beautiful. As others have mentioned the Rose Garden is also lovely and there's enough beauty in this grand old park to warrant different trips there.

The gem park of london parks....Time to visit the Roses Garden.....A must!!!. For me a unique park just outside the centre of London with parks full of tourists from a sight to another...Regent's Park offer everything but at this time of year the Roses Garden is in full bloom a wonderful sight....Close to London Zoo and Madame Tussaud soemtime people overlook this great park...or after a walk in Camden market what a great plae to chill out....Surrounded also by beautiful buildings for me is a great place where I come back so often....
Don't miss the rose garden. Nice park close to the city center. I really like the rose garden which is certainly worth a visit / often not as busy as other parks
I like it. Ireally like this park a little bit north of the center. It is enormous and it is nice to make a long walk within it. Nice restaurants.

More Signs Needed. This is quite a big park. We had to ask our way many times. The plans of Regent's Park are not enough and you can easily get lost. Finally we asked a couple of cops on duty and they showed us the way to the boating lake. They apologised for the lack of signage.We also would have liked to see more of this park but we wasted a lot of precious time trying to find our way and we were too exhausted to continue.

The best park in London for a walk. Regent’s park is the big brother of St. James’s park. Both have a lake and birds, flowers and squirrels. Regent’s is bigger and also includes the London Zoo. You can visit Sherlock Holmes museum that is adjacent to the park and enter it after your visit or do it on its own. If you like skating or biking, Hyde Park is more suitable but Regent’s is perfect for a relaxing walk.

Good place for Children. We had a good visit to Regent's Park. My young daughter was able to play in the park and have fun with other kids her age. The squirrels were also quite an attraction for her.Long walks in the park for young children are sometimes boring but the play park with well maintained equipment was definitely an attraction to the young. We went more than one time to this park during our stay.
Beautiful. An absolute gem of a park. Many trimmed areas with lovely flower gardens. This is a very large park in central London. Great to visit all year round

The Best. Regent park is really beautiful wil lush green grass. There is also a zoo you can visit. you can also sit by the pond and have a lovely time. I am never disappointed by going to this beautiful gem

A return to the Open Air Theatre. 50 years to the day since a visit to see "a Midsummer Nights Dream" I returned to see a delightful production of "Running Wild" - it still provides a most enjoyable and unusual London theatre evening.

Time for the fresh air. Great nature theater in the busy part of London. Great for romantic walk for all aged couples. It is qiuet place for thinking or just take fresh air in the big city. Recomend to visit for more than one hour walking and chillin.

Blooming Regency. Visited on a lovely sunny day ,which I'm sure helped but there are enough attractions to satisfy any visitor. The beautiful Nash Houses that surround the Park are stunning and provide an insight into how it was designed. Queen Marys Rose Garden is a must visit and the Secret Garden (St Johns Lodge) is a perfect hideaway. I didn't brave the pedaloes but fun on the lake is to be had for those who enjoy boating. Well maintained gardens and plenty of cafes make it a wonderful visit.

swans and roses. We walked into Regents after having dropped a friend at Marylebone station. It was Friday afternoon, and many people were out in the park on its vast lawns, having picnics. In the lagoons were many water birds, including a swan and its three fluffy little ones. The Queen's rose gardens were magnificent and aromatic. The high-bush varieties were in particular lush and prolifically in bloom. Walking out, we passed by the sports fields, which were covered with dog lovers and their beasts, enjoying the lovely day. What an idyllic park!
Free and beautiful. The park opening hours from 9 till 21, so be prepared to leave it on time :-)Good place for a picnic or a stroll.Variety of flora and fauna is impressive.
Good time out. was there last week with visitors from abroad, we all enjoyed the ambiance of the park, not too many people, perfect roses, other plants and water fowl.
Beautiful and not as busy as Hyde Park. Regent's Park is a beautiful park that lies within northwest London. It is one of the Royal Parks of London, with an area of 1.6 square kilometres.
to entertain kids with activities to do such as jumping castles. well their is allot of beautiful grass which made it possible for us to set up a number of jumping castles and water slides

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️. Came here with some buddies for a bit of soccer and a few beers! This park has a pleasant relaxing atmosphere that's helps you unwind after a hard day. It's well maintained including the toilets which were clean although you got to pay 20p for them. We had a great time.
Pretty gardens with plenty of space. The smaller, hedged gardens are very pleasant for a walk around in the sunshine and there are larger playing fields if you're looking for a sports space.

Beautiful space to visit!. A wonderfully kept part with lots of activity. We were there on holiday and it was a lovely, sunny day. People were relaxing under trees or playing cricket in the cricket area, playing casual games in other areas, or having lunch at one of the various establishments on the grounds. Only regret is that we didn't have time to come back and hang out more.

Amazing Park. Regent's Park is an amazing park in the middle of the city of London. A stroll around the park will give you the sense that London could be your most favorite place to live because of the very high standard of living. I wish there is a beautiful and peaceful park like Regent's Park where I live right now.

Beautiful place to escape the buzz of the city. If you're in London for a visit, it's worth spending some time in Regent's park to enjoy the different contrasting gardens, from the highly-manicured and beautifully landscaped avenue gardens o the well-tended roses in Queen Mary's gardens, to the broad fields and more natural landscape of the park itself and the wildlife around the boating lake.It's a fantastic place to go running, have a picnic, a kickabout, play rounders, or just to go and lose yourself for an hour or two and forget you're in a huge city.

One of the best yet not the biggest parks in London. I was there at srpingtime, the roses were blooming, and there are thousands of them, of every imaginable variety. Very nice park to relax for a while.
Best Park in London. Of all the Royal Parks of London I will rate this park as No 1 as its just so serene and beautiful.A must visit.

Why isn't this one the most famous park in London. I have visited Regent's Park in the beginning of June. It's absolutely fabulous. The gardeners worked miracles. You eyes find beautifully desigend spots everywhere. Do not miss the garden with th climbing roses. An oasis.Whenever I will visit London, Regent's Park will get a visit.

Beautiful outdoors in London!. Great place for a picnic with family and young active children- great playground, paddle boats for children, walks and looking at ducks and geese. Had a wonderful time on a sunny day!

Pretty park but beware the geese!. There are lots of geese and other birds around the very large pond in this park. Don't get to close of they nip at your heels! The park is peaceful and reasonably attractive but is not particularly special. It you are in the area it is worth stopping by if you desire some quiet time in the green belt but would not make a special trip.

Great place to relax if you don't have a garden in london. I've been living in London for almost a year now. I don't have a garden with my flat so I decided I was going to take my book to a London park and relax in the sun. I got there and it was pretty busy already. The park is huge so I wandered deeper into the park. There's some really pretty gardens and benches to sit on. I sat against a tree near the open theatre. It was a great atmosphere and people were having picnics with prosecco and takeaway pizza express pizzas. All the dogs were on leads too.I could have put 4 stars as there aren't any peaceful areas (when it's good weather) as it gets heaving with tourists. I'd recommend for a picnic, pug watching & reading a book.
Lovely Park. Lovely park with lots of areas for picnics and sports activities. Just be forewarned that it does get busy on nice days and can be crowded with lots of children
Relaxation. Oasis in the middle of London. Different areas for jogging, relaxing, looking at flowers and birds. Feeding the squirrels.Clean and well organized.

One of the best Summer parks. Such a great time to be had by all in Regent's Park. It is absolutely beautiful with loads of people out and having fun when the sun is out. Try and see the outdoor plays which they host in one of the corners of the park (you do need to buy tickets to these). Definitely recommend the park.

Stunning Park!. This park is huge! Definitely not what you'd expect in Central London. We walked through en route to ZSL and enjoyed the walk!There were a number of childrens play areas, boating lake and places to sit and rest. There was also a nubmer of place to have a drink or take a picnic.The weather wasn't so great when we visited so we'd definitely go back again when the weather is nicer so we can enjoy more of the park.
One of our favorites in London. We always visit Regent's Park when in London. This park offers lots of things to do for the family. Lots to see and do!
Quiet Refuge. The park has extensive rose gardens and other plantings. An easy walk from Baker St station or Euston. Take a brown bag and drink.

In the Summer it is beautiful, colourful, vibrant and not busy!. The park was wonderful. So big and so many different areas that you could easily get lost in it and enjoy the scenery. We came in the Summer so everything was so green and all the animals were out and about in the river. Flowers were gorgeous and romantic. Perfect for a stroll with a loved one!

Very nice park, very close to the centre of London. The park is very large, with very good areas to play most sports. Great whether you are walking a dog or going with family. Is also very close to the centre of London and easily accessible by public transport, e.g. buses and London Underground.
Very nice park. A very beautiful park in London, the London Zoo is also situated within this park. There is lots to do here.

An oasis of calm . A wonderful oasis of calm so close to the city, large boating lake, rose garden, London zoo, it's a big place lots of birds by the lake. Great for a little bit of time out from the hustle and bustle.
Nice park. There are small boats to be hired, but the rent-out quickly, better go in the morning. Better to go in summer

Beautiful and varied scenery near central London. We decided to take a walk the day we arrived in London, and Regent's Park is a place we'd missed on our last visit. We started on Primrose Hill and ended at Great Portland street, after having walked past the zoo, around the boating lake, and through Queen Mary's gardens. Seeing Londoners and their families out enjoying the park, as well as seeing the variety of spaces in the park, was a pleasure. The overview of London at the top of Primrose Hill was a great start to our visit.
Peaceful. Peaceful oark and very green! Had s lovely picnic with the family and enjoyed the clean weather and space

A peaceful, tranquil and colourful place to visit in the centre of London. This is a spacious and wonderful park. The boating lake offers paddle rides. Lots of birdlife. Or if you simply love to walk in beautiful and colourful surroundings then this is the place.

Love this park.. An oasis of calm just off main, busy streets. Great place to walk, run, or simply sit on a bench and enjoy people watching. We love it. The boating lake is lovely. The flower beds boast colourful and extravagant displays year round. .

Lovely, Try the cafe. Had a wonderful walk all over this beautiful park and enjoyed lunch in the Regent's Cafe in the center of it. We just used the grab and go section and were surprised how good the food was.

A gem in central London. By far one of the best parks in the city. It is quite big, located centrally in NW1 area near one of the busiest stations, Baker street, and offers a huge variety of park designs. Its rose garden is absolutely gorgeous when in bloom. For those who are fond of bird watching, or birds feeding works well for me, there is a lake with many species to spy on. Living locally I enjoyed many picnics and afternoon strolls in this beautiful park. I am in love with it!

Beautiful roses. We have walked through many times on a trip to London. This time of year is great as the flowers are all starting to come out. There are lovely fountains, cafe, toilets and places to sit. Fabulous. Also free of charge.
Rose Gardens in May. We loved all of this park. Wslked most of the gardens at the Piccadilly end of park and through the park to Zoo and back south on big road/path with side gardens.
Boating lake.. Spent a relaxing hour here on a gloriously sunny day in May, reasonably priced, friendly staff, but be prepared for a wait if the weathers good as it gets quite busy.

Amazing park. This is a very good park to go with your family, friends, etc, for a picnic, eat in the restaurants or to enjoy other activities such as pedalling boats, playing in the park or even enjoying the park and animals, while taking hundred of photos...The park is very big and enough for you to get lost, the way i did while trying to find the place were my friends were having a picnic...but the good think is that there is maps in all entrances/exits, so you can easily know where you are and find out how to get to the place you want to go.

Beautiful surroundings, charming canal with barges going up and down all the time. We visited London Zoo on a beautiful sunny day. Very impressed with the conservation work and although there were a few enclosures closed for restoration, its good to know that the £28 per person entry fee is being put to good use. All in all, a lovely day despite food and drinks being a little pricey.

Lovely break from the city buzz. I work just around the corner and love that this park is so close. It's so quiet and so great to get away from the hectic city buzz, even if only for a little bit. If I have a bit of time, I like to walk through rather than take the tube as it makes all the difference to your mental state when you're having a busy day.

Nice scenery. It's a beautiful place, perfect in early spring since there aren't too many people around yet. We walked across a beautiful small pond and lovely hills filled with exotic trees and structures. A perfect getaway from the busy streets of London-the squirrels are particularly friendly! (You can feed them if you dare.)
A lovely walk. A lovely walk after a meal or even having a sandwich there. Beautiful in the summer with green plants and flowers

Magnificent. Regent's Park is lovely - wide variety of spaces and activities. Beautiful formal gardens and lovely quiet corners too. Plus playgrounds, boating lake, food and drink options and ample parking. All with no entrance fee. Pack a picnic and have a great day out.

good park for getting away from the crowds. This park is quiet large. It has many trails for runners and walkers. It is large enough to get away from the sound of traffic and a good place to unwind and exercise.

One Of Many Large Beautiful Parks in London. It is very large and can be quite peaceful place away from the busy Marleybone Road. The gardens are well maintained and if you are looking for a quiet time in a garden seting try this. Once relaxed try Madame Tussauds and Baker Street which are just nearby
Large Park with beauty that holds your breath. Been there on the last day of my vacation in London and really enjoyed, especially the gardens and the lake.

An under-appreciated park. It's a short walk from both Oxford Street or Camden Market into the sprawl of Regents Park. And let's not forget the Zoo and the Regent's canal also traverse the park. A great place to chill out in the city, especially in the summer.
Lovely gardens . A lovely place to sit and enjoy the peace and quiet only a short walk from Baker Street. Beautiful flower displays, it was a pleasure to walk through even for a short time.
lovely to walk around.. a lovely park with a lake with beautiful trees, loads of ducks to feed and an ideal escape from the chaotic streets in London.

Wow what a park. Great walk from the tube, fantastic place for a picnic, a zoo is right there too. If you like flowers OMG your in luck . This is a fantastic place to walk around , bring your own food or but there . Just go on a sunny day unless you like walking in the rain and then go on a raining day!!! Have fun ! Too big to see all in one day.

Beautiful park in the middle of London. It is one of the most beautiful green spaces in London, where you can walk for hours. Ideal for summer time or spring time with a variety of flowers and trees on display.
Beautiful. This is a lovely park to stroll around. You forget that you are in London when you are there. It is so large that we had to keep checking the maps to ensure that we did not get lost!

Most beautiful park in London. This is the most beautiful park in London which is very close to Baker street. It is free for public access and best for the running. Anyone who is looking for a place to running you can go there.It is very peaceful green and very large park. Park has a lake as well. people can enjoy boating there by hiring a boat. They take 10 GBP Per person for an hour. In lake you can find so many birds such as ducks and swans. These days park has so many tiny white flowers over the grass, as a result you can't see the grass.

Such a delightful London asset & perfect for children. My wife, daughter and two grandchildren accompanied me to this very famous London Park which I know well but frequent rarely as I now live 100 miles away. I was so impressed with seeing not one but three Grey Herons quite close together, no doubt attracted by people like the man with raw fish that he fed by hand to one! The Lake (one of a few in the park I think) is very interesting and a haven for wildfowl. The grass and flowers are all kept very well and the park facilities are good. You could spend a day here easily - and obviously it is home to London Zoo as well.Lucky Londoners.

A pleasure to wander within. A really fine park, wander within it or use it to get to London Zoo or Primrose Hill. A longer amble through here is far preferable to the main road from Euston to Edgware Road.

London's parks are perfect for strolls. Regent's Park is great for a walk, any time of the day. When you get near the zoo, be on the lookout for animals. You can usually get a peek at the giraffes on the side opposite the zoo entrance.

the weather was good but this is not time for flowers. the weather was good but this is not time for flowers.
the park is mostly for runners and sports lovers.

A walk in the park. In all the times I have visited London I have never been to Regent's Park. Such a fab park with a beautiful lake, lots of birds and wildlife. Lots of activities in the park and goingon Such an oasis. So beautiful even in January.

My favourite park in London. I absolutely love to have a walk around Regents Park as there is so much to see! You can relax and have a coffee whilst watching people walk their dogs or you can go and feed to ducks. For people who like running it is full of joggers in the morning and at lunchtime. The Avenue gardens are probably my favourite part of the park as the flowers are gorgeous and it's nice and peaceful. If it's sunny there's plenty of space to have a picnic and sunbathe. If you have a spare two hours in London I'd recommend wandering around the park and if you have even more time then visit London Zoo straight after.

BEAUTIFUL. We walked every inch of this park and even went to the London Zoo at the top of the park. Foliage and gardens were gorgeous. The lakes superb. Cleanliness was key as we noted TWO different street cleaners through the walking paths of the park. Doesn't disappoint. Do yourself a favor and walk all the Royal Parks.
Lovely London Park. The gardens and flowers of London parks are not to be missed. The spring flowers were lovely. A quiet respite in a busy city.
". Lovely park to spend an afternoon and have a picnic. London Zoo is located in the park so loads to do for all ages! Will definitely be back!

Beautiful London park. If you want to feed the swans, gaze and the beautiful blooming spring flowers, or soak up the rare British sun with a cheeky pic nic. You can do it here. Probably my favourite London park.
A beautifully maintain park which was a relaxing time.. A beautifully maintained park which was a relaxing time. I have travelled to many wonderful places and this was one of them.
Lovely park - quiet and beautiful. Have lunch here - we took a picnicGreat oasis in middle of busy LondonGood locations for fine restaurants too

One of the most beautiful parks in London!. I was lucky enough to work near Regent's Park and saw its beauty through all of the seasons - my favourite was Spring when the blossom was in full bloom and summer when the flowers and foliage are glorious. It's great for strolling around, picnics and ice cream. The gardens, boating lake and the open air theatre are some of the highlights. It is, overall, a lovely oasis of greenness in central London.
good place. its like the hyde park and nice to walk and taking rest even if you would like to make some exercise.
Very well kept ground!. Great place to walk, sit and relax by the pond or jog, the rose garden is big and beautiful. Not crowded and quiet.
Jogging paradise. This park is perfect for jogging around - my favourite park is Regent´s canal, that is so cool. It´s also perfect just to lie down in grass and rest for a bit.
Beautiful park. A big and beautiful park. An ideal place to relax, have a picnic or go jogging. You will see adorable swans, ducks, squirrels. The gardens inside the parc are very beautiful.
Beautiful park in the middle of London. Great for a picnic, or admiring the flowers in the formal garden along the walkway. Would be a great stroll on the way to the London Zoo.
parkland in central london. Vast areas to explore Rose Gardens, Open Air Theatre, Boating Lake, walking can take you from Primrose Hill to Baker Street. Check the Inner and Outer Circles.
best picnic park. this park is the best. picnic areas are ample. spend the day at leisure in the summer months. costs very little which is a bonus.

Peace and countryside in the centre of a city.. Cross a busy road and within seconds you're a world away from noise and bustle. Aim for Regent's Canal just by the zoo and watch the boats go by and even walk eastwards to fascinating Camden Lock about 15 minutes stroll.

Beautiful. Beautiful park. Lovely place to visit for a walk and picnics with family/friends/spouse. Free all year round and beautifully preserved all year round. Could spend the day here easily. They also have a cafe which is reasonably priced in the centre of the park with toilets

Beautiful and serene in the middle of madness!. This park is exceptionally well kept and offers a place to relax amidst the hustle and bustle of London. I stayed in a nearby hotel and ran round here a couple of times - lots of sights to take in and beautiful gardens. A must!

Certainly worth a visit on a hot summer's day. Large crowds of people gather here for picnics and games when the weather is good. Instead of sitting among the crowds it is worth walking a bit further into the park and find a more secluded part to chill out in.
Gorgeous flowers, happy Londoners. Great place to people watch and see beautiful foliage. Romantic spot to walk or picnic and feel like a local.

Stroll through the park. Regents Park is beautiful and would be more so when all the flowers are in bloom
A good cafe where we had a lovely creamed scone

a quick visit. we had a quick walk around the park while we was waiting to do other things, the park looked very pretty and a lovely place to take children, i think i have been spoilt by going to Hyde park before hand never the less it was still a lovely place to visit

A beautiful park. We visited the park twice during a few days stay in Marylebone. It is a vast green area, beautifully kept, with a variety of landscapes to enjoy. There are manicured flower beds, currently bursting with coloured displays of tulips, large areas of grass and woodland walks. There is also quite a lot of water, with a variety of birds, such as herons, coots, moorhens,swans and ducks. A great place to just sit and enjoy and also worth the walk through if going to London Zoo at the north end of the park.

The best of the royal parks for its intimacy. Walk from Baker Street, Or Camden, this royal park on the north edge of city, one of the more popular parks esepcially with diplomatic-linked residents on it's southern edgeThere plenty of greenary and flower decoration, but he navigation to London Zoo, Madam Toussards, Camden Market etc make this place even more popular

Far from the Madding crowd. Literally a stones throw from busy Baker Street underground station and you find yourself in a peaceful and beautiful park that never fails to lower the blood pressure caused by other human beings simply going about their business. It is such a calm and beautiful expanse of parkland that strangers would be amazed to find it right in the heart of hectic and congested London. The gardeners do a fantastic job, as also do those who are responsible for keeping the park clean. It has now been placed on my list of major London attractions.
A great Park to enjoy a picnic. We had a great after in this park, just roaming and then enjoyed a picnic, easy to get to and lots of walking spaces

A truly great park. What a great park this is . It is so big and beautiful and on a sunny day you cannot beat going for a walk here . It has a great boating lake , lovely flower gardens , miles and miles of paths and fields its just so lovely to have this in the middle of such a busy place as london .
Spring with colors!. It is so calm and peaceful... Take your food and drink go there and eat while watching playful squirels and colorful flowers...
Love it love it. Large, green, well manicured and never overly full. If London was less rainy and dreary this place would be a dream.

Beautiful Park. Wife and I visited on the 7th May 2016. At that stage the hottest day of the year so a mini heat wave at 27-28 deg,hot and sunny. We entered via the Baker Street entrance just close to Sherlocks house! It was packed with people and picnics on the lawns. As it was bright and sunny, the flowers and gardens were incredibly colourful. Although we spent a good hour or so walking through you do get the impression you are only seeing a small part of it as it is a huge park.

love regents park. love this place it is especially beautiful in spring and summer time simply gorgeous ! if you are up for it and lovely weather you can use a rowing boat and enjoy rowing on the water
Lovely park. Nice place to spend a day if the weather is good. There are a lot of birds and flowers and you can rent a boat for a half an hour or for an hour.

Gorgeous park. Love that London is not lacking for green space which is scattered all over the city. This park is adjacent to the zoo and has wonderful gardens and paved trails to explore as well as a great playground for the kids. Within the park is Primrose hill which is worth the trek to the top for unique views of the city.

Beautiful Park. My favourite park in London. Lovely places to sit down for a picnic. Lots of wildlife on the water too. Beautiful trees and the biggest tulips I have ever seen in the flower beds! Definitely going to be frequenting here this summer

Lovley day in the park. Biggest and best park in London , family freindly , Very nice on a hot day with a picnic , beautiful gardens well kept , very central location near London Zoo, walking further in to the park you would get a good quite spot, around the gates especially closest to the stations is very crowded. Near Hannover gate is a lake were you can hire paddle boats too.

Gorgeous. Absolutely wonderful park. Bird watchers paradise tight within the city. Outdoor enthusiast galore. Runners, walkers, tennis, cricket, soccer/futbol, and many other activities. Highly recommend that u take a trip out here to enjoy a morning stroll, evening jog or a picnic.
Beautiful park. Beautiful, well kept park. The flowers were gorgeous and it was lovely seeing the squirrels running around. Really enjoyed our walk through here to get to the zoo

One of the best parks in London town!. Ideal in a sunny day! This park is immense, it goes all the way from Camden Town to Baker Street! The part of the park closer to Baker Street station and regent's Street stations are very crowded but if you walk further into the park you'll find beautiful gardens with amazing flowers and water fountains. This park also contains a lake where you can rent water paddle boats!At the rear of the park towards northwest, you will find sports lovers playing soft Ball, football amongst other sports!So bring food, booze and enjoy the beauty that surrounds you

Beautiful park worthy of spending some down time. St Jame's Park is in the northern direction of London where you will find the London Zoo and Camden Town.This is a large park and there is lovely things to see and be near. I, when time allows, walk from Camden Town to Paddington (about 3 miles) past places like Sherlock Holmes museum (Baker street).There are lots of people who use this area but you do not meet many unless you want to.
My favourite park in London. A great park for a walk or a run! I like that the gardens are very well-maintained and seasonal blooms are always around to welcome any visitor to the park.

An amazing oasis in the moiddle of London. We have walked here, many times, in all seasons. Each time, we marvel that a space this beautiful could exist in London. If you are visiting, with children, this is the best opportunity for them to have a runabout. They will love it all.

Beauttiful Park. As our son and family are moving near here in London, we visited this park. Much nicer than the other parks in London we visited. Paths and trails were very nice and well kept. We passed on the zoo, but will probably visit next time. Gardens were very well kept, especially this early in the season.
Nice park. Good for your health to take a good walk here. If it rains, take and umbrella with you as water doesn't bite ;).

Amazing Birdwatching. Plenty of people come here mainly to relax / sunbathe, walk their dogs, jog, look at the flowers, have a picnic and even birdwatch. I love feeding the squirrels at the park as they are so tame I suppose they are so tame as they are used to the amount of people visiting the area each day. Best park in London. This is a massive park with amazing flowers and plenty of wild birds and squirrels. The area is so vast that it even holds events every so often throughout the year such as Taste of London.
Lovely on a sunny day. I really enjoyed walking through Regents Park. There are so many people playing sports, walking dogs and just generally walking. Worth visit.
Beautiful Park, lovely atmosphere. very nice park, perfect for taking a leisurely stroll or an afternoon run. A must visit for tourists.

Beautiful Park. Our hotel was close to this beautiful park , went when we got there on the Sunday and before I left went twice in the morning, stunning park lovely flowers and trees very well kept, a must visit if in London.

Nice walk through to Buckingham Palace. Park itself is pretty nondescript. Deck chairs out in the sun with some people lounging. Most seemed to be heading to and from Buckingham Palace. There's a lovely and though provoking memorial water feature dedicate to the Canadian fallen during the two wars and yet in spite of two notices asking for respect by not climbing on the monument, two kids were walking up it right in front of their parents, that is until I made a comment and they beat a hasty retreat.

Small but nice. The main part of this park is divided in several sports fields. There is however in the southeast corner lots of flowers and animals to see. It's mainly built for the preservation of the habitat of several birds and insects.
Love it !!!. Amazing in Autumn. We've been cycling there quite often. There is not even one thing which O can complain about. Love it !!! 😁🌻👍
Beautiful. Gorgeous park, clean with great walks and beautiful grounds, good levels of areas to have a wee picnic.
Best park in London. Great place for a wander. Beautiful flowers and trees. Nice lakes and stunning residences to look at around the park. Also take a walk down by the canal to see amazing villas.

Generous lawns and beautiful flower beds. It makes a great walk between Camden Town & Market and Great Portland Street/Oxford Circus area. It's a pit that the water fountains were not working as I was thirsty.
Public toilets were clean and value for money at 20p per visit.

HUGE!. Wow. It looks like a carpet of white because of all the daisies. You don't realise how huge it is until you see the map of it. If you want to explore the whole of it it would take at least a day. Would definitely recommend this.
A lovely walk. We had a lovely walk through Regents Park and watch loads of wildlife, including many herons nesting.

Thoroughly enjoyable afternoon walking around this park and thinking of England. This is a park that was apparently hunting grounds for royalty and converted to a park as the city of London surrounded it. Take your time and enjoy. I was there in Summer and it was very pleasant

Lovely walk in the April Sunshine. London's biggest park, most famous for London Zoo. Plenty of very nice flower beds and lots of paths to walk, many are restricted so that no cycling or skateboarding is allowed. Lots of families, joggers, sports games and squirrels!
April brings full blooms and breathtaking views. Very much worth a stroll and be sure to bring your camera. You'll not be disappointed. Each area offers a different view!
lovely flowers in spring. Lovely park to walk with a cup of coffee in the spring and summer. Good for running as well. Has a little coffe kiosk you can buy from. Beautiful.
fans of grass will enjoy. lots of grass + trees , probably not great fun in the rain. saw some pigeons which was pretty decent.

Regent's Park In Summer. Just to sit and people watch was fun - joggers, strollers, dog-walkers, volley-ball players and a rugby game, was just the perfect. I admit it was on a perfect Autumn day that my husband and I strolled around the park, but to see the trees in their Autumn colors, the delightful and well-tended gardens, it was a sheer delight. The walk along part of Regents canal was so peaceful and at one stretch of the canal, there was only the 2 of us walking along. I found that unreal on a sunny Saturday afternoon, and in London too. The place to see an outdoor play in the summer. Comfortable seats, all good. Great food available in the theatre grounds for a pre-play picnic. You can skip the tour and walk around on your own, but I highly recommend it.
Flowers, trees and birds. What a beautiful park to visit! A lot of different trees and flowers and plants. Not to forget all the birds of different kinds. So quiet and clean!

Great for a walk!. I spent an hour or so walking around Regent's Park on my recent London visit. The formal gardens were in bloom and beautiful. It is a very peaceful park to walk around, with formal gardens, a cafe, and pond. There were plenty of benches to sit and enjoy the outdoors as well.

A bit of escapism in the Big Smoke. Lovely spot for having a bimble, going for a run or just resting up in the middle of a sight seeing extravaganza. Well kept gardens and plenty of little features. Great spot to escape for a little while.

Regents Park in Spring. Regents Park a beating heart in one of the worlds greatest cities!Originally the hunting ground of the Prince Regent & his chosen friends.NOW - an amazing inner city park, place of beauty, tranquility, beautiful colourful scenery - especially in spring!This park offers something for everyone-Rose Garden. FountainsWild Life -including Ducks & Swans, Open Theatre. CafesBoating Lake. Play AreasRunning Tracks. Football PitchesLONDON ZOO.Or just some of the prettiest walks one could ever wish for !Surrounded by the most lovely homes to admire.IT REALLY WOULD BE A SHAME TO VISIT LONDON WITHOUT VISITING REGENTS PARK!

Probably one of London's better parks. With a mixture of ornate gardens outdoor theater lakes and open ground this is in my opinion one of London's better parks. Head over to the northern side and you will be able to see into London Zoo.

Absolute must!. Regent's Park is an absolute must for anyone desiring to spend a beautiful day in London. The grounds are expansive and unlimited in allowing for all sorts of activities for all ages, or just out for a nice stroll on a lovely day. Primrose Hill is of course an added bonus in enjoying the skyline of the city. The London Zoo is very close as well, perfect for families!
Most beautiful park. What's not to like? Great public space, tons of room. Pretty flowers, cafes & even an open air theatre. Spend time walking or just sit & relax

A lovely park in the centre of London.. We walked through Regent’s Park on the way to London Zoo and it is not far from Camden Lock market, which we have also visited. The park is exceptionally well maintained, with lovely flowers, fountains and the roses are beautiful in Queen Mary’s Gardens.There are plenty of benches to sit on and there is also a large boating lake, an open air theatre, tennis courts, cafes and toilets.It really is an oasis of calm in the centre of London!
A nice chunk of green. I went last October, and the weather was fantastic that day.Not too many people, and a lot of space. A perfect place to chill when the weather is nice
Lovely park. Beautiful gardens and play areas for children. Very serene but can get busy when its sunny weather. Lovely place to go

Day at the zoo. Took the grand children to London zoo via Regent's Park they could run free in the park we had a picnic,the zoo was a bit expensive to get in but well worth it ,you can get a bus from baker st tube station or pick a bus up at Hyde park underground goes to Regent's Park then you can walk through the park .

Beautiful park. Such a lovely park to walk through and spend time in. There is places to play sports, sit and reflect, beautiful flower beds, lovely lake and plenty of wildlife.We saw all of that and then spent a lovely hour sat in the cafe in the park having a drink and people watching. Perfect!
Amazing park!. The park is huge! There is a little e river, with ducks and rocks. There is an area full of roses, of different colours and styles.
Wonderful park. This is one of my favorits in London, if you are interested in gardening it is something you must't miss. Spring is great with hundreds of bulbs. Don't miss the café!
one of, if not the best park in london!. great for picnics, sport, family and friends. regents park is beautiful and there is always something new to see on each visit.

Gardens in the Spring.. We visited in early Spring just as the plants were starting to bloom. I can only imagine the beauty at full bloom from say May onward. Leave a couple of leisurely hours to walk the park and include coffee or lunch in one of the cafe/restaurants. We enjoyed a meal in the Garden Cafe where Coeliacs are well catered for.

Dog mess and school kids. We walked through the park on route to london zoo. Its a large green park with plenty of space but an annoying amount of school kids playing games which I imagine are part of the school day. It was a Monday at around 11 am and there where kids everywhere. Another disappointment was the dog mess. We saw one dog owner totally ignore the fact their dog had fouled in the park,they just walked away but there were no dog wardens anywhere in the park which is strange for a big park with lots of kids and lots of dogs,council cutbacks I guess. It is the dog owners responsibility but some just dont care and spoil it for others. If you go then watch out for it.

Relaxing. Regent's Park is simply one of many parks in the 'middle' of London. If you are walking around the city and want a break from crowds and buildings, a quick walk through Regent's Park will reset your mind.

Nicest park in London. I love to come jogging here. It is a big park. Plenty of people coming to have a walk, do sports, have a coffee in the sun. Totally free and well preserved. The joggers rule the park together with the little footbal talents on saturday and sunday. Take a stroll in the English gardens if you have time and feed the squirrels.

Top notch London park. This is one of the best parks in London! It offers a plenty of green areas, football fields, flowers, fountains and not to mention a London ZOO. Maybe the best part is the Primrose hill, right above the Regents park, which offers the best view on the London skyline. It is quite romantic for a walk as well.
One of the best parks is London. I went in Regent's park quite a few years ago and visited since many more times. I love the rose gardens, fountains and it's variety of differently organized gardens.
great for running. I take the outer circle and then up to Primrose Hill and get in a 7km run when I am in London. A nice green patch of relief away from the traffic and madness
Just love this place. Hot or cold day it is beautiful. I just love to chill out here. I go at least once a month just to relax
Lovely park,and zoo too!.. Lovely park to walk around,and to sit in.Lots of people seen walking,etc.Also in top corner is the London zoo,which you can see parts of from the park.

My child hood memories. I love this park i went here with my girlies and we laid in the sun and enjoyed the good weather and each others company. The park is soooo big, lots of sceneries and pictures. With beautifully planted flowers. This park is well maintained and its clean. Would defo recommend this park. This park is smiles all round. Every time i go here i remember my mum taking me here to play. Its changed a lot but its always been well maintained with beautiful flowers that are always planted with beautil sceneries to take lots of beautiful family pictures etc....

Gorgeous. Wonderful place. It's incredible to have a walk and see all kind of birds (ducks / herons / etc) strolling freely in the parkThe gardens are simply amazing. A green spot in the heart of london

Favourite London Park. Regents park is by far my favourite park as a Londoner. It is always less crowded and has amazing vibe with children playing and people jogging/ exercising/ having a just a walk or a picnic and feels much less touristy than the other parks in Central London.Plus I absolutely adore Queen Mary's Gardens. I will never get tired of staring and smelling at all the beautiful roses!Plus you have London Zoo, lots of cafes (though I'd much prefer a picnic) and Camden and Primrose hill just a 5min walk away.

Amazing park in London. The ways inside the park, the squirrels climbing your legs for food, the swans, the plants make the park so especial. I went on autumn so the colors of the trees give a special feeling, where everything was gold and brown and so peaceful.
Great Park. Always finding something interesting... Great place to stroll and see what normal Londoners do with their free time. London Zoo right there it is a good zoo but a little pricey

Busy but serene park. Firstly, great parking on meters around the perimeter of the park, not bad price per hour. There is a zoo within the park if you want to visit, although a little pricey. Nice playgrounds for children, including sandpits and boating ponds. Paths for bicycles and paths not for bicycles. Open air theatre, a little pricey and can be damped if weather not great. Cafes scattered around the park. Toilets 20p. Lots of room for picnics. Areas to play football and sports. Lovely atmosphere. Well kept and safe.
A Morning walk!. A lovely morning walk through the park, the sun is out the children are on there way to school, it is just the most beautiful walk.

Excellent park. You can spend hours in Regent's Park if you want to. There are big open spaces, flower gardens and wildlife ponds providing plenty to see and do. Importantly, when you're in Regent's Park, you don't feel like you're in the middle of a big city anymore.
Footy. One of the nicest parks in London. This park is better than Regents Park for the simple reason that there is less people and therefore you can play sports or walk around peacefully.

Beautiful park. I have been to visit this park countless times and have always been awed by the natural beauty. The park is well maintained and has vast open spaces that you can relax in. The only negative I can mention is the extortionate prices for hiring lawn chairs!

If you love park and natures. This is one of he best. Love this park. It has a great combination of nature and gardening. Great areas for sport from Cricket, to Rugby but at the same time relaxing areas around the famous artificial lake. One of the best places for cycling. In particular around it enjoying the architecture in one side and nature on the other.The rose garden is a must see. Furthermore in the North there is the London Zoo. The park is amazingly well kept and quite extensive.
relaxing and beautiful. Had an amazing experience just strolling through the park, it is clean and beautiful! enriched with history and wonderful moments

Stunning Park!. One of the most breathtaking parks I've ever seen. Spotless and landscaping is simply stunning. I loved the way the rose bushes were perfectly manicured, I only wish I could be there when they start to bloom! So nice to sit on a bench and enjoy the sunshine and people watch! Lots of great photo ops!
springtime splendour. On a sunny spring day this place is full of floral colour and perfect for a afternoon walk with friends or familly. Easy to get to and to get around
Beautiful place. The top part of the park is a beautiful 'oasis' with loads of spaces, gardens and trees, I spent an evening during summer and it was unforgettable. If you go… go pic-nic!
Well manicured royal park. Beautifully maintained and an oasis of calm. Signage is good and plenty of places to stop and have a drink and a bite to eat.
Wonderful. lovely for a few hours in the sunshine. & it must be even better when all the summer flowers are in bloom
Lovely park to stroll through. Squirrels everywhere. Was so nice to stroll through this park and have a lazy day from touring. Feeding the many squirrels was great fun.

A stroll. We walked from our hotel near Marylebone via 221b Baker Stree. The layout of the park is easy to follow and when passing London Zoo you have free view of many of the animals inside.Queen Mary's garden is also worth a visit but as it was still early Spring the garden was not in its full splendour. A good walk of 60 minutes or more.The Lords cricket ground is just up the road.

on of the best park on earth. every spot is just amazing , clean and offers things for all tastes.squirrels coming on your foot to feed them. a great zoo inside although too expensive, lakes , huge grass space for all to play , amazing flowers and tree areas. coffees and nice playgrounds for kids ect.we used to visit it every day with my daughter
Beautiful Park. Really lovely, well maintained park. Perfect for a nice relaxing stroll to escape from the noise of the city.

Family time.. We found this park well worth a visit, plenty of nice plants and flower beds and has plenty of wildlife, and has lots of heron in around the water. there is also a big fountain to the rear of the park. There is a small theatre here too but was shut while we were there.
spectacular. wanted to come here for years,it was worth the wait.maybe a walk to get there,but worth the walk..we was up on level 2.cant wait to book more tickets go and enjoy

A Perfect Green Spot!. Regent's Park is worth a visit! Green fields, happy people, this is one of my favourite places in London! perfect for a walk, a chat on the grass, lunch or a day out with kids and even a romantic date!

Wonderfull. Regent's park is a Royal park carefully maintained to perfection. You can sit and enjoy brilliant food at one of the many cafes that are in the perfect places to soak up the beauty. In addition there is a boating lake where you can either peddle or row your way round the island looking at birds that you would have never seen in London before. There is also a children's boating lake where they can have a go in shallower water and smaller boats. A theatre is attached where the plays are performed out doors and they are well known for the productions done well. Football pitches and changing rooms can be rented for a small fee. This is all there plus London zoo only next door. What is not to like.

Beautiful park!. Nice large park that you can walk from Camden market canals until Regent Street. Not a lot of playgrounds for kids but large areas to run and play. Beautiful flowers. You can also walk through it/from to Baker Street Station.

Great park with great gardens. This is one of my favourite parks in London. (Admittedly, living nearby influences this) It is beautiful and has plenty of places to sit with a view for a picnic, or to run around playing some football or throwing the frisbee.

Its massive. What a wonderful park; it is truely massive and great for a wander in a dry day.There's a zoo, which we didn't visit, but seemed a good size, plus we saw the Hyenas having their lunch !!! from the banks of the canal walk.There are plentiful facilities and refreshment places, though do bring a 20p coin if you wish to "spend a penny" (change machines available.There are a myriad of walks and though cycles and wheelie devices are banned from the side paths, there is plenty of room in the main thoroughfares.We loved all the Squirrels and they come quite close to you.Dogs are allowed!We had two lattes £5Then when we left the Regents Park there was an ice cream vendor, lovely ice cream though I thought £7 bit expensive for 2 99's.
Amazing place to stroll around. Fantastic to take a stroll around after you've eaten a huge bacon breakfast, the lake is always beautiful no mater the time of year.

Beautiful place. Regent's Park is a breath of fresh air amidst the bustling city of London. It is within walking distance from Baker Street underground station /Madam Tussauds and is a rather peaceful place. It is neat, well maintained and has quite a bit of friendly wildlife. On a sunny day, you can get a glimpse of a beautiful sunset near the place where there is a pagoda like structure. Great for a run, good photography and a romantic walk!
Nice Walk in the park. Its nice to walk around Regent's park, especially on a warm sunny day- it makes a change to the hustle and bustle of oxford street

Great City Park. Not Huge, but well set up, neat and has plenty of wildlife for a city "green retreat"! You can see an owl, fox, plenty of ducks, geese, swans and other waterfowl, as well as your regular pigeons and crows, and there are a few hawks of some kind as well. The gardens are well kept and beautiful, and the park is bigger than one might expect, considering its not far from Hyde Park, and still in the city.
Another great park in London. Another great park in London. Hope to spend great time to walk through this beautiful park; nice lake, nice ducks. Plenty of grass to rest and/or enjoy.
Nice and Clean. This park is perfect for families and couples like us. We enjoyed the weather, the atmosphere and the sound of kids laughing.
Lovely park.. Walked through park on way to zoo. Really well laid out and clean and tidy, plenty of park benches to sit and watch the world go by.

Beautiful Park in the center of London . Absolutely beautiful Park in the center of London, great for all the family, perfect for leisurely/romantic strolls, or picnics or even a game of Frisbee! The flower gardens are beautiful, especially the rose garden, but my absolute favourite are the cherry blossom along Chester Road, check them out around April time! There are also a few cafes for a rest and a spot of tea when you want a break.

One of the best parks in London. Has so much for everyone. It is a very tranquil place in the mornings, especially if you enjoy walking or running. Check out the rose garden in the height of summer. Spectacular and its free!
Morning walk . It is a wonderful to walk at the park very quiet and full of flowers and many fountains plus the trees with blossom and few squirrel around
Beautiful. Very nice. Quiet. Te zoo is located here so it is worth the trip. Great getaway from the noise of London.

A respite from crowded London. Runners galore here at this large and pleasant park in the middle of the city. We took an overpriced paddleboat out on the tiny lake, and recommend that you only do the half hour, as the lake is simply too small to do much else. Still, one could read on a bench, feed the pigeons and ducks and geese, or simply people watch.
Incredible park. The most beautiful park in London.I was there in a stunnig and sunny day.The flowers are so beautiful and the spectacular view. It's very good for a walking and relaxing.

A surprise en route to London Zoo. Walked through this beautifully maintained park on our way from Baker Street to the zoo. Have never seen so many grey squirrels in one place ever! They are very inquisitive and not at all scared of people. Beautifully planted borders and a vast open space for all to enjoy, plus plenty of places to just stop and admire the view. A lovely place to enjoy some peace and quite.
biggest park. I believe this one os the biggest in the city. My favorite place is the roses garden - a good place to take a sit, breath and read a book
Incredible park. Lucky enough to work very close to the park. It is extraordinarily beautiful. Walk past the zoo area and go left is cool

Grand view of London from Primrose Hil. The park with the Queen Elizabeth gardens is a popular spot. The zoo is rundown, unfortunately, and badly needs a total overhaul. Walk up to the top of the hill for great views.

One of the main parks of london. I have visited this impressive park on many occasions.,mostly though when I was a football referee officiating one one of the many pitches there.definitely worth a visit.

Inner city cycling . I won't review the park as that's been done to death, but laps of RP are a great way to get a spin in inner city london. Go early to avoid the crowds, cars and traffic lights (I think they go on a different cycle after 7am).
Try the inner circle for faster (less traffic light interrupted) but shorter laps.

.A little peace in a big city.. Good place to spend a day if weather is fine and if you have kids the London zoo is right next door.
Beautiful rose garden in the right season.

Wonderful. Lovely stroll in good weather in this huge park. There are long jogging tracks, lakes, boats, ducks, flowers, fountains, sports fields.. anything you'd look for in a park all in one place!
Lovely people exercising their dogs and children laughing and playing.. Lovely ambiance in the sun.
Beautiful park!. We decided to walk to the London Zoo, and the shortest path was through Regent's Park. What a lovely park to walk through in the spring! Saw my first Magpie too!

Rose garden. We have been to the Regent's park couple of times.
Last year we went to the Inner Circle to see the Rose Garden.
It was spring but too early for most of the roses. We had a magnificent day though.
Hopefully will go there a bit later in summer to see the roses.
Could be so much better. Very nice park close to heart of London . Relaxing to walk round , nice boating pool but despite its size and age I felt more could have been done to grab your imagination
Just Beautiful!!!. This is such a calm and peaceful park, very relaxing. It has a huge range of flowers but i loved the rose garden. This is a must see place in London.

Relaxation. I really enjoy this place. I work quite close to here and it's really nice to come here when it's a nice day and have my lunch here. big enough to walk around for about an hour or two and lots of seats.
wonderful Park. So much to see and do, many events held here through out the year, , we love the rose garden and the cafe near the wonderful outdoor theatre

Interesting bird life. The gardens were just being laid out with all the rose beds and all the roses named in each bed. I particularly liked the fact that the rose named Golden Showers was placed directly in front of the 20p toilets. The wildfowl on the lakes are fantastic with a heronry and all the herons busy building nests.

Garden lovers paradise. This is one of my most favorite parks in London. It has a small lake where one can rent boats, bandstands with frequent concerts in the summer, and even bat watching on certain nights in the summer. The gardens are spectacular and are replanted almost every week so that there are always copious amounts of blooms to enhance your visit. An amazing rose garden as well, along with an open air theatre, tennis courts and bike rentals.

Beautiful park, a stone's throw from Oxford Street. Gorgeous park, with rose gardens, fountains, a theatre and a boating lake. Wonderful to wonder about or as a family outing. Have been going ever since I was a child and still return when I need some much needed rest and relaxation.

Fantastic greenery in the heart of the city. regents Park is for everyone. I used to walk through it everyday for work. You can boat on the lake, run round the perimeter have a picnic , play football or softball. I enjoy the green and the space.You also have the Zoo at the far side of the park as well as the canalYou can even watch open air Shakespeare in the summer

Recommended indeed.. This park is good in its own rights, and over a period of time,move seen it develop favourably. In another section of the park is the " Rose Gardens" where the roses are beautiful cared for, and the fragrance breathtaking. The Japanese garden is also a recommendation. The park caters for all ages, and to my mind it is also expanse for children to run around.
A relaxing walk . We had a wonderful tranquil walk through these gardens while in London. They were well kept and well worth a visit away from the hustle and busle.
Perfect park to chill out. nothing to complain about..it was a beautiful park ;) I will come back of course with my husband for a romantic walk

Perfect for a morning walk.. Located close by to the Holiday Inn regents park I spent a couple of hours walking through the park prior to spending 23 hours locked up on a plane. Beautiful place and very peaceful.
A nice stroll. London is full of parks but each one has a character of their own. I recommend going to as many as you can!

Beautiful Park. We visited this park in Nov first week, fall colours were still visible and it looked extremely beautiful... There were friendly squirrels around.. people were feeding them food.. I didn't had anything with me, else I would have loved to feed them..Lot of space to sit, relax and spend time. Now that summer is coming, it's a must visit park for sure.
It's stunning. Specially in spring and summer is one of the greatest park for doing a pic nic or just laying down on the grass wherever you feel like.
great. one of the best London parks that you can enjoy lake and beautiful area over there. nice coffeeshop close to lake. you will have a good time exploring this park
Really nice. Great park near Baker Street. Amazing place to run or just have a walk, especially when it's sunny (what do happen sometimes)

Very relaxing. I had a couple of hours to kill on a sunny Sunday morning and didn't want to wander too far from King's Cross, so I had a stroll through this park. It was very pleasant with lots of different things to look at. Lakes, wildfowl, statues, flowers, cafes, playing fields. It feels nice and expansive too, so you never think there's a great crowd.

A Sunday stroll favourite. Regent's Park is one of London's most charming parks with quite a variety of parts to it. There are some lovely views of different parts of London and it's perfect for a weekend stroll.I would highly recommend spending a couple of hours walking through it and visiting some of the attractions around its edge, including Primrose Hill, Camden Town, Regent Street (shopping) and Maida Vale.

Nice place to relax or exercise. Regent's Park is situated at the top of Regent st making it an ideal place for workers to have lunch at chat. It's also a great place to relax while traveling. A lot of it is quite bare, but there are some nice parts where there are more floral displays and fountains.

We Love Regents Park.. We just spent the afternoon wandering through the park breathing in the sweet smell of the fresh spring flowers. We sat on a bench in the sun and watched the world go by for a couple of hours. We also stopped in at the cafe and had a pot of tea and some sweets. Great park, highly recommend.

One of London's iconic Royal Parks.. Regent's Park is large and on the Camden side beautifully framed by white Paladian Mansions. The formality of Queen Mary' Rose garden is contrasted by the lake and borders of English shrub roses.Further on the formal gardens fountains, clipped English yew hedges and herbacious borders. The boating lake is great for families. Various cafes for lunch and tea bit ideal for picking on a sunny day.

Lovely to stroll thru!. I was on a wonderful tour by a new friend and we rode our bikes thru here. Even in the winter, it was still lovely. December 2015 was an unusually warmer month so this is why riding a bike thru here was possible. But it was a sweet addition to a wonderful day and memory!

Serene in the Spring. If you can get to this park in the morning or early afternoon before the drizzle starts this turns into a beautiful and fantastic walking or jogging experience. There are lots of different lakes and ducks. Also if you get hungry there is a cafeteria on the grounds.

Perfect any day of the week!. I go to Regent's Park for a walk every few weeks. The place is centrally located with many transport links. My favorite part would be the rose garden but it is full of interesting areas. One may think that it get's busy but due to the size you cannot really feel it that much. Good place to cool down next to the pond in summer months!
Most beautiful park ever!!. Most beautiful park I've ever visited. On sunny summer day you could stay there hole day and not get bored.

A place to relax! Heaven blossoms there in Spring!!. I love this park. So calm and relaxing. It might look big but it doesn't feel so. There's the park cafe for a break of tea coffee and some snacks and meals. In spring it is so beautiful, heaven blossoms there. Joyful colours and green everywhere.It is a must visit place.

Fabulous park. Once you enter the park you could be anywhere in the country side.The gardens themselves are meticulously maintained.Plenty of nice walks to take and areas to enjoy. The buildings surrounding the park are just as impressive and well maintained.

Must Visit Park!. If you're looking for an awesome park to visit in London I highly recommend Regents Park. Has a really nice garden in the inner circle good to walk around. There is plenty of space to relax and does not feel overcrowded.
Spend a few hours to relax. An amazing park with loads to offer if you like walking within city confines. Once inside you forget the the rush of london city.
Relaxing and Refreshing!. Went there as it was sunny! was so refreshing and relaxing!If you have kids in your family ZFL, London zoo is just walkable distance and good thing to pass your weekend
Nice Park . It's a good place to clam self on a sunny day. It has huge range of flowers but must check when they will bloom.
A Beautiful Park. When planning a trip to London I would highly recommend a visit to Regent's Park. It is beautifully landscaped and is very enjoyable to walk around.
Exquisite. The Regent's Park was so beautiful in it's autumn glory. I so enjoyed strolling along the Broad Walk; don't miss it! I wish I could have walked the whole park.

Go because ..... It's delightful - what should you expect to find...
1. Beautiful walks - stunning gardens and parks
2. It's free - what's not to love
3. It's flat so easy to walk and stroll whatever your age
4. Take the dog along too!
5. Lose yourself for hours - or a quick stroll

Beautiful Park only 10 minute walk from Euston station. This park is large a perfectly maintained. There were many different gardens to see and lots of fountains to take pictures of. We stayed near Euston Station and it was only a 10 minute stroll to the park. Take some fruit along, the local squirrels love it.

Beautiful Park!. This park is beautiful, we walked from Marble Arch right down to Knightsbridge. The park is beautiful surrounded by nature, including lovely spring flowers, ducks and swans in the ponds and the odd squirrel. There is also a lovely cafe in the middle worth a stop to enjoy a cup of tea overlooking the Lake.
