Great jogging area when staying at the Melia White House. When staying at nearby hotels, Regent's park is a great place to get some rest and do some jogging. Of course you can also have just a relaxing walk through the park.
One of my favorite places. I love walking, riding, driving through here it is so calming and beautiful. And a lovely place to visit for the family.

What a gorgeous park. London has to be my favorite city for early morning running before the city wakes up, particularly because of the parks. They are accessible early (as opposed to, for example, Paris's Luxumbourg Gardens which open at 7:45am which is late for my run) and Regent Park is a fascinating place to run. It is the first time I encountered two camels looking at me during a run (there is a zoo in the park). I loved the gardens, the water features, and be warned that it is a big park, you may wish to rent a pedalo if visiting with family. Highly recommended.

Outdoor theatre at Regents Park. We saw a production of 7 Brides for 7 Brothers in the outdoor theatre in Regents Park. It is a small scale theatre with no bad seats to view the minimal setting stage. The show was wonderful and even our 3 teenage sons enjoyed it!

How fab is Londom. Can there be a better way to spend a Sunday afternoon than lying on the grass in Regent's Park? Lots of locals and visitors with the same idea, and enjoying themselves too. Take in the rose gardens if you can.

Lazy Afternoon in Regent's Park. Our family of four spent a lazy (and sunny!) afternoon in Regent's Park, walking throughout the grounds and sitting on park benches near the pond. We enjoyed watching a swan family swim around the lake, accompanied by several ducks, geese and other types of waterfowl. After many days of chasing around London, and taking a few day trips beyond, the afternoon at Regent's Park was relaxing and time well spent, and a good way to get away from the crowds. There are several places to grab a snack, and you can also rent small paddle-boats to pedal around the pond if you feel so inclined. We did not tour the zoo at Regent's Park, so cannot comment on that particular attraction.

Beautiful place - hire a pedalo!. Lovely park only a short walk from Baker Street tube station, we went on the boating lake in a Pedalo in our group of four at a price of £7 a head (before noon) £10 (after noon). Lovely relaxing way to spend the day! Lots of wildlife which are friendly, be warned if you're not a fan of animals. The squirrels will take food out of your hands if you offer it to them!Very scenic and relaxing to walk around, great for all groups of all ages, my favourite park in London!Please note park toilets require 20p entry.

Flower heaven. This is a massive park with amazing flowers and plenty of wild birds and squirrels. The area is so vast that it even holds events every so often throughout the year such as Taste of London. Plenty of people come here mainly to relax / sunbathe, walk their dogs, jog, look at the flowers, have a picnic and even birdwatch. I love feeding the squirrels at the park as they are so tame I suppose they are so tame as they are used to the amount of people visiting the area each day. Best park in London.

lovely place. amazing to walk through regents park and then realise how close you are to the hub but of London, we walked from Camden Market down the towpath to the park and then down to Oxford Street to the mayhem, the contrast is incredible. Some foreign visitors had squirrels eating out of their hands, obviously not realising they are our tree rats.
Beautiful. This is a lovely place to go for a walk or even see a play. It's beautiful and very well kept. A perfect place for families or couples.

Pleasant day out . Fancied a change to a musuem so visited the park. Loved the grounds, formal gardens and lakes. Need a good day to complete while and an extra to do zoo. Found the tranquillity amazing. Found the cafe a little tedious, after finding a table with menu on. Breakfast menus on table, decided went to queue to order while in queue menus were changed for lunchtime and we advised couldn't order from breakfast menu. Fine, can live with that, chose something from new menu, when at counter told that until 12 only pizza and soup available. Either put times on menu or make things available when menu out. We left with no food as we didn't want pizza or soup. :-( rather disappointed. Would visit park again but take a picnic with me instead.

Beautiful and well groomed. Beautiful park with flowers, little fountains, rose garden, ponds, Primrose Hill (nice London view and picnic spot) and Open Air Theatre. Not as touristy as Hyde park or Green park. Perfect place for run, walk or picnic.
Stunning park. i absolutely adore this park! extremely relaxing ,gorgeous nature and walking distance from camden town.
Rose garden. Regents Park is outstanding whether you ride a Boris bike or just take a relaxing walk. Whatever you do you must visit the spectacular Rose garden with its amazing blooms and scents.

dazzling display of flowers. Great time to go in July. The avenue walks are full of dazzling floral displays great blocks of calm & vibrant colour. Queen Mary's Garden also is worth a look, smaller, more cosy designs, Go in early July for best display of the roses. rank the success of you own veg plot against their allotment! There is also an outdoor theatre there

Lovely place to lose yourself in. Stunning park. So very well kept it amazed us......clean and tidy......no litter. There were cafes and very clean toilets and plenty of seats for those tired tourist legs. The trees, plants and flowers were pruned and tidy and looked beautiful. The lake was gorgeous. We felt safe there and could relax. We spent a lovely morning walking through the park, but didn't get to all of it, its so big. It was worth seeing.

Roses all the way. Not my top London Park (St James, since you ask) but one of the best. Not as manic as Hyde Park and lots of nice little corners. If you are visiting the zoo include some time here as well. I think it's worth it.

Beautiful Space in the Midst of London. We stayed across the street from the park. It was raining and it was worth seeing. It is beautiful. Inside the park feels like a different world and then you step out to the fast pace of London. I enjoyed my stroll in the park and recommend that others take a moment to enjoy the beauty.

Roses galore. Beautiful gardens the roses were not gone yet and all kinds of different varieties.At which gate you are , and where you are going is confusing despite the maps at the gates.Lovely place and free.
Unmissable London Park. Regent's Park is my favourite of London's superb parks. It's very varied, with charming little nooks as well as wide vistas. The lake is lovely too.

Always lovely on a sunny afternoon!. Always lovely to go to Regent's Park on a sunny afternoon/ evening! Most definitely have ice cream at the shop near the lake - its delicious though the service is a bit slow!

Great place, plenty to do. Lovely gardens, great for picnics, fun boating lake, ice creams and plenty of space for a kick about. You've also got London Zoo at the North end. Visit the Open Air Theatre for a special (and magical) treat.

Lovely walk sunny afternoon. Walked through the park on lovely sunny afternoon from near Lords through to Camden Town. Really nice maintained park with lots of activities going on and great for people watching.

Peace and Life. The park is amazing to talk walks in on a sunny day. Best to enjoy in the summer or spring where you can get a lot of sunshine. The park is spacious, quiet, lively, clean, and time just flies by.Make sure you take few snacks for the squirrels and ducks there. Also, bring bottles of water as you might need something to soothe your thirst.PS. don't forget to enjoy the amazing London ice cream. ;)

A breath of fresh air. My favourite park in the whole world. It has a timeless beauty and offers a tranquil and peaceful space away from the hubbub of city life. A must-see for all visitors to London!
Nice relaxing place to visit. Had a great day out, stroll in the park, ice creams and tea. Very relaxing and also very clean, a great afternoon.

my favorite!. i used to cycle in and around it for years. because its huge and at the centre of London you can hardly miss it.one more private reason to like it is that as a Muslim it hosts one large mosque that provides prayer hall and a decent restaurant!

Amazing Royal Park. 395 acres of gardens, wooded paths, lawn, streams, tennis courts and a zoo! I've been going to England many ties over the past 30 years but had never visited this regal natural public space until now. Plan to spend several hours; there is a lot to see, and I thnk that return trips are the only way to see the whole park, including the zoo. There's an open air theatre where summer performances are offered. Wildlife and bird life abound. Wonderful place for a picnic if the weather allows.

Strolling Regent Park. A spectacular garden that covers 395 acres and includes the London Zoo with over 700 species of animals, The Avenue Gardens - a Victorian style garden set up, The Queen Mary's Garden with over 12,000 roses London's largest rose collection. There are many pathways that get you from one end to another and everywhere you look, you feel like Mother Nature is at her best.
Well Maintained and a real Gem. This is a large and beautiful park that is located in the middle of an urban setting. Great place to escape to and relax by the lake.

Best Park In London. One of the most beautiful parks in London - a 20 minute walk from St. Pancras - beautiful gardens - roses were just past their peak when we were there - ponds for boating - lots of sports fields - home to the U.S. Ambassador - definitely worth a visit.

Inspiring for a gardener. I did like the interesting combination of plants in the park. The gardeners do a good job. It was inspiring for me to see decorative plants together with vegetables and herbs.

Beautiful!. It was such a nice walk around this great park, extremely clean !
We spent about 2 hours, there are plenty of places where you can rest.
Stunning Pakr. lovely park - great rose garden which is worth a visit. Ideal for a picnic or just chilling on the grass. Option of hiring a rowing boat which is lovely on a hot day!
Relaxing. A fantastic Park, a lot of Flowers, Specially roses, Walking aeeras, Restaurant, Little lake for boating.
nice place to relax. it's a nice place to spend time among the trees, you can even visit the zoo, rare species of plants,

Scented Rosegardens.. Beautiful gardens, wide open playing fields, and large lake.
Lovely place to relax. Good cafe with wide choice of food.

Resplendent Regent's Park. This park is literally amazing, depending on what entrance you arrive you wont be disappointed in what this park has to offer.The park has a variety of facilities and amenities including gardens, a lake, waterfowl and a boasting area, sports pitches and of course not forgetting the little ones- the children's playground! They also have a open air theatre too!The northern side of the park is home to LONDON ZOO!!, they also have amazing flower gardens which is just lush in the blossom season. Primrose hill is also located in this side of the park and the views from this is just stunning!The western section of the park is home to the infamous London Central Mosque better known as regents park mosque. A highly visible landmark!Overall- this park is just what every park should be like!. when the weather is lovely and hot, this park sure does get busy but if you find a very cool spot - you wont be disappointed in spending the whole day there!

Let the worries of the day drain away. I admit, I have always liked parks. Walking around in the city and finding a park is like finding an oasis in the desert (although I admit, I have not experienced the desert thing yet but I have a vivid imagination). I like Regents Park because it is big. You can walk around for quite a while and just let the city stress drain away. There are some tennis courts that you can rent at reasonable prices. You can either just show up and play (wait if there are too many people) but the easiest thing is to book online. Cost is between £8-12 per hour. If tennis doesn't float your boat, but boats do, then you can also rent boats for some easy paddling on the pond or head over to the Zoo or the next-door Primrose Hill for more leisurely activities. I like Regents Park.

A garden/park a day makes doctors go away. Went here on a weekend. This place is a nice place to go for a Sunday family picnic. The lawns are well manicured and the gardens are well taken cared of. I wish I live near here.
The Gardens at The Regents Park. Queen Mary's Garden- amazing, we knew it would be good, but not this good. The borders, the roses, the summer planting out, very impressive, free and very English.

Beautiful. While everyone goes to Hyde Park, Regent's Park felt more like the local's park. Was originally not planning on visiting it, however after an expedition to Abbey Road, we decided to walk around a bit while heading back to our hotel. This took us right through regent park from the late afternoon-sunset. We spent some time taking in the view of the canal, with a couple of unique canal boats passing us. Then darted through the middle of the park where amature soccer was being played all around us.However the real magical part came when the sun had set and we came to the Inner Circle road. It was all lit up and very beautiful. We walked past a wedding, most certainly taking their wedding photos of this stock photo like setting. Once we exited the park we found a random Italian restaurant a few blocks away and had a truly wonderful meal.Overall i couldn't believe how quite and peaceful this park was the whole time we were there. I wish we had gone earlier to explore more and maybe see the zoo.
lovely park to spend the day in. Lovely rose garden, next door to London Zoo, huge park for all ages. Parking available with parking meters.

Ideal for Relaxing and Exercise. Beautiful park, and much larger than I imagined. Great for exercise.
The scenery varies quite a bit, from manicured to cricket grounds to open areas to ponds.

Great Park. Went for run through this park one morning and it was beautiful. People were there exercising, walking dogs and cutting thru on their way to work. Has beautiful gardens, a fountain and the surrounding residential area is very well maintained. Lots of green space for kids to run and play and for adults to relax. Great place for a picnic.

A great park. A great spot to unwind. It's big and beautiful. You can ride a bike around the park but some garden sections prohibit bicycles. Wonderfully maintained the zoo and Lords cricket ground are within walking distance.

A Zoo with twists. The twists are the Monkey, Butterfly and Bird houses where you walk through areas where the animals are within touching distance, but touching is "verboten" and quite rightly so. You can spend a day there. We took the tube to Camden Town and took a taxi to the zoo entrance. The Zoo only takes up a part of Regent's Park so watch how you try to get there. On entrance, follow the path and start with the penguins. These come from south America and appreciate heat. The Bugs house is worth a visit as you can see the insects etc at close range, even using a digital microscope. The Meercats are there so you can compare the "meercat"! It;s a great day out. may I suggest taking a picnic as some of the prices inside can be a tad high. If you get a sunny day, sunscreen etc will be needed as well. You might think admission expensive, but it is a "Grand Day Out"!

Nice park on a sunny day. Interesting park in the centre of London just in front of Buckingham Palace. Good place to stop off for lunch when site seeing. Not far from Horse Guards parade and the palaces, Trafalgar square and Whitehall. Research White hall Palace before setting out although it no longer exists it's interesting.

A wonderful example of urban parkland.. The Park is fairly extensive with the famous London Zoo on the north east and the open air theater in the heart.A great place to stroll around the lake on a summer evening and one of the little discovered treasures of London.Beautiful gardens and an amazing cross section of birds and other wildlife.

Day out. It's a wonderful park to wander around, so much to see and varied landscape from gardens to wide open spaces, ideal for all. Plus has a lovely open air theatre. Easy to get to from central London by tube, bus or on foot or Camden Town on the northern line. Close to Regent's canal, Primrose Hill for the view over London and of course London Zoo a must for visitors of all ages.

Wander & Relax & Swim. Lovely big open park space. Always lots to see and do. We enjoyed hiring a row boat and taking it out onto the river. Lots of  birds to see...Crested Grebes, Grey Wagtails a treat. We also went for a swim in Serpentine at the cordoned off area near the restaurant. Brilliant...proper changing rooms & a small entrance fee. Food/drink in the park is pricey but good quality You can spend a whole hazy, relaxed summers day in this park it's blissful .

A peaceful sanctuary in the middle of London. This is one huge park so well planned with lovely vistas, colourful gardens and some beautiful, mature trees.It is, despite being busy, a peaceful respite from the London energy. Certainly a place for relaxation contemplation and an appreciation for clever and passionate garden staff.
This is a gorgeous park. The gardens are spectacular, and I wandered for hour just exploring and enjoying. Such a lovely park in a great area - I will return!

Great place for a picnic or a perfect date!. One of my favourite London parks! This place is amazing on a warm summers day! The gardens, water features and flowers are well looked after! A picnic or a date with a gril/boyfriend is a must! Don't forget to bring peanuts to feed the squirrels!!

Great park to spend a nice day out in the sun. Regent's park is huge and every part of it is different but really cool. There are usually nice flowers and plants in the center area and plenty of grass and benches everywhere. Not to mention that you can hire a boat and deck chairs.
There is also a tennis club with 6 courts which is pretty cool.

Green Green Green. This is such a lovely area to walk around or ride a bicycle. I went in spring and there are many flowers. It is very pretty if you enjoy a park and abuts onto the London Zoo if you decide to visit them in one day. Worth a stroll

Lovely park. Perfect place to just walk around, read a book, listen to some music, ...
The rose garden is beautiful!

Delightful way to escape the hustle and bustle for a morning.. I generally only go to see the Queen Mary Rose garden, but it is equally enjoyable just to dawdle through the other gardens, feed and photograph the ever present bird life, or discover and sit awhile in the Zen (or Japanese) garden. The roses in spring and summer are magnificent, many are perfumed and make for stunning photographs.
Great for running. Regents Park is very big, so great for runs. The zoo is at one of the entrances to the park. Beautiful trees with an abundance of shade which is perfect for picnics with kids
quite place for relax. i went there just with my wife only, without my children, it's nice park for relaxing. you can take a book for read

huge cenral london park. Huge park with formal gardens, huge open spaces and a zoo tucked in one corner which we visited recently. It took me 2 hours to walk all the way round one evening last year. A total contrast to the busy London life in adjacent roads. Don't expect to get there and then get food; for those walking from Kings Cross (30 minutes) there is a Sainsbury half way along Euston Road which is useful for getting lunch. Not enough toilets or food places in the park but otherwise superb.
Love this park. It's just a gorgeous park. Some stunning areas that can be private, perfect for some yoga, relaxation, or sun tanning. Grab a book and go wild.
day out. had a gread fun with kids ... nice to see they did Tuesday kids fun which was fun for us as well.. nice and clean park

Family. A great park, visually lovely in the eye. Has a nice children's play area too I just wish it had more grown up seats around the edge to have lunch on and view kids playing.
Had to sit on the grass!

Family picnic. A thoroughly pleasant day. Parking was cheap as it was a Sunday with no upper limit (and there were still spaces all day). We took a stroll up the Broadwalk through the gardens (very pretty & well maintained) to the outer circle past the zoo. Saw giraffes (for free!) then headed to the Hub café - Lovely coffee with an excellent view. We then headed down to the Queen Mary's Gardens to meet the family & have a picnic. Again this was well maintained. Despite being a busy day it was also fairly quiet & we found a bit of grass for our party of 15 to spread out blankets no problem. A few points:Dogs are not allowed in the Queen Mary's Gardens Park toilets are 20p (change machines provided) but café toilets are free if you don't mind a queue. Parking on street is generously provisioned & free before 9am (in fact the machine wouldn't let us pay early despite saying you could so we had to wait).Will definitely be back

Regent's Park Open Air Theatre. I was most fortunate to be invited to the preview of Seven Brides for Seven Brothers at the Open Air Theatre in Regent's Park last weekend. This was my first visit to Regent's Park for months and I was stunned by the floral displays on my way to the Open Air Theatre, they were truly magnificent. The seats at the theatre afford excellent views for everyone and with the sun blazing down it was a perfect afternoon. The set was perfect, the orchestra just hidden behind the stage. The sound equipment was first class and we settled down to await the start of the production. I should add that there were plenty of places to purchase drinks etc prior and during the interval which lasted for 45 minutes which left enough time in hand to regain your seat. The singing, dancing and acting was truly brilliant. The songs so well known and loved. The costumes so colourful it was a joy to be part of the audience and a standing ovation at the end of the performance was very well deserved. A perfect Saturday afternoon, we all left humming our favourite song

This may be the best free show in town.. There are several different ways to enjoy time here. The many varied flower displays are stunning, and can by themselves occupy some passers by for hours. Groups of people meet together on the wide open grassed areas, and simply laugh, eat, and drink the day away. Those who wish to be a little more active will walk, run, jog, or wheeze their ways along the miles of pathways. Some people seem to organise games of cricket, football, baseball, frisbee, and such like. There is clearly enough space on the grassed areas for them all. Then there are those who clearly enjoy doing nothing more than sitting on one of the many benches and watching the world passing by. The Park seems able to accommodate all the hundreds and thousands of people who come here each day, and they all seem to have the space they need. All in all, it makes for a very happy international atmosphere, and the world always seems a better place when we are in Regents Park.
Huge space to chill. ...and to get away from the busy city roads for a bit. Lovely flower gardens and rose garden inside the park.

Beautiful greenspace. Great place for a long walk.. The Zoo is close nearby, as is Abbey Road. Great place for a walk in a beautiful greenspace. Kites, dogs, bikes, all sorts of things to see and do. Lots of fun people watching. Bring your blanket and do a picnic on the grass. Perfect afternoon.
Great place to run. Love everything about the park! amazing place to run and breathe unpolluted air. just peaceful and beautiful.

R&R for your sense of smell.. An excellent park in the spring/summer as there are so many flowers. Best on a week day to avoid the crowds and to be sure of place to sit. The rose garden is lovely at this time of year too and the air smells amazing.

My favourite of the large parks. This is my favourite of London's large parks. Big enough to absorb all the visitors but well maintained and free of too much litter. Great to stretch out and picnic after work with colleagues and have a kick around to let off steam. recommended - it's good for your soul!
An oasis of calm in the middle of the busy city.. Bring a picnic and enjoy the rose gardens, the pond with ducks and the views of the penguins in London Zoo from the Camden entrance.

The best park in the world -any day, anytime, any season!. I have a huge amount of affection for Regent's Park. It has everything for everyone - I have used it for running (races and training), some wonderful picnics in different parts of the park, attended some great events, bumped into people I know in the fog, romantic walks...you get the idea?! If the London weather changes suddenly, there is the London Zoo "in" the park, The Hub Cafe (yes, it is shaped like a Hub) and several other cafes. All entrances/exits are clearly marked, just make sure you are at the right one.If you want one of the best panoramic views of London, then walk into Primrose Hill (still part of the park) and take the short walk uphill and enjoy the incredible views. If you are there in Winter and there is snow, then you will find people tobogganing.If in London, this is a park worth enjoying.

Lovely park to visit. Absolutely beautiful gardens, especially the hidden garden. ? called the secret garden. Loved the roses. The lake is lovely. The whole park is very pictuesque. Could forget we were in the middle of London!
What a treat!. the perfect place to spend a Sunday afternoon relaxing! Boats for rent, too, lots of wild animals to see in the nearby zoo, but also free to wander in the park! Very refreshing!
Escape from the hubbub. lovely to just have a stroll away from all the traffic, crowds, noise etc. the London Zoo is also in the park but ran out of time for this.
Lovely park in the heart of London. Great place for running. It is centrally located, so there are many places to eat nearby. The Zoo and Primrose hill are also worth a visit.

Lovely way to spend a lazy afternoon. Spent a lovely warm afternoon here. underground and buses stop near so really easy to get to. The park is very well kept and apart from a beautiful lake it has many nooks and crannies all beautifully planted with lots of seating. The overhanging willows trailing into the water, families of little ducks and sweet smelling flowers all added to the peaceful setting. The park takes a while to walk around and there's a Zoo if that's your thing. We preferred just to walk and people watch especially down by the lake where you can hire pedalos and boats.

Beautiful morning run. The setting couldn't have been more perfect for a run: cool, damp, and quiet. I love the sounds of a town waking up. In addition, I got to pass through the surrounding charm of Primrose Hill, the Zoo, and nearby Abbey Road and Camden. There's even a dirt track for a local meet, run the evening prior. Very very cool.

A place of serenity in London. Regent’s Park was a nearby location to meet up with a friend during our London holiday. As it was June the roses were in bloom, such an array of roses to see and enjoy their scents, all very different.

How I wish I was back here right now!. It's a PARK (wide grassy space with funny plants growing from the ground) with a zoo (collection of caged unusual non-pet like animals that won't bite your head off because of said cage), a lake (large body of water for contemplating at or sailing or rowing on), an open air theater (sit down and watch the lovely living silly people acting for your pleasure - something we did before video games & TV) ! It's beautiful and fun. Take a bit of time out of your busy schedule and just take in all this park has to offer. Life is Good when you involve yourself with all the beauty of it!

Wonderful!. We had a nice walk in Regent's Park, it's a marvelous place, lots of colourful flowers and beautiful trees, fresh and flower-scented air. Loved the many species of birds and the squirrels. A perfect place for meditation. I strongly recommend it.

Serenity. So peaceful and well kept. There's a little cafe sort-of-thing inside which is pretty cool! It's just nice to wander along the paths/sit on a bench and just people watch. It's the sort of place where there's an untold rule for people to be as silent as possible which makes it an ideal escape from the standard hustle and bustle of London streets.

morning run in the park. Perfect park for a run, it's well kept and it's a pleasure to cross. It's near a tube station, therefore easily accessible. I combined my visit to Regent's Park with a visit to Primrose Hill, which is next to it. Very nice area.
It is amazing park if you like outdoor.... In the middle of the city, it is heaven......so clean and green, any time you can make a break and stay

A beautiful park for a lovely day. Whether it's been raining or sunny outside, Regents Park has a charm to it with little pockets that beg to be appreciated. I once sat and read in a little field for four hours and wasn't disturbed at all. There are beautiful gardens, flowers, playing fields, natural waterfalls and lakes to take in. So lovely and close to the city.
Big London Park. Walked through have not made a specific trip here but I am sure people do and suppose if you are in the area then go for it
Fun. So so beautiful and calm place full of trees and fresh air There is a little river .We had great picnic there
wonderful place.. First London experience is with Regent's park. When I came first time to London started my work in this beautiful place which is Regent's park. Always will have a place in my heart!
My Fav Place To Chill. I just love sitting on the grass watching the world go by or grab a book and chill you just can't beat regents my best park in London

Beautiful. I love English parks! So clean and groomed! Up until then I had no idea how good it felt to take off your shoes/socks and just lie around and enjoy and absorb everything in the beautiful setting.

Freedom.Walk.Rest.Play. Time-out from busy city but still in City.. A simply wonderfull place to experience the quiet of London. On any given day you can watch football/cricket. Visit the Zoo. Walk around the lake and have a coffee and eat. I have played Frizbee and eaten fruit on warm days and the freedom is really great, a pleasure to spend time here. So Central, Near the West End and also very near to Camden Town. A Must for any Visitor to London.
theatre and picnics. really recommend the outdoor theatre every summer. also for a picnic raid pret a manger and just wander til you find a spot.

relaxing out time.. it was lovely, i have not really walked around it properly but from what i saw it was well kept. however, there is a smell of cannabis that i couldnt place, and even if i did, i didnt see anyone to tell.
Clean, walkers, runners but tough to locate waste bins. Really clean . Runners, bikers and close to train not so wonderful day cloudy big.Cricket fields close by well looked after
Lovely park. Used the park as part of my early morning run to escape the noise of the traffic, lovely surroundings, especially round the flower gardens.

Picnic in the Park. We travelled by bike to Regents Park for a picnic. Lovely quiet evening spent but there's no cycling in the gardens. We walked out bikes in and sat on the grass. Peaceful and romantic! Was perfect.

Many years ago I visited, now I'm back.. I used to visited when I was a child and its taken 40 years to return. Very pretty and I cannot remember much from my childhood, well worth a visit. Must return to the Zoo.
Loovely. A great place to stroll around and get some fresh air and a little exercise. Well worth a visit if you have time to spare

Lush Gardens. It's gardens are well looked after and have a constant array of pretty flowers. Being a relatively big park it means that you have to take multiple trips to see all the different areas. On the list as a fave green spot, great for summer tanning.

The magic of the Garden. This park will give a glimpse of the various themes of being in Rose garden , or the expense of the green , the canal side , the rolling grasslands are too magical on a bright day -
Precious. One of Londons bigger parks, there's something for everyone whether it's the rose gardens of the inner circle or the paddle boats at the serpentine. It's a must on a beautiful day.

Idea if sunny. Just be prepared for a walk - this is one large park!If coming by tube Baker Street is about 5 minutes walk away - just keep going past the queue for the Sherlock Holmes Museum.The park itself has plenty to offer. Walkers and joggers will delight in the quiet walkways while on a rare London sunny day picnickers and sun worshipers will take to the grass.Rivers and canals offer water bound entertainment while an open air theatre and cafes offer entertainment and food options.
It's ok. It's a nice park, typical of London and a good shield from the noise, but not one worth going out of your way for.

Beautiful, beautiful gardens!. This place is so beautiful and the place to be. We were lucky to be there on a perfect sunny afternoon, about 75F. The park was full of couples and families lounging and playing in the sun. There's an outdoor theater, cafe, rose gardens and many winding paths. We would have gone a second time if our stay was longer. Don't miss this!

Peaceful family park. Quiet. Geese, ducks and squirrels to amuse the kids. Just next to Buckingham palace and short walk to Trafalgar Square. Leafy with large trees. Waterway with bridges to walk over. Mixture of tourists, locals walking their dogs, exercising and taking a short cut to work.
So many parks. We loved all the parks around London and found them to add a lovely scene to the city life that surrounds them.

Just beautiful!. We visited the park as a way to fill in time before other attractions opened and immediately regretted not having more time, this park is beautiful with lots of different areas to explore and enjoy. There are lots of underground and bus stops surrounding the park so it is easy to access.
Probably London's best park.. I love everything about this park. Something for everyone. Walk for miles, sit and people watch or something in between. A must!
Terrific. If you go there, do visit queen Mary's gardens in the middle of the park - they have thousands of different roses, each one more beautiful than the other.

Great on a nice day. London has a multitude of nice parks and this is one of the best. Honestly, bring a good book and laying out in the grass on a nice summer day is one of the best things in the world.

A park to revere. Loved the size and beauty of regents park! Great to get through by wheelchair or bike, wide paths, plenty of seats amongst stunning lawns and trees. Beautiful Rose garden one end. Close to zoo.

Beautiful park on the middle of london. Very big and beautiful park. It's a very nice walk and good for kids because there is lots of space and not crowded one bit. Lots of beautiful trees and plants to look at.

Beautiful!. I strolled through here with my daughter en route to the zoo. Could have spent more time here as it was just lovely. Beautiful flower beds, water fountains, open spaces...perfect for picnicking and just communing with nature. We also spent some time in one of the playgrounds.. It is one of the best playgrounds I have seen in a while. Lots of equipment for children to swing, seesaw, climb on, slide down, get sandy in, my daughter had a great time there. There were even toilets just for the children. Never seen that on a playground before. Top marks for this place.
VERY big. We just touched the edge of this. Next time, we hope to dedicate about half a day here. There is so much to see here and the flowers and general grounds are beautifully maintained.

Huge, pretty park. This park is huge with plenty to do and because of the vastness it's not that busy. We went to the rose gardens where they're are hundreds of roses all labelled so you can look through and find names etc. and we then walked along the lakes where we watched people in peddle boats and if you look out over the bridges you see plenty of different varieties of ducks, birds and fish.
Very pretty.. A very nice park, beautiful gardens. Young children will love it. The way to the London Zoo. When the sun is out, prepare your cameras!
Excellent place for a walk and contemplate Nature. Big and beautiful park in London like many others.nice and beautiful place for a walk and contemplate Nature.

Beautiful Park in the middle of a Large City!. We walked through the park on the way to the Zoo. What a lovely area! No crowds, lots of ducks and beautiful flowers and trees. If you are feeling cramped in the city head to this park.

London residents love Regent's Park's serenity. Don't miss the Heron preserve.. For several years, I lived near Regents Park and I became well acquainted with its amazing assets. The park is huge, with an outer and inner circle that make the interior park sections more accessible if you have a car (tons of parking). The well-laid out walking paths, the boating pond, Regent's canal, the rose garden, the outdoor theatre, the running track and sports fields appeal to a wide variety of visitors (not to mention the London Zoo at the North end). But London residents relish the park's elegant serenity and ever-changing activity level. Wildlife is abundant: ducks and water fowl thrive in protected waterways, green parrots crisscross the trees in summer, and herons live in a reserve at the Southeast corner (over the foot bridge). The only disruptive elements are the swift-moving bike riders who race around the outer circle. On any day, you'll see varieties of dogs and dog owners, as well as visitors of every description quietly taking in the beauty of this lovely London refuge.
Amazing flower gardens. Missed this park on previous trips to London, but it is a treasure trove of flowers and other horticultural elements--highly recommended.
Very nice place for relaxing. Very quiet place in central London where you can do relaxing, walking, running just yourself or with all your family

big park. Very nice and big park! You can have a pick nick or run or you can simply get some tan when the whether is nice!
Very well maintained.
Have a nice walk!

Wonderful Open Air Theatre. Each year we try to book to see a play or musical at this fantastic theatre in Regents Park. The productions are always innovative and exciting. We have seen everything from Shakespeare to outrageously funny Gilbert & Sullivan operas, Sondheim musicals and serious plays. It is one of the 'must-see' attractions in London if you are coming from abroad or even from the UK, you won't be disappointed. The present season included a re-run of 'To Kill a Mockingbird' which was simply wonderful when we saw it last year. Parking is fairly easy if you arrive early and park on the road. Food is good before the show and the facilities are always being improved. Sight lines are perfect and one year a fox even wandered onto the side of the stage!!! If it rains, who cares? The show goes on!

An wonderful Trip. Most people want to come to London. It is a fascinating idea. the city is very big and orderly. And It has a lot of parks. Regent's Park is one of them. It is wonderful. You can run, walk, and you can read your book on a bench. Also you can see the beautiful gardens, flowers, trees, the lake and red squirrels.And it has an open air theatre. You can hire a bicycle and wander around. And the weather is sunny, you may sunbathe. If you want to go to Regent's Park, you can use the bus or the subway. The Subway is easier than the bus. I think you should choose the underground, because It is near the Regent's Park Station. If you visit London, you need to see the parks.
Lovely Park. Big park to the north of central London. Very well maintained, good for running, cycling at speed around the outer circle, walks, relaxing in the sun, etc...

I just love it everytime I go there.. A beautiful walk. I would suggest anyone to spend a lovely afternoon walking past the ducks and pigeons, feeding them / boating as that is my favorite time pass to do. It is a lovely and huge garden suitable for all sorts of outdoor activities.
Peaceful. A perfect time to gather one thoughts with family and friends in the heart of London. This hidden gem area is perfect for that time to relax
Beautiful Garden. Very relaxed place to walk around, flowers are fantastic, excellent place to sit and people watch, ice creams expensive but i suppose that's London prices

Big Park. London is famous for its parks but this one being not very central is not the best known or the must-see. A big park though, if your visit to London is for parks. If not there are easier to visit ones.

Nice and fab. Great greenery surrounding you. A very well made Mosque near the park which has great ambience, aura and toilet facilities which is always a bonus. With young kids makes it that much easier

the most wonderful park in London. In my opinion this is the most beautiful park in London. It's peaceful yet you won't feel lonely thanks to the ducks and birds everywhere around you. also the flowers, trees and the river in this park make it more magical. I highly recommend this park to have a picnic or just to relax..
You need to see it. This big city oasis is a place you need to visit if you reach out to London because it's atmosphere, colours and energy are amazing!

Nothing special. I visited the park to go on the boat.. there was a huge queue so wasnt able to enjoy the boat. There is also a lack of chairs and wasn't able to find toilettes, so didn't enjoyed the park much.

Beautiful park!. This is a great park near Madame Tussaud's. Very relaxing and there was all kind of small animals from squirrels to turtles around the park.There was a lot you could do in the park; hire a paddleboat, have a picnic in the gardens, pop into the London Zoo and much more.Very nice park to just relax in after you've done some shopping or just walked the streets.
On our way to the zoo. Beautiful landscapes - heavenly flower smells - good for late afternoon stroll with enough people to bring it alive but not overcrowded

Lovely. This park is a great location to have a nice walk, either alone or with friends and family. It's also a lovely location for a picnic or a nice lie down in the sun ☺A little bit of calm in the manic chaos that is London.

The perfect place for a summer picnic.. Regent's Park in summer is simply magical. It's the perfect place to retreat from the busy city that is London and enjoy some quiet with friends (and hundreds of other people doing the same).The park is well laid out and contains so many beautiful gardens, take a picnic and a bottle of champaign to enjoy with friends or get there early in the morning for a pre-work run.
beautifull park. living very close, the best place to relax, weekends quite crowdy but week days very nice, great place for parents because they have a very good playgrounds around all parks

Wonderful Park All Year Through. Not much to say, it's a beautiful place to go and chill, with friends or alone. It's free, has lovely gardens and trees, and a feeling of serenity.Definitely the best park of London.See you there!

An oasis in a hot day in London. After trawling around Camden Market we headed for Regents park and it was so beautiful and peaceful there with the roses in full bloom and gorgeous flowers all around. Had lunch at the Garden restaurant there which was great. Always a pleasure to go to Regents park
Take a stroll. Nice place to take a break in your day and relax. You can wonder around or sit and people watch. Enjoyable either way.

Always an oasis in the centre of such a busy major City.. There is so much dignity about certain parts of our capital and this is definitely in the top 5.Any time of the year you will find interest here, from the snow covered trees to the blooming summer petals...this park holds its own, it can be proud, quirky, majestic, cosy, interactive, solitary...it has it all with the tree and birds and retreat from the traffic nd bustle of nearby major streets nd paces of interest o tourist swell a practical offices nd eturants nd shopping areas.A real retreat, always always a pleasure to be within this park.

Best Park in London!. Just visited Regents Park in London for the first time - despite being a Londoner!. I have been to most of the other parks here which are all lovely in different ways but Regents Park is by far the best Park. I thought unspoilt and close to natural Richmond Park would be hard to beat having spent my birthday there in May but this Park did it. I highly recommend it - especially Queen Mary's Gardens.

Great park serving north London.. A beautiful park with a nice small lake, probably the cleanest of London's Royal Parks, and maybe not as visited as say Hyde Park which is great but spoiled only with the large events especially during Xmas (avoid Hyde Park at all cost). The Royal Parks are an amazing part of London.

Best Park in London. My favourite park in London, lots of open spaces, excellent gardens, summer theatre, plenty of places to eat, great for picnics, working out, relaxing, perfect for kids. You can even take trapeze lessons!!!!
huge park.. peaceful but nosiy lots of people sterostyles passing and lots of flowers roses and plants. enjoy the day.

Morning walk, breakfast+Sherlock Holmes!. You can't believe how quite it is in the morning!! I have a very nice walk in the park and had some breakfast in the Garden café near the middle of the park.The other side of the park which is the Sherlock Holmes Museum near tube baker street. Open at 9:30am.
Nice park to stroll in. Enjoyed a walking tour through this park and area. Nice park to take a stroll in. Very relaxed great place to have a picnic or just people watch.
Regents Park. Lovely park in the heart of London also home to London Zoo as Zoo standards go its very good, - lots of places to sit and eat as well

Nice and relaxing. Right outside Buckingham place, it is a nice place with many different kinds of wild birds (although now they are used to humans). It is a nice place just to walk around along the lake and relax

Visited every week that I was in London!. You absolutely must visit this park if you are in London. I was here for three months and loved watching winter give way to spring. The flowers, the wildlife, the people sitting on blankets with their children...everything was perfect. Walk all the way back to the rose gardens for the full experience. This was a great place to sit on a bench with a book, to take pictures, give a few scraps of stale bread to a greedy goose, or just to enjoy the scenery. This is one of my best memories of London.
A quirky touch in the Rose Garden. One of the Regent's Park gardeners has a sense of humour and has planted the rose, "Golden Showers" next to the sign for the Ladies Toilets.
A very special park. A great place to visit on a sunny day ,with a boating lake restaurant cafe ,and wonderful flower gardens in the heart of London

Excellent place! I do recommend!. Fancy Park. This place, as well as other parks in London are perfect places for enjoy the afternoon with family or friends, doing a picnic. Also very suitable for running and biking lovers.

Still the same. Brilliant visit again to Regent's park, we spent a few days in London, the weather was great and it is very large area to walk, so will need good shoes. Close to the underground so easy access if you want to visit other places. Well worth a visit.

An oasis in London. So much open space, so much to do, this is a lovely park. The pedal boats are always fun, the small cafe and Honest Sausage are great, but the nicest thing to me is the open space and lack of crowds that make walking a pleasure.

Beautiful garden walk. Regents Park is a lovely place to spend a day, strolling, sitting with a picnic, enjoying the gardens or paddling around the little lake. There's even a nice restaurant as well as live theatre in the summer. Less than a 30 minute walk from the bustle of Oxford Street.

Royal Splendor. I think this is the best park in London as far as the array of settings, sights, and services (e.g., tennis court and racquet rentals, boat rentals, etc.). The Queen's Gardens are spectacular, especially when the roses bloom in June. It is my "go to" running, walking, or relaxing place.

Walk on by. This part is huge, but trying to find a nice spot on a summers day is like trying to find a needle in a hay stack. Huge is size, but packed with people. Nice to walk through, but not great to stop off at, if you want peace and quiet.
Wonderful Place to spend an afternoon. From the zoo, to the ponds, to just enjoying a lazy picnic lunch, this is a great place to spend downtime.

Relaxing, quieter than Hyde and Green Park. I love walking around regents park. It's not quiet, but it's a lot quieter than the other big london parks.
Great place to walk in the early mornings.

Extensive and expensive. Well, if you eat it's expensive. There's a fab tea rooms which serve a breakfast for kings, but you have to pay for the privilege.
Otherwise, the park is well kept and very nicely landscaped. There is the lake, with its bridges, a bandstand, a Japanese garden, and of course the zoo.
Lots of people sunbathing during the summer.
Incerdible. Excellent place, colorful and peaceful. Very nice lanscape.If you can get some time in a sunny day, have a walk there and have lunch as well.
Nice scenery. A wonderful area for a relaxing tour. Close to so much more to see and do. Beautiful trees and monuments too.
Amazing perfumed rose garden. Well worth the walk through this large park. Must visit the inner circle rose garden. July / August a great time as the roses are in display and highly perfumed

gardens and lakes. this green jewel in almost the center of London is definitely worth visiting.boat hire available;walk towards london zoo or along the canal;visit the wonderful rosegarden or the italien gardens;perhaps buy tickets for the open theater(not open in winter)and picnic in the grounds.

Peaceful ..... Peaceful Quiet and Serene !
Fresh Air, mix of Woody n Earthen Smell, Pathways, Soccer & Tennis Fields, Benches, surrounding Lakes, walkways, Cafe`s , chirping Birds, zooming squirrels and friendly people around, all add up to a Great Stroll in this Park !!
Beautiful park. Loved this park!! We went through The Queens Garden at Regents Park and it was beautiful! There is also a nice play area for children.

Another Beautiful Park. A smaller version than Hyde Park and so beautiful!
A boat ride to Camden Town out of the park looked like a great adventure!

Gorgeous -- definitely worth a visit!. London, for a bustling city, definitely does not have a shortage of gorgeous parks; this park is no exception! I would stroll through this park on my way to and from Camden Town and Primrose Hill (a DEFINITE must!) I visited in the winter, so I was not able to actually visit the Open Air theatre, though many have praised the theatre -- so I'll send forth the recommendation.
What else can you say but classic London. It's a classic London park - a great place to step away from the crazy pace of the city and enjoy some fresh(ish) air

Beautiful City Park. Any time, all season people can enjoy nature in the very busy central city, there are lakes, animals, birds, flowers, trees...it's such picturesque scenery that travelers must not miss it.

Beautiful gardens within Regent's Park. Regent's Park and more specifically Queen Mary's Gardens and Avenue Gardens were worth the trip. It's on the way to and from Camden Town and definitely worth a couple of hours of your time.

Shady Respite from the summer sun. The gardens are lovely. There is a kiosk for refreshments that are tasty and reasonably priced. There is theatre in the park in the summer. It is close to shopping areas including the Sherlock Holmes Museum.
A pleasant park with an awesome theatre. The park itself is a lovely place for a walk, but my biggest attraction is the Open Air theatre in the summer. The atmosphere is magical.
Excellent!. Perfect place for your day out, or just your lunch brake. If in London, deffinitely go visit the Regent Park. Especcialy in the sunset!
Areas near London Zoo. Nice place to visit along with the London Zoo. A great people watching place when it is hot outdoors.
Nice place. A wonderful place. Nice to walk around during the lunch break, and get a bit of fresh air. Better when its warm.
From Cricket to Roses. This is a beautiful, clean place to go running, picnic with your family, read on the grass, and feel like you can blend into the life of the city.

A soothing experience. Remember what formal gardens used to be like? Closely cropped grass as flat as a balliard table, tightly packed flower arrangements in bright colours, broad straight paths, couples strolling arm in arm, a tinking fountain? Very much the experience at Regents Park today, although runners, roller skaters and raised voices tend to shatter the tranquilty from time to time. If the rest of London seems noisy, crowded and well, vulgar, come and have a stroll at Regents Park - it will soothe you.
Picturesque London. Absolutely beautiful park with many paths to run or walk on. The gardens are exquisite. The open air theatre is absolutely charming.

Oh, the roses!. Regent's Park is beautiful. We just happened to be there on a spectacular day in June when all the roses in Queen Mary's Garden were in bloom, which may color how I felt about the visit. If you're in London in June, go see the roses!
Taste of London. Brilliant especially Pilsner Urquell stand. Good day overall with lots of variety of stalls. Food quite pricey but good quality
Nice Park. We enjoyed visiting the top of Primrose Hill in the park to get a lovely view of London. The park is pet and child friendly and was very well kept. Would visit again.

Lovely large park. park has two parts separated by a bridge in the road, but when in park can walk all around.
lovely shaded areas under large willow tress,very peaceful.

Beautiful relaxing spot. Have visited Regents Park in all seasons. Always something to see, bird life, etc. In spring daffodils are beautiful followed by roses & many other flowers in midsummer. Fun to just sit on a bench, relax, & watch people go by. Also has zoo on north side. Near Baker St. Tube station.
beautiful. beautiful park in the centre of London, not worth the boats or the cafe, bad quality food :( and not clean place
my day. fantastic im always coming back here with family and friends so come along you leave here wanting to com back.

Green area****!. Great park for playing sports! Lots of space and green area everywhere! There is also a zoo if you are interested in animals :) Primrose hill is very close as well from where you can get a nice view of London!

One of London's loveliest parks. A wonderful place to while away a sunny day or evening. Enjoy a stroll through the landscaped gardens, take in a show at the open-air theatre, picnic on Primrose Hill, or perhaps visit ZSL London Zoo.
Wonderful oasis in London. Beautiful park, very well maintained. Lovely walks. Rose garden & "secret" garden well worth a visit. Lovely cafe's to choose from.
Hello squirrels. Well, it's a park. But a terrifically groomed park and a great place to take a break from a busy itinerary or just the busy population.
Even the squirels are polite.. Renting a bike or just walking around, it is such a beautiful place to visit. Just make sure to wear a very comfortable pair of shoes.

Brilliant. This is a must go place in London. Nothing to say that much, you have to feel yourself. Imagine the busy days when you at work, colleges, find a sunny day take a walk and go for a picnic with your love/friends.
A pretty park. London is full of great parks. This one has a view of Buckingham Palace and a pretty lake with lots of flora and fauna. It is where my parents proposed and I can see why.
roses, roses, roses. The middle of Regents Park is the most beautiful flower garden I have ever seen except for the tulips in Luxenborg Park in Paris
Triathlon event. We watched our son in law in a triathlon event. We didn't get much opportunity to have a wander round the park as we were visiting other places as well
Beautiful surroundings. I am lucky enough to be nearby for work so enjoy going for walks/runs/lunch in the park when it 's nice weather.
Beautiful park. Nice place to stroll around when the weather is nice. Especially when the flowers are in bloom. It can get pretty crowed in the summer season.
Best park in London. Regent's Park is my favourite of London's parks. There is so much wildlife and so many different areas to explore. Its beautiful and doesn't cost you anything.

Good place to relax. It's huge so depending what you're looking for there are probably sections of the park to cater to your needs.
Would highly recommend ZSL at the north end of the park. The grounds are well kept and very pretty in summer. Great place to chill out and relax.

Beautiful!. We spent most of the day wandering around the gardens, especially the roses in the Queen's Gardens. Gorgeous flowers and a quiet, relaxing day. It started raining around lunchtime, so it was a perfect excuse to stop at one of the cafes in the gardens. Nice way to spend a relaxing day.

London's Best Park. My all time favourite london park! It has everything! Rose gardens, duck pond, lots of wildlife, cricket matches on the week end and you can even check out the camels from the back of London Zoo if your feeling cheap ;) Both restaurants are no much better than before and there are incredible houses round the back that are worth checking out! All that and your 5 mins from baker street. Its a great park to explore as just keeps going and going. Also perfect for a morning run. Cant say enough good things about this place, its beautiful

Relaxing afternoon. I love Regent's Park. While Hyde Park is usually full of tourists and rather busy you can usually find quiet spots in Regent's Park even on a sunny weekend. It's nice to mingle amongst Londoners and have a picnic with friends here. Plus you are right next to London Zoo in case being lazy in the sun turns out to be too boring after a while.
Running 5K: perfect park size. My favourite spot to run in London as I usually stay nearby. It's the perfect size and great paths for a 5K.
Regent's Park. Clean and well-maintained historical site. Centrally located. Great for family get-together. A must see!

Peaceful, green and wonderful!. I loved this park because it was so quiet that you could just hear the nature noises. The birds singing, and the wind blowing.It started to rain when I was there. Despite the rain, the place looked incredible! It is so green that makes you stay more time just to sit down and contemplate the trees and plants.

Walk from Little Venice. We walked from Little Venice along Regent's Canal to Regent's Park. Would highly recommend. Very relaxing and enjoyable. Stopped at lovely cafe set in glass conservatory on bridge overlooking canal.
Picnic. Beauty in the city and next door to everything, great for a picnic in the oak, perhaps buy the things in Harrodsburg food court and then walk North.

Such a nice park. This is one of my favourite parks in London. It's so big and quiet and peaceful. It's lovely and green and a really good spot to spend and afternoon reading, or to go for a stroll or a run. I really like coming here.
Smells like a heaven.. silence in the middle of the city. It's peacefull. Walking around the roses, smeling their fragrance inside you, that's unbelivable. I say only, go and see.

Most Beautiful Park in London. I have been to most of the parks in London,and Regent's Park has the best gardens. Both of my visits were in June so there was a lot in bloom, but the park is also spectacularly designed and groomed so I am sure it would be lovely anytime of the year.

Beautiful park. Beautiful park but massively overpriced coffee and sandwiches, wait was very long and staff were calling their bosses whilst making coffee to say they had run out of milk! Overall, lovely park in the centre of London
Heaven in the heart of London. I loved strolling by the pond watching the swans. It is such a pleasant thing to do in London. Lunch in the Park!!

Beautiful . Such a fantastic settings in here, it's more than a garden very well looked after.
On a sunny a day, here in Regent's Park is the best place to sit and relax
Love it !!!!
Queen Mary Rose Garden. 12,000 roses at their peak in June and a glorious sight and scent. It is a clam refuge in the midst of busy London. With the long summer days, there is ample time for a visit.

Regent Park- one of my favorite parks…. We crossed Regent's park towards the Regent's canal. Lovely Park,
Beautiful lake, great lawn, ducks, rose garden, boats and little coffee shops.
We ended up in the Regent canal, a lovely walk which ends in Camden market.
Do not miss the park and the walk along the canal.

best park in London. Never miss visiting Regent park, in fact it's my favorite park, but u need to know one thing ( which I didn't know in the past as I visited Regent park more than 20 times during my frequent visits to London) the park is divided into 3 sections.. when u enter a section, and then u exit, u need to go to the next one, and the 3rd section is the best, lush green specially in the month of May which I visited this year because summer didn't start yet and it was so fresh and beautiful.

Interesting place. Very quiet, really nice place to take a peaceful walk, to take a deep breath into the city. London is great, the parks are so green! a lot of green . Not too big but enough to escape from noisy places
gardens. Regents Park has beautiful rose gardens. It also has a wonderful zoo. And in the evening you may spot a hedgehog as thats where they live.

Lovely place for a stroll, if a little big!. Went a couple weeks ago on a Friday and the park was fairly busy. Not being from London, it was probably empty but seemed full to me. Beautiful large park with parking nearby and of course London zoo. Dogs allowed in most the park but I did find it big so best to use a map.
Near Sherlock Holmes Museum. really Big pond. Very nice gardens, walk ways, fountains. There are boats you can rent (although it is not cheep) there is also a zoo ( I have never been to the zoo)
Take a walk. Beautiful in the Spring. A favorite place for Londoners to walk and get some sunshine. A lot of nice gardens to enjoy.

A pleasant break from the city rush!. London in summer can be hot and tiring, but Regents park offers a break from concrete and buildings. The atmosphere is relaxed and the gardens well worth exploring. Bring a map!

Wonderful experience. חוויה נהדרת. As someone who lives in the village, like gardening and landscaping, the garden's green spaces plus water accounted for the pleasure of a few hours. The encounter with various animal park spaces, by rich greenery, the sculptures were great.
כמי שגר במושב ואוהב גינון וגינות, נהנתי מאוד מהמרחבים הירוקים, שפע המים, המצחיה העשירה, החיות הרבות ומהאוירה הנהדרת. מומלץ בחום.

More than a park. I just walked through the park and didn't see the whole of it but fell in love with the place. There are no dogs allowed there which I don't really like but means that the squirrels are roaming free and are very friendly!

Beautiful . It's a park you could spend a day at! Just enjoying the sunshine, take a picnic and a book or a couple of games and just relax! I only walked through but wished I could have spent the day relaxing there such a peaceful but busy park! Will be going there for a day out even if it's a park!

Favourite London Park. This is my favourite London park. There are beautiful gardens in the inner circle. Head in that direction for lovely photographs by the waterfall. When you are standing on the bridge, you will see an island in the pond. walk around the pond until you get to the tiny bridge that takes you onto the island. Follow the path until you are opposite the waterfall. The best photos are taken from there. Explore that area as you can also go to the top of the waterfall. Beautiful weeping willow trees, lovely roses. This area changes with the seasons. The outdoor theatre is here, along with a very reasonable cafe that sells picnics. Walk through the hidden pathways to the big fountain. In the outer area, you can go to the lake and rent boats.This area is great for jogging, running. There are so many varieties of birds here, including ducks, geese, more-hens and swans. Near to the Regents Park Mosque is a children's playground with toilets. you can walk to London Zoo from here.To get there, take a tube train to Baker Street and walk to the park 5-8 mins. There is a shop by the station selling sandwiches and drinks and an ice-cream shop. The Sherlock Holmes museum and Madame Tussauds and planetarium are all nearby.

Excellent Park in the middle of London!. As with all other parks in central London, Regents Park provides a relief from the city. Based in the north side of London, there is a pond as well as a lot of greenery. Rugby and Football pitches are also available to hire in the park.

Nice park, family friendly . Regent's Park is the most park we visit in London. If it's a family gathering, a day out with my other half or a day to take the kids out, the choice is always Regent's Park. The park is very pretty with amazing flowers, the lakes and the ducks are so cute. The boats are very fun to go on and it's always an exciting activity for the whole family. Nothing compares to a picnic with the family. Always enjoyable.

Excellent roses and flower beds. The rose gardens have a variety of roses on display and other well colour co-ordinated flower beds. The crescent shaped garden with tree ferns and fountain was particularly good. The one criticism is the lack of dead heading in the rose gardens.

Better than Hyde park. This is a beautiful park with all sorts of different activities, with tennis courts, football fields, a lake with row boats, stunning rose garden and other various spectacularly manicured gardens. It also has the zoo, and close by is primrose hill with the amazing views of London skyline.Highly recommended, but bring walking shoes, and refer to the maps around the park, it's very easy to get lost!

nice to sit on the grass. it is a very good park plus there is a near by zoo and a kind of a botanic garden inside I went there and lay down on the grasses real relaxing i recommend couples to get an ice cream and sit on the grasses

One of the best Royal Parks in London. A great place to wander aimlessly or sit and chill. The Park has a variety of areas - lakes, play areas, rose gardens, secluded spots, cafes. London Zoo adjoins it and a must in the summer, is a visit to The Open Air Theatre.
Beautiful park. It really does feel like you aren't in London anymore. It's such a beautiful park perfect for a walk, picnic, sports games and just wandering around!
Peter Pan. The Open Air Theatre was wonderful. Peter Pan has now finished I would love to see Seven Brides fir Seven Brothers but it is so booked up already.

Perfect day out during a perfect weather. I lived near the park during my stay in London. So I decided to use my mornings to do my runs here. A simple run around the park takes about 30 minutes covering 5 km. The morning sun and cool weather is great for the run, passing by other runners and the occasional dogs on their walks.

A Great Exercise in how to get lost !. Regent's Park is well set out. There are pleasant gardens and walkways and it is not over crowded. The lake with ducks, swans and other birds is picturesque and there are plenty of open spaces to enjoy. That's the good news.The bad news is that in places it is like a maze. There are several directional maps but these are nowhere near as clear or helpful as the normal maps that are visible in many of the streets of the West End.My wife and I walked from Primrose Hill through the Park to Baker Street. The first thing to note is that the Inner Ring Road and Outer Ring Road are actually 'outside' the Park. The exit from the park to the road does not coincide directly with the entrance to the Park. This means it is easy to end up going round in circles. There were no signposts back towards Primrose Hill. Indeed we met a lovely couple walking and he was getting so frustrated that he was beginning audibly to speak loudly in very strong language. I think they were native English speakers; for anyone who is not a native English speaker or who does not know the layout of the Park, it can be very difficult to find one's way around.Better and more accurate signposts please !
Nice for a stroll. Nice for a stroll but if you want to be wowed go into the Queens Garden adjacent. Lots of green with easy walking. It was s bit tricky to find.

Beautiful day. We walked from Little Venice to Regents Park on a beautiful day. The beginning of the walk was not along the canal as there was some work being carried out, however after about half a mile we joined the canal again.This is one of those must do things when you come to London, you are not aware of the fact that it is there until you see it. It is a peaceful walk and very pretty,especially as the sun was out today.We spent about 2 hours in Regents Park and still did not see everything we wanted to, so I guess another visit is a must.I would recommend this area to one and all for a nice peaceful day out.Of course the Zoo is there as well if you are interested.
taste festival. taste festival 2015 loved it! great food! great people, lovely experience. Beautiful setting, well kept gardens and helpful staff
Go and see the roses before they're gone!. head to the Queen Mary rose gardens immediately. a great park with lots of cafe's etc and plenty of space for a picnic.

not enough time to really enjoy it. We visited Regent's on our jet-lagged day late in the day so the light was not the best for photos or to really experience the tiniest part of this huge park. Like the other Royal Parks, our focus here was birdwatching and we weren't disappointed even for the short amount of time we had.

the rose garden. if you are in London on June, go and see the rose garden. it is a wonderful place to see a huge variety of roses and perfume. take your time to feel the environment and absorbe the London live

Beautiful. We walked through from Camden to Portland Place and visited Taste of London.
The park is beautiful. The flower gardens so tasteful. Great space for everyone
Beautiful and peaceful park!. Regent was a great and wonderful surprise for me in London. A peaceful place for beautiful and long walks. Loved it!

Attraction . Without any doubt this is the place which attracted me with there live views.a place where you will forger the world.when you enter the park you'll realize you are not in earth.you are in haven.
worth a visit. It's a beautiful park and definitely worth a visit. If you enjoy a walk or cycling this is the park for you. It has amazing views and a great ambiance.

Splendid sight when the roses are in bloom!. Bordered on the south by attractions like Madame Tussard's and the Sherlock Holmes' museum, and on the north by the canals that run through Camden Lock, Regent's Park is a great place to relax, visit the rose gardens (in season), play football, turn your children loose, and watch kids sailing little boats on the ponds. A nice oasis in a bustling city.
Beautiful Park, Wide range of Birds. Went for a few sunrise runs, it was very peaceful, quiet and the range of birds in the park was quite cool.
Beautiful. Just a very nice park, that's all. As Australians, we liked the squirrels but they probably wouldn't impress you northern hemisphere types.

A place for everyday. A large park, many places for picnics and sports, wide open grass, great to get away from busy streets. Many art shows and outdoor sculpture exhibitions very now and again - lovely lakes with many birds

great roses in summer. plenty of space for children to play.
the rose garden is a must see and smells very nice in summer.
can easily spend the whole day there.
the shop is ridiculously pricy though. £13 for a £2 box of strawberry is a joke really.
Beautiful park. A little piece of heaven in a bustling city, amazing how tranquil this park is, would never guess you were in London.

also near Camden Market and London Zoo. we exited London Zoo into Regents Park. A vast park which families and couples seemed to be enjoying. Lots of places to rest and look at lovely gardens while others played/used the wide open field like grass areas. great place to let the kids run wild.

Heavenly park. This was hands down my favorite part of my recent visit to London. The roses were in bloom and beautiful and it was all around fun to see everyone hanging about and relaxing on a gorgeous day. Can't wait for my next visit back!

Worth a visit when in Camden Town. Walked from Camden Markets along the canal to Regents Park. This is very relaxing and picturesque. You can buy food at the markets and create your own picnic to eat in the beautiful gardens. Or have lunch in one of the many cafés. Definitely worth a visit especially after the crowds of people in the markets. The Rose gardens are magnificent in Summer.

One of the world's great parks. Regent's Park it's one of the world's great parks, on a par with any other capital. It has a lake, a zoo, several marvellous formal gardens and many elegant Regency buildings. Don't miss the lovely "hidden" garden of St John's Lodge just off the inner ring road, and the herons' nesting on the island in the lake,
adorable. great park to walk, running and etc. Besides it, there are lot of animals, like birds. it's awesome.

The one and only.my favourite. if you have to pick a park to visit it should regent's park. it is better maintained than Hyde Park, but it is big enough to feel free.The location is superb: next to London Zoo,Baker street tune station or short walk from Kings Cross.
Lovely. Going to the zoo, we stopped off in the actual park area first. Relaxing, well maintained and very clean. Greta place
Perfect place after a zoo visit. We walked through the park after the zoo visit. It is hugh with attractive playground for the kids. The park is also well connected by bus services and tube station.
Ideal place to visit with family. If you are travelling with kids, you must visit Regents park & make sure to spend a day. You'll have enough to do...

Great tennis in the park. I am a tennis player so I looked online before I went to London. There is a chain of Will to Win tennis centers and one is located in Regents Park. Look online for the website. Email the head pro, Sameer, and he will arrange a lesson or workout with one of the pros. Price is between 41 to 43 pounds per hour. I hit here twice and I enjoyed it tremendously. There are many courts and the place was very busy. There is a nice café inside and pro shop and there is free wi fi. If you want to play tennis in London, this is the place. Tell them Andy from Las Vegas sent you.

Best Park I Visited in London. London has a number of famous parks, but most of them are not famous for their merits as parks, rather because they belong to the royalty, or something important happened there, etc.Regent's Park, however, deserves a visit as just a park. It's fairly large and not crowded, good for jogging or relaxing, and the central part (Queen Mary's Gardens) is really beautiful and IMO mandatory on a first London trip. It doesn't hurt that it's between two major attractions—the Sherlock Holmes Museum and the London Zoo.

Would be a world class park without the traffic. This is an amazing resource in the heart of London.It would be so much better if the Royal Pavings Commission (who run the roads) restricted the motor traffic. Why a park has to have through traffic is a mystery. Local surveys show the vast majority of this traffic is not visiting the park, it is taking a short-cut through it. Speeds of over 80 mph have been recorded on the Outer Circle.Unfortunately traffic noise is dominant from almost every part of the park. Such a shame.Highlights are the flower gardens in the Inner Circle and the beautiful broadwalk down the middle.
a little haven of tranquility. just resting a while and watching the tourists.. we had my grandson with us and he loved feeding the squirrels which were quite friendly

Great retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city. It is appropriate that Regent's Park was once the hunting grounds of royalty but is now is available for all. Be thankful that we live in the 21st century and that we have the freedom to go and travel to places that our ancestors did not have the chance to see in their lives.The English are known for their love of gardening, and the this love is very apparent in the landscapes that are found in many areas of the park. Be sure to walk and take pictures. During my visit, the tulips were in bloom and the roses were just about to open their buds.Regent's Park is also a great location for people watching. It is here where you can truly find Londoners enjoying their time away from the hustle of the city. I visited during a weekday and it was fun to watch as different local schools came to the park to play different athletic events. It was amusing to watch PE classes where the students were playing cricket, lawn bowling, and croquet among other games. As an American, I was also surprised to see a group with ball gloves playing catch with a softball.As is the case in many public areas in Europe, the toilets cost money, so be prepared if you plan to spend a good amount of time in the park.If it is a nice day, Regent's Park is an excellent location to eat a picnic lunch. There were a couple of food stands, but some of them appeared seasonal. If you plan to eat in the park, check to see what is available and open before you go.

lovely place. i walked through regents park to go to london zoo and if you ever want a place to go for peace and quiet in london, i highly recommend coming to regents park early in the morning, the sun was out and me and my mother were highly tempted to just say no to the zoo and sit down in the little cafe we found and watch the world go by, we were shocked with how peaceful it was and how beautiful the gardens were.

Best park in London! . My favourite park, especially during spring/summer. There are plenty of things to do. There's a lake with boats available for hire. An open air theatre. Playgrounds for children. A few cafes to have a quick bite or a cup of coffee. The Zoo is located in the north area of the park. The canal is also in the north and it's quite enjoyable to take a walk down there.There's also a bandstand and if you are lucky enough you might see a band playing.Make sure you visit the Queen Mary's Gardens, they are just splendid!On the northern side of the park is Primrose Hill, with a stunning view of central London.

Beautiful. Have a look around this park especially if you are visiting London Zoo, it is everything a park should be, wide open spaces and plenty of more formal garden features. It's hard to believe you are in the centre of London.
