Walk Through Regents Park. Spent about 1 hour to walk around Regents Park. The blooming flowers were beautiful. We were a bit early and most the of gardens had yet to bloom. Easy to get to via Underground.

Peaceful. Wunderful rose garden. Animals, like black swan , birds, goose....
Peaceful for a break or a picknick.
Bakerstreet and Sherlockholmes Museum 5 Min away.
Love this park. This is one of my favourite parks in London. The boat rides are great in summer and it's right next to ZSL London zoo. Perfect for a day out.

Open Air Theatre - Peter Pan. AMAZING. Such a beautiful environment with all the lights and flowers. It is perfect to go on a summer day but is necessary to see the weather forecast previously because the show runs no matter what.I had a lovely time, the whole performance was extremely creative and gave an extra twist to the story. I would recommend for all ages, tourists and locals.

Walk in the Park. Children love seeing the ducks and wild birds. nice park to walk through. Worst bit, the prices of very ordinary ice lollies that normally cost only 80p being sold for £2.00. Total rip off for tourists
Great place for a relaxing stroll. Regent's Park is always lovely, nice and full of colours. If you want to detach from the World a bit that's great place....
friendly with kids. this is my go to park when kids feel they need to run. there is green there are animals, it's easy to spot them from far so don't get lost at all. and is clean.

My heaven on earth!. The perfect time of year to visit is in the month of June. The roses are in full bloom the temperature is mild and the park looks like heaven. Truly worth a stop if you happen to be in London during the Spring. Lovely.

Superb . Wow what a lovely place to spend sometime in. This was a spur of the moment trip but it was amazing the manicured gardens and fountains are gorgeous it definitely helped that it was a gorgeous day
Stunning. lovely gardens. The weather was gorgeous which helped but after a few days of sight seeing a trip here was a great break and it was lovely to chill in absolutely beautiful surroundings

What a great park. I was taken here by a friend who lives in London, it was a great sunny day and this place was full of life from people to animals it was great, its huge so you can always find a nice spot for yourself. If i lived in London i would come here every weekend and have a nice picninc with my wife (weather permiting)

An amazing green space. This is an amazing green space in the centre of London. We were amazed at the number if people jogging through the park. It is huge with everything you could hope for. We were amazed to see several sqirrels foraging and paying little attention to ourselves who were only feet away. Go visit, you will not be disappointed

A lovely place for a walk!. Large park with beautiful gardens and The London Zoo. Apparentlly the gardens would be at their peak in June, so we were a little too early. A pleasant place to walk or run. Small cafe in the middle of the park with washroom & shower facilities.
lovely place foran afternoom. The grounds are beautiful. Pack a picnic, stroll around and enjoy an afternoon here. It's close to the tube stations and easy to get to.

What a great park! So much to see and do!. Walking at the edge of the park, I ventured in, lured by the beautiful plantings. The roses were spectacular, so many colors, so fragrant, just great. The park is home to the zoo and a theater as well, and a Mosque to boot. So much to see, there are families everywhere, especially on a sunny day, which do occur.

Lovely Park. My husband and I loved walking through this park. We loved everything about London!!!! We thought it was spectacular! We really loved taking in all of the parks while we were there. Definitely a walking city.

One of the many lovely parks in London. I love to walk the streets and parks of London regardless of rain or shine, summer or winter. I visit through out the year so am used to wonderful and bad weather.I was there in May 2015 and very much enjoyed the Sunday late afternoon stroll through Regent's Park.It was full of families, couples and solo walkers by myself. Folks of all ages can enjoy the natural beauty of this park.

Amazing rose garden. Gardens were wonderful with roses in full bloom. A lovely place to stroll with varied areas from sports, gardens, wooded, lakes and a selection of eateries. If the weather is good to early to avoid crowds.
Wonderful. Big park, full of lakes and different bird species. Wonderful to have a walk, specially on Saturday mornings.

Enjoy it's vastness. As always a lovely gentle relaxing experience better when not major tourist season
Loads to see don't rush or you will miss some gems

Beautiful Gardens at Regent's Park. We had a very nice evening walk in Regent's Park. The highlight for us was the Queen Mary's Garden. It is a beautiful rose garden with many different types of roses. It is laid out in a unique circular pattern with large beds of roses. We enjoy seeing and smelling all the different kinds of roses. The garden was not in full bloom during or June visit be it must be spectacular when it is.We also enjoy the walk around the water areas.When we were there the park had some activity but not too much. It was quiet and peaceful pace for an evening stoll.You can take a boat out in the lake, visit the zoo, see a show in the open air theater but we didn't get to do any of these things in our first visit to this park so I am sure we will return.It was a short walk from the Regents Park tube station.
Lovely. can find a peaceful spot in london. love it, fresh air , boating lakes, not too busy. Definitely worth a visit
Regent's Park. Located near Madame Tussauds is the perfect place for a walk of at least one hour or for relaxation before or after visiting the museum.

Really worth a visit. We love walking around Regent's park in good weather.Visit Queen Mary's garden - beautiful roses with the scent hanging in the air. Try and remember to bring some bread or nuts for the birds and squirrels - they will feed from your hand :)

Not too large but with good variety. As well as all the normal stuff of parks (grass and trees etc., plus a lake), Regent's Park offers the London Zoo, an open canal walk, an open-air theatre, paddle-boating, ice-cream for much of the year, a cafe (crowded in summer) and a major art exhibition in October (Frieze Art) - a great concentration of options in a park that's easy enough to cross in about 20 mins on foot, from Baker St to Camden, or Euston Rd to St John's Wood.In some parts (the north-west corner on a warm weekend), there are so many veiled women that it feels like one's been transported to the exotic East, as if by a magic carpet. Best of all, a comfortable jog around the Outer Circle, which circumscribes the whole park, takes about 20-25 minutes. I did it every other day for years, till I retired. Or if you prefer to jog on grass, you can choose almost any distance you like, inside the park. Downsides: not enough seating, watch out for the duck-crap near the lake-water's edge, plus rather too many antisocial (sometimes aggressive) cyclists, weaving though the walkers.

The best park in London!. In my opinion, this is by far the best park in London. There are ponds, huge open fields, and beautiful gardens so it has something for everyone. Queen Mary's Gardens are especially stunning and are a must-see in June. I highly recommend visiting the park while you are in London.
Nice open green with great views.. Headed here to get away from crowds in Camden. Lovely walk uphill in open park with great views of London from the top. Worth a look if you are in the area.

Not London's Greatest Park, But .... An evening each month, the Baker Street Irregulars bring along telescopes to peer into space. You need not bring your own telescope or binoculars unless you desire.
Pleasant stroll through one of London "green lungs".. Great place to spend a few hours whatever the time of year. Lots of walks, flowers / shrubs, a boating lake and of course the Regents Park Zoo.

Wonderful. Absolutely totally wonderful.. This is the best kept secret in London, how come I had never thought to visit it before. But so glad I have now. The Regent's Park is so big; so beautiful and so empty of people that it is just wonderful. The formal gardens are simply beautiful, even when the bedding plants and roses are not in full bloom and the meadows are fields just seem to go on forever.We spent most of the day here and will come back again. You should too!

Excellent park. I thought Hyde Park was good until we went to Regent's Park. This is an amazing park. It is so large with a beautiful lake to hire a boat on or walk around the gardens and admire the plants and garden. We had lunch at the cafe which was affordable and a pleasant place to sit and have a drink. We didn't get to the zoo but walked around and enjoyed this huge park. If you only have time to visit one park in London you must go to Regent's Park.
Great Park. Without a doubt Regent's Park is one of the most loving and romantic park anyone could visit. Anytime of the year...it's always beautiful. Don't miss it when you come to London...!!

Perfect stroll. For any tourist, regular visitor, resident the park is a welcome open space of green lush beauty. Carefully manicured and well paved it offers a multitude of spots to sit, have a picnic, a rest..maybe reading a good book. Or just a leisure stroll. The sky is the limit here ! Always lovely.
Great family walk. Flowers and gardens are very nice, clean and well maintained. I think June will be best time to go for the flowers in bloom. Nice walk and play areas for kids.
Stunning park, albeit a bit popular!. I love Regent's Park - it is stunning. It is really several gardens ensconced in a much bigger park. They are beautifully kept, and have stunning variety.
Great Park. I have always loved Regent Park. The duck ponds, the inner and outer circle, the Zoo, the runners, the Rose gardens - it has hardly changed in so many years!

Open Air Theatre - Peter Pan. Highly recommend this show. Superceded expectations. Suits all ages.Stage set very creative and acting highly professional. It's not what one would expect from Peter Pan. If overcast, take some warm and waterproof clothing. It's all about appropriate clothing. And, don't forget the picnic. Enjoy the show.

One of London's best parks. Regent's Park is special. The gardens are nicer, the walks more interesting, the views less city-fied. It's a place for quiet strolls on busy days and it gives access to some great places, such as the zoo and Camden.

Beautiful Park - A Must See. Wow, Who would know that you are in the centre of London.Regents Park is so pretty and beautiful, you could spend many an hour either strolling around the park or just taking in the scenery or take a picnic.There are lakes with boats, playing fields, beautiful and colourful flower beds, a playground for the little ones, cafes, a lido.Such a lovely tranquil park, well worth a visit, forget the tube and take a stroll to your destination instead
The Park The Zoo. While perhaps not as famous as Hyde Park for my money,much more beautiful & one of the oldest & great Zoo's,well worth a visit for the beautiful gardens if nothing else.
Oasis in Central London. This used to be my nearest park & I'd love visiting throughout the year. So much happening here from the affordable art show in the autumn. Also home of the open air theatre.
Nice bit of green in the city. just wandered through on way back from zoo . Very well kept green park with children's play area. Lovely to relax or keep fit in

Calm and quiet. It's calm and quiet
There's a good restaurant called
(.EAT)
Nice place
You need a half day to cover it
Beautiful. One of the many beautiful parks in London, this place offers a great stillness amongst all the madness of the city.
Beautiful park. Great place to relax, have a picnic, let you dog/kids run around, people-watch. Very nicely landscaped, plenty of room for everyone!

Walk in the footsteps of royalty. What a wonderful park to stroll around and to take in the fresh air, sights and sounds of the natural world while only being a short walk away from the hurly burly of busy London streets nearby! It is the most marvellous park. Plenty of space to walk around, extremely clean and well kept with lovely floral displays and mature trees around you at every turn. It is well worth a visit to recharge your batteries if you are feeling jaded by shopping or too much sight seeing! Just around the corner is London Zoo-an amazing place to visit too!

Fantastic evening. Had good seats for Peter Pan, the performance was excellent. The use of the stage was memorising. We bought a picnic had ate that at one of many picnic tables within the theatre. You can bring your own wine or other alcoholic beverages and can even drink it during the performance food.Food is available, I saw someone with burger & chips (looked nice) and there is something else on offer but couldn't tell you what.We've been coming to the theatre for many years but I would say if you are a tourist to London this should be at the top of your list. If you plan to visit in July & Aug I would advise getting your ticket in advance (online) so you are not disappointed.Fan evening.

Takes All Sorts. A gorgeous garden for strolling and relaxing with a nice cafe to grab a bite to eat and a refreshing drink. Honestly, my favorite thing I did at Regent's was move from spot to spot and people watch, because everyone seems to go through there. I know it sounds mean or odd or just plain ol' silly, but try it--you won't be disappointed. ^_^

Stay here and enjoy !. This park is beautiful, my favorite before Hyde park. Big enough to have a long walk, different spaces (roses garden, playground for the kids, or just large grass-covered field). Always flowery ! You can also bike and have a picnic or go to the Zoo

Fantastic Birding spot and people watching too. This is a very large urban green space. Although there are lovely gardens and flower, there are great green spaces where you will see people playing cricket, football (soccer) and having picnics. If you are a birder, this is the place to go. There are several large ponds so expect to see many water fowl. We identified over 25 species just walking along with no binoculars. You can also hook into the canal path at the north end of the park.
Nice park. It's a nice park, there's not much to particularly say about it if you just fancy a walk it's good though.
Canals. Loved walking the canals that lead to Regents Park.. Enjoyed seeing the Canal boats. It is a beautiful area
full of activities. dont miss the sunset , the park is full of activities in the morning you can get free tai chi classes
Stunning. A stunning gardens, we went through on our way to London zoo, it was all the better for the sunshine being out, well worth a visit

Roses, a zoo and a great walk. From the heavy traffic of Marylebone Road head up to Regent's Park. It isn't touristy and is an amazing oasis. On one side are elegant Regency terraces, on the other, a long walk away is a Mosque. The first area you enter is a formal garden then you head on past casual football areas to a "long walk" with a cafe and then on to the zoo. If you like you can detour to the Rose gardens and the outdoor theatre.There's another section of the park with a mini Japanese garden and a large lake. It's a big place and great in all seasons.
Hidden Gems. Look out for the sculptures made from tree trunks - so impressive! The wide open space is well kept and really pleasant just to wander around and enjoy the weather.
Another wonderful park. Just close to St James' park and equally as beautiful. A good park to go to to get away from the crowds and recharge the batteries.
green and lovely. great gardens a lot of space and nice sitting . we spend all afternoon by walking and have great picnik

The paradise in the center of London . This is the perfect place to spend time with lovers , children , friends or even alone! All the park is blooming, colorful , cozy, a lot of space for picnic, games and walking! We were there in a cloudy weather but still enjoyed this place !

For Respite from the Wild West End!. Space to picnic, go for a row or just take the kids to play in the sandpit and in the playground - or go to the cafe, if you haven't time for picnicking - the rose garden is worth a visit and if you go i the Summer, there's the fabulous Open Air Theatre - we go every year for a Shakespeare, but there are musical and kid's productions - just take along some sunshine and you'll love it!
Always something on. Great place for a run or some sports or even if you want a nice day by regents canal. Usually quite busy but the park is more than big enough for everyone :)
Beautiful park in northern London. We went to visit the Sherlock Holmes Museum which is just on the outside of the park and could see how lovely it looks.

Regents Park. Regent's Park is like all the parks in London. They are so beautiful you must take a half or a full day for each one .Take your time to stroll the path's and take in the lakes,sit on the grass nod take in some sun . What a way to spend the day.

Free fun and wide space. Regent's Park was bigger than I expected. The wide open spaces and carefully interspersed formal gardens. We loved the walkways with fountains and also the lake (also a hit with the wildlife!). One negative point is the lack of WC facilities, we ended up leaving the park prematurely as a result.
A little piece of heaven.... The planting is beautiful. A great place to take a book and sit for hours. On a summer's evening check out the open air theatre with its fairy-light lit outdoor bar.

Lovely yet Royal privileged park!. Visited here back in Sep-Dec 2009 as a student of QMUL, I loved Regent's Park and St. James's Park as well. Very fresh and clean air produced by the flowers and trees. Great fountains in which you can take beautiful photos by, and wonderful musicians here practising)) Reminds me of China and the parks here too. Lovely!

Probably the nicest of all London Parks. London has 116 parks more than any other city in the world I think. I haven't seen them all but so far with its variety of lovely sceneries Regent's Park is most probably one of the nicest. It's ideal for spending at least half a day.
good fresh air. great walking and fresh air, hours of walking and looking at different things, friendly people and nice places to stop and have a coffee

A breath of fresh air. This is like Central Park in New York City. A quiet retreat from the bustle of the city. Great walking paths, and leads to Kensington Park if you want to go there. If you are traveling with children, it is a great place to let them run and play.

I love this park!. I work close to here so occasionally run around it. I went to an open air theatre production here in June 2014 and it was amazing. Beautiful part of London and a must see. London Zoo is here or just a good picnic place. Lovely x
So Many Dogs. I am a bird watcher so it was great to see so many species right within the London city area. Colorful flowers in every quadrant.

Cricket in the Park. Had a sandwich and a drink in the HUB food was okay staff need retraining in customer service. They all came a across as not particularly customer friendly. Perhaps they are in the wrong job?

Wonderful, very beautiful even in rainy weather. By far the best park in central London. Beats St. James and Hyde without a doubt. Colorful flowers, ducks and squirrels. Really lifts the mood, even in rainy weather.

Absolutely Beautiful Park!. My daughter attend Regent's University in London near the park. It's gorgeous. Lot of people outside enjoying it. People playing sports and paddleboats in the water. Make sure you go.

Beautiful Day. If the weather allows it go for a walk in this park, down the flower lanes and sit and watch some cricket while basking in the sun. Then a pint of Beer or Cider to cool off and you will have had fun.
Lovely for chill out. It's a big and very lovely park for chill out laying on the grass. You have some nice (but quite expensive) coffes there too.
Ride at the Regent's park. We rented bicycles and crused the park. Nice and quite atmosphere. Beauty everywhere. Generosity in space that we don't know from Switzerland.
somewhere to go. somewhere to go if its raining although exhibits are great some areas are quite small and claustrophobic due to large tourist groups.

A lovely, lovely park. We fancied taking a stroll from our nearby hotel, so popped into the park. Two and a half hours later, we were still strolling as the park is really beautifully laid out presented. The fountains and floral displays are always shown at their best, according to the season. As this is Spring a lot of new growth was in evidence, to support the existing established beds. Immaculately clean and tidy, and there were numerous ground staff around making sure that the park looked at its best.
beautiful lake. I enjoy Regent Park on a daily basis on my way to Bond Street. It is less crowded than Hyde Park during the week. The lake is beautiful with pigeons and ducks around. It is serene.

A must see. This park is larger than you might think. Whenever I go there I see something I haven't seen before. One of my favourite bits is the rose garden. It's simply amazing in the summer and the smell of roses.... out of this world!
Beautiful and restful.. Flower gardens fit for Regents, and close to 221 Baker Street. Did Sherlock roam here while trying to think through a crime?

Beautiful park in spring/summer. As a londoner I find Regents Park 10 times better than Hyde Park.You have all the fountains and intimacy in the park.Also in Spring its amazing the whole park blossoms and its full of flowers.Same in Summer,you can always find the perfect spot to hide and get a tan :) Also you have the Rose Garden which is beautiful and its worth visiting of course when its not raining and sun is shining :)
Beautiful!!!. The space is beautiful, well organised, planed and taken care. You can wander around or just sit and enjoy all day.

beautiful gardens to visit. Regents park is a great place to go. If you have children there are plenty of places for them to run and run. If you like gardens, there are some lovely planted borders and fountains, the park is huge and is great to take a picnic, and have a day out there.

A green oasis in the heart of the city. London's not so best ket secret is it's glorious parks and Regents park is the jewel in the crown. Wide open spaces give city dwellers space to breathe...in the summer there is always space for a quiet picnic and in the winter brisk walks are what it's all about. The rose garden in June is a stunning sight (and smell). There's an outdoor theatre and Londo Zoo on site too.
Hyde Parks little brother!. Had an enjoyable walk in the sun in this small but perfectly formed park. The rose garden is well worth a visit, it must be amazing in August.

Boating Lake. Lovely Park in the city. I would recommend the boating lake on a fine day, either hire a pedalo or rowing boat (depending on experience!!) and enjoy the views and calm of the park. Makes a nice change away from the busy streets, you almost forget you're in the heart of the city!
beautiful place!!!. One of the most beautiful parks of London. it's huge and quite clean. I loved it!!! A must go in spring!!

My favourite London park. I've walked Regent's Park from every angle and love every nook and cranny of this place. It's part of my upbringing; my Grandfather lived across the road and stopped traffic for us to cross, I went to London Business School on the edge of the park and I kept fit by walking every inch of these varied gardens. Make sure you take a stroll here when visiting London.
Beautiful walk. We went to the gardens of the Sultan of Brunei. We also walked around the inner circle and spent some time at the rose garden. All very beautiful.
great to people watch in the sun. if you fancy a day in the sun then this park is perfect grab a bottle of wine and sit on the grass and watch the world go by in the sun and safety of this busy park.
Love this park. everything >You have disabled facilities Toilets Food and the most beautiful flowers,lovely on a good day There is even an open air theatre ,

Serene garden at St John's Lodge. A relatively small, secluded and beautifully designed garden adjacent to St John's Lodge - located just outside the "inner circle' road that rings the Queen Mary's Gardens. The entrance is little marked at around 1 o'clock on the circle. The Avenue Gardens in the SE corner of the park were also in beautiful display. The roses will bloom soon in the Queen's Gardens and they were spectacular last year.

Beautiful day in the park.. Walked from Camden market along the canal towpath to Regents Park,found plenty of space to walk,good seating,a couple of decent cafés,gardens and a boating lake.Ideal if you want to get away from Londons hustle and bustle.

Now our favourite escape. This was a first for us, even though we have visited London often, and have walked the big three (Hyde, Green,St James) extensively. Regent's has it all, traditional flower gardens, large rose beds, two water features with pedal or rowboats available on the large lake, hidden Japanese garden, lawns, restaurants. Lovely to walk around, very relaxing, good for families, the most peaceful of any other park we,ve found in London.

A beautiful park!. We visited this lovely park for the first time on this holiday to London. It was an unplanned visit and such a surprise. It is more structured than Hyde Park, and has very interesting garden displays from top to bottom. We enjoyed our walk through there and also visit the Rose Garden Restaurant

A fabulous city centre green space. Just go and wander round. Especially have a look at the lake and the aquatic wild life (but take some bread to feed them with). This is wonderful for small children. The café next to the lake is good, but whatever you do, do not go to the café in the Hub. The staff there are some of the rudest people on the planet.

Beautiful, Peaceful getaway in Central London. I was recovering from a massive health scare at the times I visited. It was a nice getaway a little walk from my flat. The greenscape and ducks, geese, and other birds at the lake brings smiles to visitors and makes for nice photos to remember by.

Forget you're in one of the busiest cities in the world. One of the Royal Parks on the edge of Westminster and Camden. Boating Lake, some stunning old trees, gorgeous flower beds and the American Ambassador's Residence, not to forget London Zoo. A beautiful venue for a fine day.

Tulips. An absolute delight to stroll through the flower garden. Plenty of path area to the side for joggers and cyclists. A huge parkland with space for picnics and games. I've never seen so many well kept tulips of such a variety before.

A lovely oasis in the centre of London. Regent's Park is a lovely park which offers a quiet oasis, away from the traffic and city life so close by. It has a beautiful boating lake, which is lots of fun and a smaller one for children, with pedallos, also a large children's playground. Duck wander around amongst the visitors and the band stand offers entertainment throughout the summer, harking back to 'old England'! If you want to chill out, maybe with a picnic, I'd recommend a visit.

Lovely Park. This is a lovely large park to sit on the benches and have lunch over looking the lake. There are plenty of people around and small hire boats on the lake. Nice place to take and eat your own sandwiches. Parking relatively easy, pay & display. Very relaxing and recommended. London Zoo is one side of the park (separated).
Great Park. Very peaceful, so well maintained, great trees, so green. It was like being in Heaven. Awesome and perfect place for bird photography....
Lovely open area. Perfect for a picnic out in the sunshine! Admittedly we don't have lots of days of sun, but when we do, Regent's park is perfect for a picnic or a stroll with the dogs.
the best park of london. yes it's nicer than hyde park :) arrive this park after a walk from the canals begins from camden town. You will be so peaceful and calm.

Beautiful park. Walking through Regents Park on the way to London zoo to see the beautiful gardens with peole just walking there dogs, running, playing football, having picnics, just sitting & relaxing in the many seats that are available a few feet apart all the way through the park, or just going abut there buisiness & the Squirels & wildlife doing what they do Regents Park is heaven on earth.
Well kept. Lovely Park always well kept. Shame about the dogs running free as many people do not realise not everyone is comfortable with a 12 stone great Dane bounding towards them
Perfect run. Great Large park to go for a run. Passing London Zoo in the morning you can hear and see some of the animals

Great place for some tranquility. Wonderful setting in a very affluent part of London. Great gardens. Not much traffic in the area. Great for runners. Close to Euston and Oxford Street/ regent street.
Massive. This park is huge. The zoo is located here, there is a wonderful rose garden, beautifully landscaped. A nice place to come with your whole family to spend a day. Really nice.

nice city park. Park is nicely laid out, some parts dogs are allowed, others are dog-free.
We loved to feed the squirrels, while enjoying the park.

Amazing Spring day. Walked to Camden Market from Browns and on the way back to the hotel took a detour through the park. It was a beautiful sunny day and the Park was stunning with lovely landscaping and benches to it and watch people playing in the fields.
Lovely. Gorgeous and well maintained, lovely to be able to escape from the noise and bustle of the inner city and take some time out
Serene, massive and beautiful. Visited the park a couple of times on a recent trip. It's a beautiful place to escape to away from London's hustle and bustle.

Spring and its blooming. This is one of my favourite parks in London. Its a people's park and there are many people - young old, families and individuals -enjoying its space and beauty. The Japanese garden and the roses make it a sensual delight.

Spring is in the air.... The Regent's Park is simply amazing, especially in late spring with all the flowers, grass, colors and aromas.
There is everything for everyone. The zoo is just adjusent to it.
Well maintained park. Regent's park certainly lives up to all the hype. It's such a lovely park and it's huge! I'm always discovering parts that are new.
Flowery in Summer. Beautiful flowers, greenery and a pedalo lake. Picnic in the park or walk through, usually quite empty and very calm in a storm that is baker street.

Beautiful!. We walked from our hotel to Regent's Park-the entrance gates were a beautiful beginning. Lovely well cared for garden-one of the best things about London is their massive well maintained parks!
London zoo. The London zoo in Regent's Park is a great day out . If your staying in Camden it's an easy and pleasant stroll along the canal path for about 15mins and you're there!
Not Hyde park. Although it was March so a bit bare Hyde so much nicer. Great cafe though. Relatives went to Mme Tussands and were disappointed so glad for time in the park instead

Beautiful for pictures in Spring. Best part was the pond with the chubby (from being fed so much) ducks and swans. And all the flowers blooming in the Spring were wonderful. Clean and well-kept. Beautiful break from the fast-paced city life.
Beautiful!!. Nicer than Hyde Park for sure! Its smaller, and it is very beautiful! I travel quite a bit to various places and London's parks are just amazing!

A truly magnificent central London Park. Spring is a gorgeous time to experience all this park has to offer. I guess the beautiful flowers everywhere are out favourite aspect of this park. There's so much to see: boating lake, Regents Canal, lovely walks and it's easy to walk to Lord's Cricket Ground, Camden etc. not to be missed especially if you need a little downtime!

great day out. Miss the elephant rides,and the big gorrila but penguin feeding times still good laugh,not sure if they still have the chimps tea party ? Always was a highlight back in the day
Good and drinks very expensive

Beautiful park in central London. My wife and I recently visited London to visit our daughter, and we walked in Regent's Park, which was close to our rental flat. The park, including several arranged flower garden, is beautiful, and we enjoyed seeing the many different kinds of water fowl.

Beautiful piece of nature. There is a few selected places in the world, where you could just sit and relax in the middle of big city, watching at swans, and smelling flowers, in absolute silence. Regent's Park just can't be missed on your travels.
Great park. nice place to visit , awesome for a family picnic, can spend the whole day, beautiful place...................................

Lovely park and well maintained. In the spring the gardeners have been working hard to get the flowers coming out and this has worked as the whole area was colourful and lively. The area is litter free and clean and a nice haven in the hustle and bustle of the city of London.
Love this place.. We loved staying in the Regent Park area. Close to the tube and many great attractions. Great grocery stores with fresh fruit and groceries nearby. Can't wait to visit again.

An Oasis of Tranquility. Just situated as a next underground satation from the Warren Street and also within 15 minutes of walking the Royal Park 's expansive greenery, flora and fauna offers a peaceful sojourn to the visitor. Further LOndon Zoo is also there in the Park.
I just love the parks of London. In the Center of the City, where in the world you will get so many parks! Thank you London for opening our minds that how important an open space is in the City.

395 acres -12,000 roses in Central London. Regent's Park is an oasis of calm in Central London - all 395 acres of it !!! including the Queen Mary Garden .The Queen Mary Garden is best visited early June when the 12,000 roses are in full bloom -though right through the year there's something to admire across the whole of the Park.There's the Delphinium borders and the Begonia Garden and there's lots of benches to take in the sights and smells. The Avenue Gardens will soon have the summer bedding -look out for the lion vase -a large bowl supported by four winged lions.Or just wander -the Park is home to London Zoo and the Open Air Theatre -there's statues, fountains, and the boating lake -so much to see-or just relax.The bandstand in the park has a plaque commemorating the seven soldiers who were killed by an IRA terrorist attack during a concert given by the Royal Green Jackets on 20th July 1982. 24 others were injured.There's landscapes to enjoy and plenty of places to have a meal to make an enjoyable afternoon or morning .

Good park in middle of London. It is a good park in a good area of London. We went in April hence early in the season and it was cold. But still we had a good walk. It will be a pretty sight later in the year when there is more flowers and the weather warmer.Queen Marys garden will be good in around June when all the Roses will be in bloom!
A beautiful Oasis.. Take your time. Grab a coffee, enjoy a caffeine buzz and chat away with your fellow traveler(s) as you traverse this beautiful park.

nice spot to have a picnic. We stayed just north of Regent Park when we visited London in March. We often walked through the park to get the subway. Although summer activities were not in full swing, there were ducks and other birds to see, tennis being played and lots of green space. The boats were just coming out of storage and there were dog walkers everywhere. I would have liked to see it when the flowers were in full bloom as the tulips were just starting.
lovely birds and great people around. The trees were huge to hug them,it is a great "seance" to hug a tree,birds and people around are very nice...

Beautiful park. What a pleasure!. The foral arrangements are a feast for the eye. Each colourful flower bed is different from the next.The weather was sunny and we enjoyed a little picnic. There were many people relaxing in the sun yet it was quiet an peaceful. Amazing to have this beautiful green oasis in the heart of the busy city.

Lots to see and do in this beautiful park in London.. It's hard to believe that you are in the "centre" of London, when you walk through this beautiful park. Although not the largest in London (that's reserved for Richmond Park), you would be hard pushed to see everything there, even in a whole day. I remember how large London Zoo seemed, when I last visited many years ago; it occupies just a small corner of the park.If you love roses and time it right you are in for a treat; there are said to be over 12,000 plants (we must go back in June/July to see them in flower). Away from the roads that circle the park, all you will hear is the birdlife. Car parking "on site" is chargeable seven days a week. On a Sunday, we easily found free car parking only a 15 minute walk away (near the University College Hospital). There are a nuimber of London Underground stations next to the park.Overlooking the park are the elegant terraces of large houses/mansions. It's hard not to feel envious of the folks who can afford to live there.
Gardens & park. The rose garden is beautiful in the summer months and a peaceful place to have a picnic. I also love going to the open air theatre in Regents Park.
I love Regent's Park!. On a sunny day, it is great for a big leisurely wander or a power walk! Beautiful gardens, little cafes and ponds. Just fantastic. One of the best london parks in my view

Wonderful park for strolling around in the north-center of London. We visited the park during the spring and all the flowers were blooming. The park is extremely well-maintained, everything is symmetric and there are lots of ducks, swans (black and white) and other beautiful birds. I highly recommend a visit.

Lovely park on a lovely spring day. Lots of wildlife and a true oasis in the city. The flower beds were a delight and the bird life on the boating lake was really interesting and varied. We stayed nearby and it was a lovely way to spend early Friday evening

Had a extremly unusually nice day.. Spent quite a few hours visiting the grounds and gardens of the park, which will be better later in the summer right now only the spring flowers are blooming, there is a rose garden that will be terrific when it blooms. Zoo was fun to especially if you have kids with you.

Grateful to experience it every day. I'm lucky enough to be able to go to University at Regents University London which is actually in Regents Park itself. Owing to the fact that I don't like the university all that much, being surrounded by the beauty and the serenity of the stunning Park makes attending my uni all that much better. It's one of the last truly scenic places left in the centre of London, so if you enjoy an afternoon stroll, a jog or you simply want to take the dog for a quick walk, then I highly recommend Regents Park. Its not too big and very possible to walk around the whole park in about an hour.

My favorite park in London. I love to walk through Regent Park. London has many wonderful parks but somehow this one is my favorite. I love their gardens with beautifully arranged flowers and water fountains. They are so beautiful and make me feel relaxed after a long day of sightseeing busy London. I like to pick up early dinner at Camden Market and walk along the Regent Canal to the park. It's a fun walk. You can see what you don't see in the city here. And when you get to the other side through the gardens, you have Marylebone High St. where you can enjoy London again, all refreshed! My best way of enjoying kick-back evening in London.

Calm away from the madness. It's easy to be consumed by the hustle & bustle of London. Whether you live here, like I do or you're in town for a city break. Most people tend to hit all of the main attractions of the city that involve queuing for a while, getting barged around by fellow subscribers of Wanderlust or paying over the odds for gimmick sights. Anyway, if you're looking for a few hours to unwind, take a stroll without fear of walking in front of a red bus or black cab then this is the place.There's something about Regents Park that allows the most tightly wound tourist or resident to just relax & smell the roses. My tip for your visit to London.
Best park in London. I used to go hear with my grandparents who lived nearby. Love the zoo and feeding the ducks! Beautifully landscaped and with lots of water features.
Peaceful and calm.. We enjoyed a beautiful walk through this lovely, well cared for Royal Park. Also lunched in the excellent café.

I don't know what I love the most of Regent's Park!. I always have been a nature lover, and when I moved to London, Regent's Park has been my first green spot where to hide from the city's chaos.At that time, I used to live at Camden Town, which I hated, and every morning I was running at the Park. Surrounded by ducks, swans, different smells, beautiful gardens, and colors. I loved watch the dawn at Regent's Park it was poetry. Maybe I might be too syrupy, but so far, it is the most romantic and idyllic Park I ever visited. When you walk in, you feel as if you are miles away from the London's madness. If you are having a bad day, run there, after, everything will have a better perspective.It is ideal to practice sports, watch someone doing sports, relax, meditate, have a picnic or just have a nice walk.Everyone should visit Regent's Park once in a lifetime.

The best park. This is the best park in London in my humble opinionGreat for people watchingOn a fine day take a picnic and waste a few hours hereIt's a great place to escape the madness of London So tranquil
Nice walk. I loved walking from the BBC headquaters down to Regent Street and all the way to the Victoria Station. It has amazing stores, lots of restaurants and pastry shops. Loved it

Peaceful Oasis of calm. Regent's Park is a real gem, a quiet oasis for the bustle of Central London, close to many tourist destinations such as Madame Tussauds, Sherlock Holmes Museum, Marylebone High Street, the Mosque and the Zoo, it is a quiet and safe place to stop, relax and unwind. Many traffic free walks of various lengths, especially round the boating lake, good cafe near the Tennis Centre and places to eat your own picnic, either on one of the many benches or one the well tended grass. Copious amounts of (nearly) wild life including water birds of many kinds, pigeons and doves, hundreds of squirrels, to watch whilst you rest.Best park in London.

The most beautiful park in London, or certainly most-manicured. I have studied near Regent's Park for years, and it is a wonderful place to take a short trip when you are in London. It was almost everything that you'd want in a park. It has the wonderful Inner and Outer Circle configuration, with inter-crossing paths all over the park, and it's wonderful lfor all - walking, running, cycling, sun-tanning or picnicking. Many just sit and read, sleep, snack, kick a football or walk the dog. There's the ducks and swans to feed, the youthful enjoyment of London Zoo, or the culture of the outside Theatre. Then there are the magnificent scented rose blooms in summer in Inner Circle. What better free rest and relaxation is there for all, including friends and the family?

A long-time favourite. I've known and loved Regent's Park for a long time. What I most appreciate are the rose gardens, and the lake/water areas. Also that although it has many different areas, for different moods. One can be tucked way, reading quietly, or out in the sun on the deck-chairs, or meeting a friend in the fabulous cafe, or taking long walks in the gardens, or watching the ducks. Truly something for everyone.

Amazing park that has everything a park need to have!. The park is truly a gem of the city. It is one of the biggest parks that I've seen and certainly the most beautiful so far. The park borders with the zoo at one point and you can see some animals right from the park. There are lots of animals in the park itself as well. Ducks, squirrels, dogs (with people) and of course lpts of people everywhere. People playing cricket, soccer and just having picknick on the green vivid grass. There is a drinking fountain for the thiraty ones and a wc for the ... ones ;)The flowers in the garden aare gorgeous!
Come Back in June. One must return in June to see Queen Mary's Roses in bloom! Nevertheless, at any season it is wonderful park.

Beautiful & Perfect for Rest or Exercise. We stayed a few blocks away from Regent's Park on our recent trip to London. It was the perfect park to be near. It has wonderful paths and streets that circle the park and make it great for walking, jogging, riding bikes, etc. It also has plenty of places to just sit, kick back and enjoy the peace of nature inside this busy city. Regent's Park also houses the London Zoo, which is great for the family.
most beautiful park. Regents park is one of London's most beautiful parks, it is must visit, the rose Garden is at its best in May- June. there is also an open air theatre.

Nice place to relax. I was lucky and I visited the park in a week in a good weather (beggining of April). It is a nice Park to visit, do some jogging and relax.
You also can view some squirrels.

A Classic Staple of London Leisure. One of many a youngsters memories of this park start in childhood. A safe and trafficless place for infants and small children to run free. The layout is very clever, and spots which require extra attention to the childrens' welfare are relatively well guarded, and guardians have time for the 'save the lemmings' life'-run!It was set aside initially by Henry Viii and recognised for its' potential contribution to regal leisure-filled moments by succeeding monarchs. The lawns are always well-tended, with seasonal, and sometimes out of season species of bulbs, shrubs, and resident trees, which have witnessed its' continued contributions to Central London life over time and many a colourful picnic/or gatherings of like-minded compatriots, and fun-filled moments. London zoo is also located here, with its' world renowned inhabitants, as well as the summer open air theatre. A magnificent and continuing staple of London living. But, BEWARE!!! don't get lost in the outer or inner circles!
Beautiful park, every day of the year. This is a beautiful park for a stroll, a run or just to lay down relax, sleep and enjoy the sun. It has nice flowers. There are points to buy refreshments.
Calm. Calm place. great park and lake. Lots to walk around and spend an afternoon. Lovely restaurants near by. Take a company, walk , relax and spend some quality time

Regents Park. I was staying with my cousin in London who took me to regents Park. It was nice and pleasant in the evening. A good place to take kids and play with them and a good place to walk around!!!

Lovely place to sit in the sunshine. The gardens are looking beautiful in the April sunshine. Busy day but loved just have a sit down, read my Kindle and watch the world go by. One work of warning...you have to pay to sit in a deck chair, no signs anywhere to say that and the charge is far too high!!! Still loved the visit!

Beautiful park with lovely flowers. Well maintained garden, beautiful flowers, a lot of space to sit, walk, enjoy, sport,...A big difference between the bustle in Oxford street and the quiet in this park.
so nice place. relaxing and amazing park to enjoy yourself. Very British i must say. Plus there is a Zoo park which it is plus to spend your day
A worth rest during the journey. Nice place to take a rest, enjoy the view or even to walk trough. Nice for all kind of tripper. Points of refreshment.

An Excellent Green Lung in London. We walked through Regent's Park on our way back from London Zoo - lovely straight walk through the well maintained gardens. Our 5 year old granddaughter thoroughly enjoyed the walk.

nice park. like the birds in the boating lake
the canal around it
a little underwhelming considering its reputation

Beautiful place to stroll or rest. Huge park with a variety of areas. Lakes, park areas, formal gardens. It's got the lot. Spent nearly 5 hours over 2 sunny days, enjoying the gardens and sitting watching the world go by.
Definitely worth the visit and a great place to calm down and chill away from the noise and pollution of the London traffic

Stick to the Rose Garden!. Much of the park is devoted to sports facilities and open fields, but if you stick to the Inner Circle and beautifully landscaped avenues in the southern portion of the park, it's a heavenly breath of fresh air in the city! Also a fabulous place for picnics!
Good Park. Spectacular location and really well maintained. Historical buildings all around !!! in the middle of central london..look out for special events!!!

A walk in the park. This is such an amazing space in the heart of London, siping, summer,fall or winter, what ever the season this place is full of enchantment. Such a lovely place to walk, relax and enjoy the best London has to offer.

A Zoo in the Middle of a Park? Who would have thought it!. Regents park, large grounds that holds London Zoo. Lots of animals to see and you could spend a long time here. It has various enter/exit areas, so this can be a bit confusing, especially if you end up by the back way, which is not uncommon. The animals look happy and well cared for. The park itself looks good, clean and inviting.

GOOD. visited this park whilst waiting to get into maddame tussards, which is just around the corner.usual park stuff,people sitting around eating etc.long walk around the lake if your fit.a few cafes, but we found these expensive.good stroll though.

Holiday. Typically London and lovely. The weather was great,the park was clean and the people were friendly.London is very animated and cosmopolitan and full of history and places of interest.There are so many restaurants and eating places with a wide choice of prices and cuisine! Fantastic city!

Large, well arranged and a beautiful park!. This park has something for everyone and we visited twice . It was very peaceful to stroll the paths and watch all of the activity going on. There were fields for athletics, fountains and flower gardens, paths for walking, running or biking,a lovely lake for boating and more. Records show it became a park in 1812 and a John Nash designed it. There is an open air theater and a bandstand for summer enjoyment. We really enjoyed stepping away from the city and finding this wonderful oasis in London.

Amazing park. Great play area, walks, views and a large boating lake for adults and families and a small for the young ones to captain their own pedalo. Fab day out on a sunny day in the city. Take a bucket and spade and picnic
Lovely even in early spring. Walked the length of Regents Park on the way to Camden locks. It's so beautiful. Especially enjoyed the waterfall and bridge.

Sausage in the park. On a beautiful day, Regent's is the best park to go for a stroll and have a little rest in the lush grass. Don't forget to have a Cumberland sausage at the Smokehouse, formerly The Honest Sausage, smack bang in the middle of the park. Beautiful gardens and immaculately kept flowerbeds - I'd love to go back when all the roses are in bloom!

Just great!. This is my favorite park in London. Nearby to an aristocratic neighborhood with beautiful houses, it is an oasis, quiet and within easy reach from central London. Queen's Mary's garden is just so beautiful. Prepare to spend at least two hours.
weekend away. I enjoyed being able to see London and enjoy the Theatre, also was able to spend some time shopping in Oxford Street, and spend time relaxing with friends.
First visit. Beautiful park with many activities. Near Baker St. and the Sherlock Holmes Museum and house. Zoo here too, want to return to it soon.

One of the Worlds Best Parks.. There is so much to this wonderful city centre park. In the very centre, the hidden gem, Queen Mary's Rose Garden. Visit in the summmer time to see the thousands of roses in bloom. Be mugged by squirrels looking for snack. Take some peanuts and make them really happy. The sparrows are so trusting here, they will take seed from your outstretched hand. Be sure to take some seeds too.Visit the wonderful Zoo. ( This can easily take the whole day)Thies park was laid out by Nash for the Prince Regent. So marvel at the amazing terraced homes on the east side of the park, for all the world like a Greek temple with their amazing roof line statues of the Gods..There are Nash terraces to be seen also on the south and west side, but I love this one the most. Visit the beautiful mosque on the West side.Take a boat out on the lake,See Shakespeare plays in the open air theatre.This is the park with everything, and so much to discover.
Nice park. Well kept park with lovely grounds, walk round the lake and enjoy the sunshine (if its sunny the day you go !!)

Lovely retreat. The park was a relaxing retreat from our busy city weekend. We had amazing weather and decided to picnic in the park. I was impressed on how well kept the gardens were. We relaxed in the gardens and enjoyed the open space and tranquility. Unfortunately did not have time to explore all the park but will definitely return.

a beautiful park. I find this park the most beautiful park in London. It is quite big, but smaller than Hyde Park. It is on a hill which enables having nice views. It is border on the West side by the London Business School beautiful building, the Islamic Cultural Center, the residence of the American Ambassador.There is a boating pond with duck.There are a few building (schools, cafe et house?) in a rod called the inner circle, in the center of the park.There are long alleys surrounded by trees, and large open space areas.It takes about 1.5 hour to walk around it. It can be reached from Baker street .
All in Once. Close to Baker Street and Sherlock Holmes; the Central Mosque and the London Zoo. Lovely scenery and things to do on the water and on land.

A relaxing quite green place in buzy city. I simply love this park.It is perfect for family picnic.jogging.walking.wandering or having buddies get together.It feels like you are in Alice wonder land.once you get into the park you simply feel the relaxing athmosphere.like being in a small forest in the middle of the city.I love the Queen Mary's garden.In summer time this garden is quite favorite place for wedding picture shoot.If you feel thirsty it has ready money drinking fountain. ON a hot day the water coming out of this fountainIf you have no plan for picnic in this park..the benches near to the fish pond simply good spot to enjoy the sunny day or just relax a bit for fresher airItaly Garden is another perfect spot to have small picnic .the green grass n pine trees just beautiful .

A green oasis. First time we had visited this park a welcomed green oasis away a welcomed break from the very noisy streets of London. From the beautiful formal flower beds to the boating lake there were plenty of places to sit and maybe have picnic or go and have coffee on site or simply just enjoy the surroundings. So pleased we visited.

Really Beautiful. This park is really nice to walk through. Is very big so you might get lost but that's the fun of it and there are maps around to guide you. The flowers around the park make it really beautiful so if you are around there, check it out.

What a pleasant surprise. We don't know London well but have always been rather underwhelmed by some of the Royal parks, particularly Hyde Park. As we staying about near Euston and had a couple of hours to kill before our train home, we decided to walk along to Regent's Park. What a lovely park, even so early in the season (late March). It was clean, spacious, quiet and well maintained. Lots of colour already in the garden and I'm sure the rose garden will be spectacular in the summer. Very pleasant walk around the boating lake with lots of birds to see, including a number of peacefully dozing herons, who weren't in the least bit phased by all the humans around. The bright but cool day helped, but we will certainly visit again - hopefully with a bit more time to spare.
Stunning. Stunning Park, something for everyone.... no better place to sit down and watch the day go by, all chilled...
Best Royal Park. The best Royal Park in my opinion. I particularly like the Open Air Theatre, its fabulous in Summer. Also endless possibilities to swim in adjoining Hampstead Heath.
One of the best parks in any city. What a wonderful park in the heart of such a big city! Great to see the lake with its bird-life as well. Great for a jog or a stroll.

pleasant if you have the time. Exemplary gardens, shrubs & trees; a haven of peace for a romantic walk; also on the fringes you have the Zoo, and the excellent floating Chinese Restaurant. Watch out also for live outdoor entertainment in the park, in summer.

Beautiful Park, Beautiful Gardens. Lovely spot to visit. Family friendly, and fun to watch couples with their dogs. The gardens in the center with the pond are the real treat. Delightful waterfowl, including two very friendly black swans.
March sunshine. Nice to stroll through park on way to science museum. Plenty of people enjoying london in spring sunshine.

Lovely. I love this park! It has just about everything you could want in a park visit. There are beautiful flowers and ponds, the animals are friendly, there's shade and sunny areas, places to relax or play sports, and the landscaping is beautiful! You can visit every day throughout the week and have a completely different 'park' experience!

Beautiful park and great location. I liked this place to walk around during summer days. It has an open air theatre that show great plays. Also there is a beautiful rose garden and a lake. You can walk easily to OXford Street or Camden from there.

best park in London. Do not miss this park. Much prettier than Hyde park area. In late April it is a must see flower garden. We travel to London in late April mainly for the beautiful flower display which we think are better than the Chelsea flower show in late May. The London Zoo is here; nice but small. In summer, Queen Mary's Rose Garden is a must see.
An enjoyable day. I enjoyed walking through the Park before and after a visit to London Zoo. The plants and flowers were beautiful to behold.

Lovely royal park .. As my hotel was not far from regents park i decided to go have a nice stroll . As its a royal park its beautifully kept , the boating lake is lovely and i was very impressed to see 5 stolks lined up along the edge , i did notice they nest on the island too which was lovely to see . Lots of things for the eye to see and keep you interested while your enjoying a walk round . Its great to see people make the use of these free out door spaces still .
Our Favorite Gardens!. The collection of roses and the layout of the Queen's Garden is exquisite. We visit the garden whenever we are in London and wish to relax in the most beautiful surroundings.
An Nice Retreat. I walked over from Camden Town and was delighted to find a quite place in the sun. Plenty of walking trails and benches to chill out and rest.

Just Lovely. It is one of the best parks I have seen in London. It is really huge and surpassed all my expectations of a park. The small lake adds to the beauty of the park. I could not stop myself from clicking the pictures of various birds and flowers.
lovely!. really lovely park- people watching, fantastic kids playground etcvery picturesque- can get busy. great for bird life, boating, great cafe
Great week ends. This is a place to visit for walk and wonder around with lovely places to drink or eat with figurative sculptures and beautiful views
Lovely!. Beautiful! You should visit this in spring or summer when all flowers are in bloom. And don't be afraid of the squirrels! They are very nosy!!!
Beautiful Park. We visited just as spring was beginning and so the daffodils, heather, cherry trees and the like were all in bloom. Lovely place for a stroll.

One of the best parks in London. Whenever you can make sure to include a visit to Regents Park, you'll forget your in London with so many great views and lush parkland. making your way over the various bridges accross the water and finding new little hiding places for the animals who call the park home is brilliant.

A wonderful park!. This beautiful park is well kept with lovely walks and delightful planting. Queen Mary's Garden is well worth a visit, numerous rose gardens with many varieties, A visit when the roses are in bloom is essential
A royal park!. One of London's royal parks, very well maintained, you can spend at the least a couple of hours per visit. Primrose Hill is nearby.
Super. Had a nice relaxed day here, green grass super clean and no people that disturbed me, evrryone is busy doing their own thing.
Running in the green. I love running in Regent's Park, animals and green all over, there is a tiny lake and the Zoo is just few steps away and you can see the animals… Love it!

Great for a walk at any time of the year. We regularly visit Regent's park as we enjoy the atmosphere at any time of the year. In the winter it is brisk walk time but in the spring and summer it is a delight to sit in the inner garden and watch the world go by. The rose garden is a popular location for wedding photographs and in the fine weather there are often wedding parties being photographed.The heronry is always interesting with a large number of birds who sun themselves on the banks in good weather.

My garden!. Close to where I have lived for nearly 30 years this place offers so many wonderful things. London Zoo, walks, open air theatre, rose garden reasonable cafes [not as good as previously most sadly].Best of all it is a great place to wander and see the heronry and lots of warming sights.
Beautiful!. Regents park is a must see in London. It is very close to primrose hill which is also great for a stroll around. Great to have a picnic and enjoy the gardens!

A nice park in central London. It is a great area with several attraction inside. You can walk, biking, sitting and do whatever you want. During the hottest summer days it is perfect place to rest a little.

Morning walk before flight. I have been to London 2 times before, unfortunately both times in late autumn. But this time - Spring :) As I had few free hours before flight, my goal was ,,walk in park,,. It was definitely worth it - all the beautiful trees and flowers etc. I totally lost feeling of being in big city. The pearl of Regents park is Queen Mary's gardens - can`t describe, have to see it yourself.

Green area near Harley Street. Great open space near close to medical centre of London and Madame Tussuads. Lovely walks and laid out gardens. Lake and outside theatre in the summer months. Nice restaurant with lawns. Good Cafes and facilities for children. London Zoo situated to the North. Good are a to park car to avoid conjestion charge if visiting Harley Street only ten minutes walk!

close to baker street. this park is picnic heaven .close to tube station its a great place to people watch from joggers to families from london celebs to eccentics if you have time its a short walk accross the road from the zoo side of the park to primrose hill which is the best free spot to view accross this great city

Beautiful. The park is lovely, their are frequent runners and families, but I remember last year how busy it gets in the Summer. They have little ice cream shops and cafes around. Great location, right outside the station. Great for a picnic, and a cold stroll.

Gorgeous park so close to one of the busiest cities in the world. The playgrounds were lovely for my children and they loved the freedom to scoot around. It has various things on such as an open theatre which are worth checking. Nothing to dislike.

Lovely again today as the spring flowers are coming through. I came here for a walk today and as the sun was shining it was wonderful. The almond blossom is coming out as are the daffs and it was warm enough to sit in the Sun. If you are visiting London come here for a couple of hours to stroll around this huge free attraction.

Fresh air in the middle of the city. I love this park. It is very diverse: lac, football pitches, flower gardens...its bigger than you think and is a perfect place for a picnic and kick about on a Sunday afternoon

Nice open and a relaxed feeling. Sit on a bench and enjoy the sun and a statue/fountain or stroll through the park and have a look at all the different types of people. Would love to come back in the summertime to see all the roses.

Beautiful park in a wonderful area of London. Bordered by Nash terraces, a green sanctuary with wonderful trees and plants, lovingly cared for.
A bonus is the Regent's Park Theatre which stages open-air productions of Shakespeare and other illustrious playwrights during the summer months - well worth the tickets - just hope it does not rain!
Sunday walk. Lovely park , husband and I enjoyed a long walk and were lucky with the weather, nice to see all the runners and people enjoying some exercise and fresh air.
lovely. lots of squarells who u can feed with nuts! lovely park for a romantic walk, or walk with a child. lots of nice flowers, beautiful place

A Walk to Remember. If you are lucky and manage to catch a bit of the British summer, which usually lasts about 3 weekdays... Then go for a walk in Regent's Park. You are not going to meet the Regent for sure, but you will be able to enjoy the scenic beauty that Regents enjoyed. Lovely old trees, a big lake with flocks of ducks and geese who will eat bread from your hands, birdsong if you are deep enough otherwise that gets drowned by the traffic noise outside, some lovely old statues and lots of amazingly fresh air.In winter, when it's not raining, it's again a lovely place to go. There is a sense of quiet that dawns there. Wrap up well and take that walk!

London's equivellent of Central Park..... An enormous park within London that on a sunny day will provide a great day out. I'm sure the internet will provide much more detail and information than I can possibly write here.If arriving by public transport then fine, but if arriving by car then forget it, absolutely impossible to park and beware traffic wardens.London Zoo is next door, Hampstead Heath just a couple of miles North

A great park for a run. All parks in London are extremely safe to walk in alone.This is my local park where I run and cycle around and thought that sporty visitors would like to know the following:The outer circle is 4.6km and you can run on the pavement around it at any time of the day or night. It is a bit dark and you will be met by heavy armed police guarding the american ambassador's residence who lives in the park.If you hire a "boris" bike you can also cycle around it.The perimeter around it us closed to traffic between 10pm - 7:00 am which makes it a mecca for club cyclists in the summer

Ducks galore. Beautiful park and had a great variety of ducks and geese in the ponds. Plenty of information displayed about them. Only slightly annoyed at the teenagers who ignored the signs saying 'DO NOT FEED' the ducks.

Relaxing park. Regents park is well managed and clean.It is nice to just sit and relax and watch the world go byListen to the birds and watch the cute dogs being walkedA tranquil place in the center of London
Great Central London park. A great place to walk around in the Summer. Also gives you a view on where the very wealthy reside! One of my favourite London parks. Also now a centre of learning.

London landmark. Regent's Park has many gardens and flowerbeds that make it the most scenic of the major London parks. It also has its own boating area. There is a nice cafe that you can visit whilst exploring the park. Quite conveniently located as well, you can reach it easily by tube.

Beautiful and peaceful park. I love walking around Regents park, particularly in the Spring and Summer when flowers are in bloom and it is full of colour. It's one of the best parks in London and definitely worth a stroll around if you are visiting.
Weather didn't dampen the day. Superbly laid out, vast areas of grass, ponds and gardens. A treat for all ages and a little peace away from the noise and traffic.

Rural London. How lucky are the locals to have a facility such as this on their doorstep?
Right in the heart of the capital is this little piece of tranquility and peace; somewhere to refresh the lungs and wonder at the superb features on display - horticultural and others.
What a splendid place.

Just amazing. I worked in parks as a young man and remember them looking a little like this for quality. That was a long time ago, this park was how I remember parks to be. It was full of attractions and top notch plants. A really nice and peaceful place in the madness that is London

ONE TO VISIT. In the heart of the city lies a traquil park which is REGENTS PARK which i recommend one visits during summer time, only for the rose garden within the park which has all types of rose flowers for your senses!..a must.

Relax and watch the world go by. We have spent a few hours sat in the park iin the sun and it was relaxing with many people; skaters, bikers, picknipers parents with babaies meeting up and pleanty of places to sit. Good before or after London Zoo and there are cafe's not cheap but good coffee

Lovely. i went to see Shakespeare in the garden in 1969 and they are still doing it, although the sling back chairs on the lawn have been replaced with an open air theater. Queen Mary's garden is magical with songbirds and nicely overgrown water features. And the roses - oh the roses - beds and beds of them, each sorted by the most insane names. Flocks of crocus and daffodils in the spring. A nice afternoon's walk - with a pizza place near the Baker Street end. Adjacent to the zoo. I

A lovely park. The park is lovely, very tidy and pretty. Nice plants, fountain and lovely for a relaxing walk. There is also a place you can get tea, coffee, something to eat which has toilet facilities that were also very clean.

A really nice park. come here on a summer day with a picnic and a blanket. It is very nice to walk around and get fresh air, then you can eat outdoors and have a glass of wine. I come here with my family when the weather is good and the kids love it.

One of the best parks in London. I highly recommend a visit to Regent's Park, simply beautiful and not as crowded as Hyde Park. Spending the afternoon walking around the park was a family treat, the kids sure loved it.

Lovely Place. I like that is so beautiful, and calm and smells fantastic.
We like coming here to relax at any time of the day or evening.

Lovely park, but not London's best. Had a brief walk through this park, saw some local wildlife including a rather over friendly duck which came to other visitors for food. Gave a tramp my packed lunch especially after he asked so nicely. He was very grateful. That was my good deed for the day :)
spectacular park. lots of features, flower gardens, boating lake, opportunity to peep into the zoo, very well maintained, an oasis in middle of london
It's just a park. What can you say, it's a park in a city nothing special. It's certainly not worth a special visit.That said Central park in NY did nothing for me.

lovely walk. had a brief walk, around 40 minutes, and saw lots of local wildlife including a very friendly squirrel which came to other visitors for food. watched some tennis training and nice fresh air.

lovely park. we headed here more to stop for a quick lunch but ended up strolling since the ambience is simply lovely in summer. our daughter particularly loved the ducks at the stream inside and we even spotted couple of cute young ones underneath the bridge. Good place to click some nice pictures as well.
An Oasis. Like many of the London parks, this provides a calm and pleasant Oasis when you are spending the day in a busting city. Pleasant without being spectacular.

Regents Park Bliss. A beautiful and fulfilling experience in the heart of London!
A relaxing and peaceful place with opportunity to interact with a variety of wild life, inc. those on the pond
Highly recommended

A Must Do Experience. Regents Park is a London icon and is a beautiful, peaceful and relaxing oasis in the middle of London
Take time to stroll and then sit and relax with a drink and/or a snack and you will leave refreshed
Highly recommended

Gorgeous. I did a study abroad stint at Regents University which is nestled inside this expansive park. It was a beautiful place to live and study. There are many things to see in the park but the rose garden is worth a visit rain or shine. Simply beautiful.

Regent's Park, London.. This was once the Regent's Park, but now open to all comers. An incredible spacious green space, where numerous football, rugby and even baseball games are played, and where runners and strollers intermix. The lake caters to boating and duck lovers and London Zoo to those interested solely in animals. There is something for everyone in this vast park - Open Air Theatre, Cafeterias, ice cream parlours, childrens' playground, and once a year conkers fall from the parade of horse chestnut trees near the playground.

Green and Luscious. It was so refreshing to see a park in the middle of the city that is green. here in California it is so dry. The ducks, squirrels, and other animals running about were so interesting. There is also interesting tours that start here and allow you to see the city. Even though it is the center of the city near Buckingham Palace it is very peaceful and relaxing.

Good park, but not London's best. Regent's Park is one of London's many great parks and it is certainly very scenic and pleasant to visit and get away from the hustle and bustle of the city.The Inner Circle and the lake are amongst the picturesque highlights, and of course there is London Zoo here as well, though we think the many playing fields and the Hub detract somewhat from the simple beauty of the park.Definitely a good place to visit whatever the season.

Wandering happiness. We often stay at the Melia White House Hotel which is two blocks from the park and I love just wandering around. I, after three years of staying locally, have yet to get to the zoo but I have walked by it a dozen times. Lots of roads, paths, diversions to keep a girl happy and walking. Local neighborhoods are filled with interesting shops and more diversions. I love the window boxes on display around the park. This to me, is my Central Park in London. Next time, I think I will ride a bike.

Good park. I have been there for long years ago and was happy with the huge rose-garden in the park with full of different types of beautiful roses, smell was nice around. However that park is too huge for my taste. And we walked through to the Zoo and that part of the park was not that nice, rather weedy and looked like a meadow.

Lovely place for a walk and families. The ducks in the pond love to be fed left over bread, so let the children delight themselves. Nearby the pond is a dockside cafe for coffee and food with outdoor seating and beautiful view. This is definitely one of London's loveliest parks and a breath of fresh air after all the city trekking and tube riding. I heard from a local that the zoo is not worth the price of admission as most of the larger animals have been relocated. I entered by the mosque after exiting the tube at St. John's Wood and walking down Wellington Road.

Great place for stroll jog or cycle ride. Beautiful park, tons of mature trees, open space, nature reserve, plonk bang in central london. Great idea to build a city round parks such as this one. The royal parks make london great!

Beautiful park in central London. Like a breath of fresh air in central London? This park is beautiful, and well looked after, from the flower beds to the avenues. There is also a boating lake with lots of birds to feed. The grey herons and the geese are quite used to people, so you can see them up close. London Zoo is in a corner of the park and the Regent Canal runs through the Zoo. A really nice walk

one of London's loveliest parks. This is one of London's loveliest parks, and not over-run with tourists, even though to one side you can find the london Zoo, the other the grand Mosque. Really nice to just wander in , preferably on a sunny day. You will greatly enjoy its tranquil atmosphere.
dont miss!!. No trip to London would be complete without a trip to Regents Park. Boating on the lake, the zoo, and in the summer,an open air theatre. What more could you from a London park!!!
Great park. I love regents park. Its smaker than Hyde park But got less people in it. You have some nice little cafes and resturants and a great atmosphear

Regents Park. All of the parks in London are great. We visited and walked through many and just enjoyed the outdoors and the flowers and greenery. People just sitting in the grass enjoying snacks and kids playing. Very enjoyable.
Fab park with so much wildlife. There is a lot of space, it's clean in most places and full of wildlife, including herons! We saw 5 at the same time by a lake.

A peaceful park. Regent's Park may not be the biggest park in London but it's a very nice location to relax and have a walk, jog and even to have a picnic. After a busy day in London, just take away your food, rest and enjoy the beautiful afternoon.

good. i (12) has fun there. it was crowded but fine. there is a sand pit (huge) and lots of play areas for all ages. there is boat riding ( height restriction, something like 1m 40) and lots of open greenland- good for playing football.
Lovely play area. Fabulous park, really well kept and a fabulous play are for the children. We will definitely visit again and take a picnic :)
Lovely formal park. A beautiful London Park! There is London Zoo there too. It has a feeling of space and light even when it rains!
Worth a visit. very clean public free toilets - lovely planting, waterfalls etc, a very pleasant place to walk round

Lush Greenaries.. It was my first photo shoot of the day in London and I was so amazed by this Park. It was huge and lots of trees and seats available to stroll and relax. At the ends you will find small cafes. Its a busy park indeed with all walks of life.
Lovely park. Lovely large open space and the gorgeous weather helped. We enjoyed sitting and watching the wildlife.

Welcome!. I couldn't think of a better place to spend most of my time. Regent's Park is one of the most stunning parks in all of London. Whether it is in the autumn or the summer is always filled with people. One can never get bored because there is so much to do and see. I often go there with friends on a stroll or to write. So go on get there and let your adventure run wild!
Lovely park. This was a lovely park and eating place inside the park. Very open and beautiful. Had a lovely afternoon there.

Beautiful place. Like many other parks in London, it is really beautiful and well maintained. We visited it during the week and we got surprised how many londoners were there practicing sports.
