There is one big restaurant near the southern entrance. I know that there are many tennis courts, but I couldn't see them. You can enjoy the park before or after visiting London Zoo, which is inside the park, but the entrance is at the northern border.

Roses Roses Roses. I love this Park it feels tranquil and relaxing , I love visiting when all the Roses are in bloom.. whoever takes care of the landscaping and the gardening shows an absolute love . The display of Roses are just amazing , colours are so striking . This is a place to come and reflect. Enjoy!!

Really Made Our Day..... A lovely park in a quiet serene area with beautiful landscape really made our day as it was the Birthday of my son.Beautiful flower beds,array of trees along with misty fresh breeze freshened us up.Free entry here and is adjacent to zoo.Canal for boating at Camden Lock is also near by.
The park experience.. Amazing park, dogs friendly, runner's friendly, kid's friendly.Big enough to get a bit lost. Romantic.Also hidden gems to be found.
Walk from the tube to the zoo. we had a fantastic walk in his beautiful park. We decided to walk from the tube to the zoo and it was a great choice.

Love this park. We like so much to wake up and have a run at Regent's that we have stayed near this park everytime we come to London. In such a big and busy city, when in Regent's you can feel relaxed and start your day both with some exercise within a calm surrounding.

Beautiful Park. Big green fields with lots of sporting activities for crickets, football, baseball and plenty of nice footpath to walk doggies.They have water fountains and nice cafe to chill out for a bite and lovely trees on edge of park.

London the way it was. Is this a must visit...probably not, however its a real looking glass into the way London may have looked 100 years ago. The architecture of the houses around the park is very English and the park itself extremely well kept. Good for an afternoon stroll on a nice sunny day.
Quieter than the others, sometimes.. Beautiful flower beds. Close to the zoo. Not far from Oxford street. Summer open air theatre, Lovely open space in the city.
Beautiful park. Up there with Hyde Park as one of the best parks in London and probably the world. Really nice to walk about, take pictures, feed the ducks.

Regents Park at Dawn. Beautiful as the sun rises, you can hear the animals wakening up in the zoo, just over the fence.
A mist rises above the grass reaching the heights of the old lamps.
Beautiful place to take photographs.
Liz

the epitome of Georgian landscape architecture. John Nash set a high standard for urban parkscapes with this project, which leveraged private development to create an upscale expansion to London at the beginning of the 19th century. Regent's Park become the model which was emulated by urban parks in Paris, New York, and modern cities thereafter.

Truly gorgeous park. This is a beautiful park, which has some magnificent, serene corners as well as wide, open spaces. The cultivated bits are outstanding as only Her Majesty could support. The rose garden is probably the crown jewels of the park, and of course it is surrounded by some of the most beautiful architecture in the world.....

Absolutely fabulous park. This is one of my favourite parks of all time. First of all its huge, there's plenty of green space and private areas. Secondly it has a lovely children's park there which my daughter adores. There's plenty to see there; it's right next to london zoo, there is a nice barge lake where you can go on boat rides into Camden, there are lots and lots of beautiful flower displays, theres a large drinking water fountain and there are toilets and a nice little cafe. In the summer this park is simply picturesque. It's a nice safe park too with friendly people. I've been going here for years and will certainly continue to do so.

Beautiful park and a welcome escape from London's noise. We love Regent's Park and enjoyed walking around in December. It's one of the few places in London where kids can run around (but not climb the trees! One of my boys got yelled at like a terrorist by a gardener who saw him climb up on a branch).Amazing ducks, swans, geese.

Serene and beautiful. A really lovely park where you could quite easily pass hours away just in your thoughts.The location is central and the main roads are only a few minutes away. This is a real oasis tucked away.The park itself is clean and feels safe and would be comfortable bringing my family here without fear of idiots spoiling the day.

A gem. We love this park, our favourite in London. So much space, a real oasis in the city, even when its busy there is still room to relax and chill out. The kids love London Zoo and the space, beautiful flowers and spotless.

Winter Wonderland!. We were fortunate to be in London for Christmas so a visit to the Winter Wonderland was high on our list of things to do. It didn't disappoint. What a magical night we had! Crowds not too bad, plenty of options for food and drink. Rides reasonably priced. Some attractions like the ice sculpture exhibition were sold out so would definitely advise booking ahead if you can.For Southern Hemisphere travelers like us it was a truly wonderful experience.

Picnic with a view!. We love Regent's Park and more especially, Primrose Hill!
This is the best best picnic spot! Views of London on a clear day are amazing! Little Deli nearby has all the picnic stuff you will need!

Strange noises. Located next to the London Zoo it is a peaceful walk. If you sit and listen you can not only hearths birds but some other animals living in the zoo next door. During the winter the naked trees are inviting during the day and can be Erie after dusk.
Take a picnic and kick off your shoes. A short walk from the bustle of Oxford Street and Madam Tussauds. Lots of quiet spots, even in high Summer and a great place for a family picnic.

my favourite park. Regent's Park is very beautiful and what is important, not too busy. The garden and flowers are amazing and you can just sit on the grass and relax, either alone or with your friends/family. It's also very good for walks. I loved every second I spent there :)
lovely in winter. See the park at any season but in winter there's a quiet majesty there. Serene and calm, birds and ponds, a wonderful place to stroll after work or touring.

An excelent park. There are so many things to see in this park . The rose garden the lake the birds and the great atmosphere in central London where you find al lot of locals
You can even watch some football games and other sports

One the capital's finest parks. I've visited The Regent's Park innumerable times for almost as many years!I've walked its miles of paths, rowed on its lake, lunched on a bench watching the world go by, enjoyed the roses in Queen Mary's Gardens in the Inner Circle and admired Nash's famous crescent of terraced houses nearby. I've visited London Zoo, also within its boundaries too, of course.I've never visited the London Central Mosque by one of its entrances, although I've passed it many a time, nor have I attended a performance at the Open Air Theatre - omissions which I'll try to rectify soon!
A lovely place for a picnic. If you just want a stroll or a picnic then it is a super place to come. Of course if you want to visit the Zoo then it is on your doorstep.
Regents park. Breath taking greenary all roundHad a lovely stroll with my other half which was what we neededOthers seemed to enjoy the surrounding just as much as us
Beautiful. The walking path is beautiful. It is well maintained. I would recommend they enforce the No Dog policy strictly. Though they have signs everywhere but no one seems to follow them

Clean and Huge. Nice and huge park, very clean, leads from Regents Park station to London Zoo and primrose hill on the other side, loads of toilets (albeit very dirty), shops, cafes and activity areas

SQUIRRELS. Squirrels are everywhere in London, this is no surprise, although, in this park, they seem to be VERY friendly !! I did not even have any food with me, but as I was taking a nap on the lawn, a few of them approached me silently and stared at me for a while. I managed to pet 2 of them. As I left, one of them followed me until my path crossed a dog, the squirrel then ran away.
Beautiful. I will simply say this, The Regent's Park is wonderful. Thank you to all the people who work so hard to keep it that way.
A Haven. This place is one of my favourite corners of London. Great for an escape from the madness of Camden Market. Fantastic for picnics or simply for space to think. near London Zoo too.

Motor vehicles and overzealous Policemen.. I do like this park and use it quite a lot (3 - 4 times a week) for walks and some quiet time.Every time I come here though I get moved off the paths by a vehicle of some sort though. There seem to be a lot of people with legitimate reasons for driving through, but it is a pain at times.BEWARE: You can only do sports in the booked areas. It is also illigal to exercise in certain areas of the Park. I came here once with a friend of mine who was recovering from chemotherapy and thought we would do a little exercise to get him back on his feet. We had a verbal warning from a Policeman for doing pushups on a park bench without a letter of consent from the Home Secretary to exercise in the park. I have also seen people moved off of the football pitches only to leave them empty as they presumably didn't book them.

Beautiful park land. What a lovely way to spend a morning . Lovely walk hard to believe it's in London . Away from the hustle and bustle of the high street thoroughly enjoyed our walk here. Not far from Baker Street. Ideal if you want to see Madame tussauds

One of London's finest. Coming down from the North, we walked through this magnificent park on our way towards the river. This park must look incredible in the spring and summer - I hear their rose gardens are beautiful. But, even in winter, this park is so beautiful. Wide lanes, sculptures, playing fields and smaller gardens with water features - this park has it all. Its also great for people watching!A real London gem.
Beautiful outdoor space. Within walking distance of our hotel, there are flower beds, fountains and lots of space to walk your dog on or off leash. A real joy in the center of the city.
Beautiful place . It was an unexpected visit and we surely loved this park there was a cafe in the meddle of this park they serve an amazing omelet ;)
Best park in London. This is one of the best parks in London. The view is so breathtaking and relaxing. Nice place to spend time with family.

One of the greatest parks in the world. A summer in London (when its not raining) requires a stroll through what I consider to be one of the greatest parks in the world. The park management does a fantastic job with maintenance and planting

One of London's best parks.. Located in a very good neighborhood , Regent's park is one of London's best parks and one of my favorite ones, as well.The park never feels too crowded and its endless lawns give it a tranquil feel.There's a beautiful lake (or rather - a big pond) in the park, and numerous willow trees by the water.All in all, it's an almost magical place.

beautiful landscape. Regent's park is a beautiful park tranquil where you can have a peaceful walk in a wonderful surrounding and a beautiful landscape, artificial lakes and a lots of roses..i loved it

Rose garden defo the best part. Lovely tranquil place - although a tad huge (I got lost a bit, stupid, stupid me). Artificial (?) lakes and smallish picturesque bridges over them made beautiful sights. Rose garden in August was really impressive.

Lose Yourself for a Day!. How lucky we were to have a Royal Family, because their legacy, their old hunting grounds, ceded to the public - ended up as vast green spaces across London which we call the Royal Parks. The best in my opinion is Regents Park. Look at the following list - which other park in the world has:i) A zoologial reserach centre and zoo with 760 different species including tigers, lions, gorillas and penguins (entry fee)ii) a canal - connecting the Thames river with the Grand Union Canaliii) Walking distance to nearly 80 West End theatresiv) Its own outdoor theatre (entry fee) - that puts on 4 or 5 plays in the clement weather monthsv) A sister green space attached Primrose Hill, the top of which you have one of the best views of the London skylinevi) Over 400 acres of trees, some very tall, some very rarevii) The arguably the finest public rose gardens, in southern EnglandAs well as statues, ponds, boating lakes, bandstand, cafes, restaurants, inner and outer access roads with parking, and surrounded by beautiful Nash terraces - the finest in EnglandYou can lose yourself for a day in this fabulous attraction. Well worth a visit in any of the four seasons

Stunning Regent's Park. I love London and Regent's Park is one of my favourites. The ponds, Queen Mary's gorgeous rose garden (feel free to lose yourself in the various heady, rose fragrances!), the avenue of fountains and the random chancing of someone from a country far away from yours but having a brief chat about the awesomeness of the place and feeling truly blessed to be experiencing it (it happened to me!). I love it and I hope you enjoy it too!

London's most beautiful park. Regent Park is beautiful. It is beauty untouched. With tall trees and greenery all around, it's a beautiful place to be at. London is known for it's parks and heath. Regent Park is one of the many parks that stands out.

One of the most underrated parks in Central London!. As I'm quite a big fan of London Parks in general. This one I feel is often very underrated by comparison with some of the other ones in Central London.This is probably due to the fact that it's slightly more out of the way being that it seems to link the central part of London with the north west part of London.Although it is situated next to some of the most interesting parts of the city centre. With the world famous Madam Tussauds & Sherlock Holmes Museum just nearby. As well as the delightful London Zoo (which is also worth a visit) just at the top corner.Of course it doesn't seem to be quite as big as Hyde Park, but never the less you'll certainly enjoy spending some of your vacation time enjoy the lush and colourful gardens here. With people playing sports in the summer months, the various species of wildlife running around and the pretty colourful but crisper scenes of the autumn leaves falling. Giving rise to some very spectacular views. With most of the time feeling certainly less crowded that the other parks.Quite frankly just like Hyde Park. It's pretty much a much a Central London Park for just about all seasons. So make sure you pay this one a visit and I certainly don't think you'll be dissapointed.

Getting ideas from the flower beds. As an avid gardener, I always come here and take pictures of the flower beds. I love to take photos and enjoy so much studying the experienced work the designers put in here.Aside that the whole place is marvelous.

Another London Park Collection. We visited Regents along with other parks such as Hyde, St James and Kensington. The park is northeast of our hotel. By tasking a short-cut through the park on our way to the British Library, we were able to enjoy what it has to offer. There are 2 nice little buildings in the part - Winfield Hall and St John's Hall - but were closed during our visit. Like the other parks it has much wildlife, birds, flora and fauna to offer. Unfortunately during winter time, most parks look a little bland. To park tourists, go for this !

A Classic London Park. We had a stroll through Regents Park on the way to the Zoo in the early morning. It was November and the park was full of colourful Autumn leaves. It was lovely to see people playing sport or walking their dogs. The birds, gardens and the ponds were spectacular. A very pleasant place to be.

The most lovely park. When in London, my wife and I used to go to this stunning park every Sunday. There's just so much to do and see walking around the lack and feeding the friendly ducks that come to your feet to smelling the beautiful flowers of the the very central gardens.

Fabulous!. Everything you expect a London Park to be. Gorgeous trees, plants, flowers, wildlife, water features. After we walked to the top of Primrose Hill to see the London skyline and then walked over to Abbey Road. A must do!!!!!!!!!!!!
Great park.. Sunny day? Grab your camera and take a trip to Regents park. A lo of animals, lot of stuff to see and its so romantic. Great place to run to.

Stunning. My boyfriend and I shared our first date here, a year ago. Sipping ice tea in the glorious sunshine, looking over glorious views and stunning scenery. We went back here for our anniversary, and had a lovely picnic. Quite possibly the best park in London, and equally has a lot of special memories attached!

One of the best. This one is one of my favourite park in London, very clean, not a lot of people/tourists, there is squirrels who like taking pics !
L'un de mes parcs préférés à Londres, très propre, pas trop de monde et avec des écureuils qui aiment les photos !
Nice place. A very nice place to walk through, beautiful scenery and a lovely lake with ducks etc. I loved how close you could get to the squirrels!

Amazing view of over London. We were surprised that this park is not on the tourist's route. Perhaps because it's a little further out London than most of the usual spots. The park is not as well maintained as Hyde, Kensington, Green or James's Parks. However there was a large number of locals enjoying the sunshine. The view towards the city centre is amazing. London is a beautiful city and Regent Park allows visits to see a large part of it.

Something for everyone. This large park to the north of central London is something of a mixed bag. I have often come here with friends to go to the open air theatre, but this time I decided to explore it a little more. The south of the park (which you go through on the way to the theatre) has a boating lake and is good for a walk or a picnic in warmer weather. Further to the east in the south of the park the English and Avenue Gardens make a very pleasant walk. But as of today my favourite part is in the south east corner of Queen Mary's Gardens within the Inner Circle. Here you will find a small lake and garden with water features, where the noise of London is drowned out by the sound of water. The North of the park is more open, like a common, and contains sports pitches and long paths which are good for walking dogs. I enjoyed it, but if you are visiting London you may want to spend your time elsewhere, though it does make a pleasant walk if you are on your way to London Zoo or Primrose Hill.

Big and a beauty. Regent's Park is a downscale of Central Park, but totally worth a long afternoon walk in. It has multiple entrances, but my favorite is the hub in the middle area. It is surrounded by big open areas where kids play football on the weekends. Bring some stale bread to feed the ducks at the ponds!

Terrific walk down from Primrose hill. This is a relatively flat park with nice ponds and the beautiful Queen Anne's gardens. You may enter at the London Zoo at the northern end and walk south to Anne's gardens and Baker Street or Marylebone Street exits; there are tube stops at Baker Street to the south east and the Regent's Park stop to the Park's south west.

Beautiful park with a lot to offer. I am a study abroad student at Regents University which is located within Regents Park. The park has so much to offer within it and in the area around it. The park has cafes, tennis courts, soccer fields, paddle boats, gardens of flowers, bridges over the water. It is a great area to check out for an afternoon. Within a mile of the park is Primrose Hill which gives you an amazing view of the city, Baker Street with places to eating, Oxford Street for shopping, and much much more.

Green. We only went through the South edge of the park during our visit. We crossed a little footbridge to get across a boating lake where at least one couple was paddling along. There were quite a few dog walkers and joggers out and about as well but the park wasn’t too busy that early in the day. Grey herons were relaxing along the water and on the left side we saw Regent’s University of London, a small private school right inside the park.A group of schoolchildren were doing track and field stuff for gym class and workers were working in Marylebone Green constructing what looked like a temporary concert venue. I wonder what they were planning for that structure? We saw some fountains before leaving the area. It was a nice little place to take a calm, relaxing walk.

Splendid!. Regent's Park is in North West London, just north of Marylebone/ Baker Street. A large green area with a beautiful lake, this park is lovely for walks and picnics. There are lots of ducks here. The greenery is super beautiful and for the more active ones, this is an excellent place to go running. A lovely lovely park right in the city. Most highly recommended!

beatiful beatiful and beatiful. I just been there 9 days ago. It was really nice and smell was PEACE :). I saw squirrel and more than one! It means this park really safeful, peaceful and excellent. I saw people who were walking and were running. I felt autumn on my heart and skin..There were also zoo but I have no time so next time I wish to visit too.

Glorious London 01. Yes!Give it up for Regents Park running across Great Portland Street and Baker Street.This is London, bustling, cosmopolitan, chic and with lots of greenery and Park to chill.Another weekend in London/chilling on Sunday at Regents Park with my buddies and we had an excellent time

Remarkable. I have been coming to regents park since I was a toddler , I have so many memories here , from building a camp site with my friends 30 plus years ago ,to boating in the lakes.. Playing football.. Fishing in the regents canal .. This is a beautiful park you must come with the kids.. Queen marts garden in the inner circle is amazing .. During the cold times if you go up on the hill with a few nuts and bread .. You can feed the blue tits and robins . They take food from your hands ..I'm bringing my kids to the park like I used to come and they just luv it.. I could go on and on.. But there's nothing like experiencing it for yourself.. If you like a bit of peace and quiet. Go to the little lake by the tennis courts .. Harmony .

One of the best free outdoor attractions in London. This is not the best known or most accessible of London Parks but I have been coming here for 40 years and always love coming even in the cooler weather. The best time of year is Spring into early Summer although there is also plenty to see even now.Firstly allow at least an hour to walk around although you can easily spend half a day here without going to the Zoo or open air theatre or playing tennis or hiring a row boat...Secondly print a PDF map off if you want to make the most of your time here.Thirdly best to come on a nice or at least dry day - if it is raining you can get very wet here as it is a very exposed site.If you want a nice walk here start at the entrance North of Baker Street Station. Walk around the boating lake - there are some beautiful flower borders near the wooden bridge at the Southern end. In the Summer on a Sunday there may be a band playing on the Victorian Bandstand. From the West side of the lake you can view 'The Holme' which must be one of the most magnificent locations for any private dwelling in Central London.Do not miss the smaller lake and rose gardens to the South as well as the Avenue Gardens near the South East corner of the park (they have only been planted some 20 years but look much more established). During the Summer the most spectacular gaden is the small round garden right at the centre of Queen Mary's Garden - this is surrounded on 3 'sides' by hedging and is sealed off by chains but a few inconsiderate people insist on climbing onto the pristine grass for a photo - please do not!Do not miss the fountain or the borders to the North and West of the toilets nearby and opposite the open air theatre.Another place not to miss is the 'Secret Garden' which is properly called St John's Lodge Garden - located on the Inner Circle just North of the junction with Chester road. It is beauftiful and secluded and not visited by many people.If you have more time walk around the Outer Circle to see the unrivalled Regency houses, especially at the Southern end (both East and West). Also look out for the mosque with the gold dome further West and North.Don't bother walking across the sports fields unless you are heading to Camden or the Zoo (or wish to play football or baseball) as there is not much to see. If you do need to walk across the park keep to either the East or West edge as it is more interesting.There are lots of toilets in the park as well as cafes and kiosks and plenty of benches. Bringing your own food to have a picnic is a great idea. If you wish to buy food the cafe in centre of the park (Benugo - The Garden Cafe) is pretty good but expensive. For those die-hard visitors that want to see a bit more head North towards the Zoo and get down onto the Regents Canal. Walking West towards little Venice is very interesting for the superb mansions overlooking the canal with their terraced gardens including the American Ambassadors residence on the North side - look out for the serious railings, the canal boats and the short canal tunnel which you can walk around easily. If you walk East you will soon get to Camden Lock market via a very interesting walk showing how London can change its character within a few hundred metres.Consider walking a little further North from the Zoo area to Primrose Hill and St John's Wood. Great views, lots of shops a restaurants and beautiful houses and people - and not may tourists.Lots of wildlife here - look out for Herons who live on the islands in the boating lake on massive nests - Herons are huge, grey and tame with wings, squirrels - small grey and tame (no wings but sharp teeth) and tame robins and tits. The really tame birds are located within Queen Mary's Gardens and with patience will come to your hand for nuts. The squirrels will climb up your clothing to take nuts from your hands but they can bite so be careful and probably not a good idea for small children who may panic and get bitten. If you are really keen to do this then my tip is to buy peanuts still in their shells - keep your fingers at one end and the squirrel at the other end - this is relatively safe and I have never been bitten. Lots of geese and swans as well.

Amazing day out. A beautiful sunny day, and everything shines brighter. The beautiful green grass, trees, water in the fountains and the unique clusters of roses. Wgat a delightful sight!With so many things to see, a day is simple not long enough to see everything. There is the free summer concerts, the adult boats and the children’s boats, the theatre, cafes, restaurants and the zoo.Take a nice picnic and a jacket as there are huge open areas yo enjoy and it vould suddenly feel cold (welcome to England). A camera is a must to capture all the beautifully kept and planned gardens.If you are in London, take the time to enjoy this huge park in the centre of town.

Beautiful. One of the few things in London that are free, we strolled through the park early on a Sunday morning and were amazed at how many people were there, joggers, people walking dogs others sitting down on benches and reading.The park has several eateries and also incorporates London Zoo and a boating lake, well worth a visit.

Absolutely Gorgeous!. Probably one of the most beautiful parks I have ever seen. It is a great place to go for an afternoon stroll or find a cozy area to enjoy a book. A person can forget that they are in one of the largest cities in the world when in Regents park. I recommend bringing some bread and feeding the ducks there. We had a blast!
Yes it's a park c. Nice gettaway in the middle of London. Just walk along the lakes or through the park it self relaxing park nice to do even better with a partner,

Park!. This is also one of the places you must go to whenever you're in London.Regent's Park is lovely to go for a walk, to relax and of course to enjoy the view over London. If you are into running, you can also get your work out in there :)
nice backyard. bring camera and snacks jacket open mind smiles and immerse yourself in it. bring a friend that you want to hold hands with.

It's a park? Yes and go see it!. So you've travelled all the way to London to see the lights, the glamour, and most likely other city centric cliches. However, I would recommend making a stop at Regent's Park. Long story short, this place is beautiful and deserves to be put on your list of sites. Enjoy your time at this beautiful park.

Exciting park that offers many different experiences and environments!. Despite many visits to London over the years, it was the first time we visited the exciting Regent Park, just north of London's very center! This park is full of different kinds of activities, gardens and cafés ... Especially beautiful is the part with all the different cultures of the roses! The difference from Hyde Park, is that this park is more lively and active and more 'planned' - Hyde Park is more of an 'one big lawn with isolated trees'. Both are equally good but in different ways!
Take a camera :). Beautiful park no matter what time of year you visit.Take a camera and a packet of bread for the ducks :) x
Favorite park in central London. The Regent's Park is my favorite park in central London. 15 minutes walking from the Oxford Street it has a beautiful garden where you can take some nice pictures.

Breathtaking. Regent Park is breathtaking with manicured gardens. The rose garden is my favourite! It is the perfect oasis to escape the hustle and bustle of the city and just enjoy the tranquility and beauty of this park. Take a romantic stroll through the gardens and have a romantic picnic afterwards.Note that the London Zoo is situated on the North side of Regent Park.Not to be missed!

Beautiful park. This huge park can be found smack bang in the middle of London. It seems to go on forever. Lovely for a stroll.Some of the garden areas are planted with annuals and perennials making for a very colourful display. Well worth a look. And there are some fantastic large urns that look spectacular when their plants are in full bloom.There are also large grassed areas and people make great use of them for picnics. For those not as adventurous, there are quite a few benches available as well.In other areas of the garden are water features, lakes, beautiful rose garden, lost of different areas in fact. And you might see one of the many grey squirrels that seem to abound.Lots of people visit but because of the size it never seems too busy.

Great escape in the city. Even for a short walk, this is one of great parks in London. It's only a stone-away from busy Baker Street.
One can find diversity of the city on weekend.
Nice stroll in the weekend. Enjoy a nice stroll in this scenic London park. Especially when walking from the Camden Locks to the fancy Marlylebone, Regent's Park offers a beautiful route.
Beautiful garden park in london. This is a huge amazing park in london a bit outside of of city center so not as crowded and beautiful flower gardens pond and trees.

Best park!. Our hotel was very close to the park so we went there almost every day. I think it is the most beautiful park in London, better than Hyde Park in my opinion!I especially liked the rose garden!

Beautiful park worthy of the Regents!. We strolled through this park (which adjoins the London Zoo) on our way to the "tube" station. It was absolutely wonderful. There were beautiful garden displays along the route and other gardens (the Queens Garden) which we didn't have time to see but, according to locals, is extremely beautiful.

Everything a park should be!. We were staying in London for several days, near Marylebone station and Regents Park was a short walk away, so one sunny September Sunday we decided to visit Camden Market via Regents Park. It is huge, but has everything you want in a park. Tranquil, lovely well maintained grounds, a boating lake, sports area, cafe etc. My husband and I took a rowing boat around the lake - lovely. If we hadn't been on route to Cambden I would have happily spent a lazy afternoon at the boating lake cafe or enjoyed a picnic at one of the many pretty gardens.

Lovely calm place. Beautiful gardens spread out with many seating areas & lakes lovely rose gardens & many squirrels lovely quiet place to relax in all of the rushing around for a while.Nice cafe for drinks etc.
Another stunning park in London. Real family park loads to do here and the locals use this daily, london zoo is at one end of the park and there are areas for young kids as well as tennis courts.
Enjoy the silence!. The colours of Regent's Park are a refreshment for your eyes and mind! Walk and breathe the fresh air, rest on a bench and later have a hot cappuccino... You'll be renewed!
Perfect Garden!. Probably the best park in London! Very well kept. Lovely, peaceful place to spent some time and relax.

Just lovely. A very beautiful park and the Queen Mary's Rose Gardens in the Inner Circle are simply amazing. We couldn't spend much time in it, but enjoyed it immensely. I would definitely like to visit it again next time we are in London.
Beautifull walk. I walk via this park everyday to work and it is such a pleasure. Its a beautifull safe park with lovely walks,it is unspoilt and can be breath taking any time of the year

Great Royal London Park. A Great Royal Park in the centre of London that us great and well kept - definitely a favourite of ours to walk , relax and watch London Life or just travel through whilst visiting for a few days or just the day being out of towners. - recommended
Enjoy
Deserves More Than a Drive By. Sadly, we only had time to drive through the park. It is a beautiful park, and we'll find several hours to spend here the next time we're in London.

an island of calm. a very peaceful island of calm in the middle of the teeming metropolis that is london.
there are public tennis courts,beautiful trees and gardens and love little cafes. The hwole park is surrounded by the most wonderful victorian and edwardian houses. Perfect for picnics, romantic strolls or gneral fun with the family

The Rose Garden is wonderful. I love this park and especially the rose garden. It is so beautiful and peaceful, that it is hard to believe it is in the middle of a city. A great place to take a break in the middle of your tour of the city. The park is very big, so if you are only interested in the rose garden - look at the map to see to which part of the park you should go.

Great for children and adults alike!. One of the things we love most about London are its parks..and Regents Park is way up on top of that list! Great play areas, lovely lake, the rose gardens, awesome cafe in the centre of the park. It is so big that you can do several visits and still experience something new depending where you go. We have been going since the children were small and now they are 6 and 9 and they still enjoy playing football, and having picnics with friends and family.

Heart of the city. Regent Park is easily the best park of the city and one that I love the most. Its a fun place to be in - where you can either just laze around on a sunny day picnicking with friends or just go around for a run - the latter is what I love more - as the number of health freaks out there never fail to inspire and push me to strive harder.The park is very easily accessible through the London underground - there is Warren Street on the Victoria and Northern line or even closer is the Great Portland Street on the Hammersmith & City line, or otherwise you can also use the bus services.The park itself is very well maintained, lush greenery, spotlessly clean benches and jogging tracks - what else can one ask for and all of this just for free :-)Its a great escape from the chaotic and rushed life of the cosmopolitan city of London - once inside the park you are transported to a different rather serene world.

The best park in London. I visited this park over a weekend in Autumn and found it to be the prettiest park in central London. The south side of the park is enclosed by huge mansion blocks which enclose the park giving it regal feel. As you head North you will find the tennis courts and football parks. Further north you will find the rose gardens and Japanese waterways. I recommend heading north first time and experiencing the beauty. I will take maybe three or four visits before you get to see the entire park.

The green heart of London. Hyde Park might be bigger, but I always preferred Regent's Park. In fact, Regent's Park is one of my favourite spots in London - you can enjoy an atmosphere, worlds apart from the hustle and bustle of the big city.I spent hours after hours in summer in this welcoming patch of greenery, sitting under the massive beech trees watching every breed of dog going wild over a ball or a squirrel; or playing football; or just getting lost within the enormity of the park. But even in winter, when the sky was steely and grey and the trees were stripped and bare, the park had something to offer - from Her Majesty's collection of birds around the frozen ponds, to the white fields strewn with sleet.And if that isn't enough, the Zoo and Lord's Cricket ground are located within the perimeter of the park, so a dull day here is hard to come by!

Great greenspace. The gardens, green space and water make for a great day out, rivalling and perhaps surpassing Hyde Park (but it's a tough call). Definitely worth a trip to get away from the city sights and congestion for awhile!

even enough space to play with a frisbee. came here for a picnic with friends there are plenty of benches and many pretty floral gardens to walk through with interesting statues , ponds and fountainsthe secret garden was the quietest one ,maybe because it is yet to be found,found an area surrounded by high hedges, where people were out walking their dogs. this was the ideal spot to practise throwing a frisbee.............even if I did accidentally hit a few canines

J'accuse!. I was accused of stealing squirrels, but they were thrashing about my bag without my knowledge, probably due to my half eaten scotch egg. Apart from the accusations, I had a nice time walking the paths picking the flowers.
Beautiful Park. If you are looking for a beautiful place for a walk head here. there's so much to see as you walk through the park. There's even a hidden meditation garden.

London in a nutshell. Regents park is the best parts of London in a nutshell to me. It's beautiful, calming and although it gets busy in the summer, it has such a nice relaxing and friendly atmosphere. There are a few private spots good for picnics and there is also a lovely little café that sells ginger beer floats - yum!
Lovely walk. Walked back from zoo to underground through this beautiful park. The flowers were so lovely and you would be hard pressed to know you were in Central London. A little piece of paradise.
Parklands worth a visit. This is a beautiful parkland - we didn't get to see all of it on our stay, but it was just gorgeous to walk through on the way to the Zoo and to Camden markets from our hotel
lovely views. Nice, spacious, loads of ducks and geese, a cafe available, seems clean enough, nice deco, could do with more benches.
Nice park but nothing special. Lot of grass some trees etc, just ordinary park, unless you going there for some special event then it might be quite exciting.

Stunning. What a stunning array of rose gardens, all currently flowering and the smells are fantastic, flower lined walkways, hidden gardens to relax on the chairs in amongst the greenery, marvellous big trees.People walking and running around the lake with all the bird life and beautiful white swans. SeverL cafes within the park are great for coffee,cakes and small meals, plus you have the added chance to visit the London zoo (great) Regent park is such a credit to the Royal Parks and gardens and their staff, especially to be in the heart of a vibrant city. Well done.
Great park for wildlife. A highlight of our stay.We hand fed ducks,geese and squirrels.So nice to see green areas in London.park wellcared for .Take nuts for the squirrels.

If you have to see one park in London, see this one. Regent's Park has an incredible English garden and Queen Mary's Rose Gardens. It was my favorite of all the London parks I visited. I combined my visit to this park with a visit to Abbey Road. It was a short pleasant walk from Abbey Road to Regent's Park.

Lovely walk through the park to the zoo. We visited here on the way to ZSL London Zoo. I didn't remember the park being so pretty, loads of shrubs and ornamental gardens. Tidy and well kept with lots of places to sit and spend some time. The lake with all the geese, ducks and swans was a bit of a disappointment as it looked like it had quite a lot of algae but overall keep on the other side of the park and you won't be disappointed.
Plenty to see and do. Much enjoy just strolling around the park, or indeed driving around the classy Nash built Outer Circle.

One of the best parks in London. A very large park which offers something for everyone. London Zoo is also located in the park as is Regent's Canal. The park has Los of interesting parts to it including formal gardens, ponds and lakes, playgrounds and cafés/restaurants. A great place for a picnic.

I had a long walk through the rose garden and other flowery paths.. I love walking in the nature. Regent's Park provides all the varities that one needs. It has wild areas, secluded sections, Seasonal flowers, cafes, lakes, ponds, waterfalls and most beautiful Queen Mary's Garden. One can see pictures of my latest walk in this park on facebook/rkmathur

Porgy and Bess opera in the park.. A birthday treat from my son. We had a meal before the performance and were praying for a dry evening as it had rained hard in the afternoon.Luckily it was dry although progressively cooler as the night wore on.The theatre was packed with people suitably dressed and with wraps or small blankets.Picnic hampers were in evidence and the place was lit up nicely.We all enjoyed the fabulous performance which was very dramatic and moving.Thank you.

One of London's great parks.. London is unusual in that it's a huge city interspersed with parks (some of which are huge). Regent's park is pretty big, but easy to walk through , and safe (during the day, at least). It has a lake, cafés, and lots of really relaxing space - not necessarily a place to visit for its own sake, but if you're wandering from the underground station (at one end of the park) to the Zoo (at the other), it's a nice way to do it.
As the other parks in the city is very good. As the other parks that are in the city of London is a good place to do a walk, seat and talk with your friends or simply relax..
nice place. have bee here many time and i have enjoyed here , park is big and i always have good time over here .

Not just your average park. Regents park is a real favourite of mine, not just because of the location but with its vast array of things to do. Walking distance to London Zoo, a stone's throw away from camden town which is great for people watching. The park is full of amazing things to do and perfect for families with little children. Its gorgeous in the summer; and although I am a hay fever sufferer who generally shy's away from parks in the summer, I cannot help but go to Regents Park. Nothing an antihistamine or two cannot solve before hand.Perfect picnic location for the family. A must visit.

Regents Park Open Air Theatre. We went to see Porgy and Bess at the open air theatre, fantastic show in a fantastic setting. Would recommend to everyone. I do wish that we had booked dinner 'under the canapy' which looked amazing - but maybe next time
Gorgeous Park. We played at the playground by the boating lake and fed the many ducks. Lots of different kinds of ducks. Bring bread. Had a great time!

Fantastic. Been to this park many times and what's different about this park is it's size wonderful views lovely view of the dome of the central mosque borders London zoo people from all walks and nationalities alike come here great day out for the family no doubt
Love to be here all day . I love to spend my lunch break in the park feeding the birds. A very mind relaxing and peaceful place. I believe we all should keep it tidy and not to litter around.

Disappointed in the roses, flower beds in mid-June. Regent's Park was close to our hotel so it was very convenient for a quick visit to see the rose beds and other plantings on a Sunday morning before taking the Tube to visit tourist sights in London. I had been to this Park many years ago and was absolutely astounded then with the many rose beds, the healthy rose bushes, and the abundance of blooms. I remember even the flower beds were awash with color - gaudy orange, orange-reds, yellows, reds with the silver white of artemisia. This year in mid-June I was really disappointed in the flower display, especially the rose gardens. Have the number of rose beds been reduced? Have different, smaller growing varieties been planted to replace the 4 footer rose bushes? Some of the plants were either newly planted or just not bushy. There was not an overwhelming color explosion here in the rose garden nor in amongst the other beds. The Grand Avenue, with its twin plantings on either side of the sidewalk, was rather boring to walk along....all green with minimal interest in either good plant combinations or flower color. The one area that did look interesting was the walk around the pond area. From this visit, I don't think I will be so eager in the future to put Regent's Park with its Queen Mary Rose Garden on my "Must See" list when in London.

great location. I loved walking here when I visited. It was right across the street from where I was staying, so it was easy to just go and walk there. It's so cool to see everyone relaxing in a park in the middle of the city. It's so relaxing.

Beautiful place. The nicest park we visit in London. Huge, spacious and well maintained. Especially the section of the Queens gardens. We went twice there during our week visit and each time were surprised at how relaxing it is just being there. The park (and the others Royal parks) gives you a the feel of the empire Britain once was

Great Royal London Park. This is one of the Great English Royal London Parks.Central, large, clean and well maintained.Well worth a visit either as a foreign or English tourist or a localSee the joggers passing you by in their spouts of glorious energy it's don't get run over!!Recommended - Enjoy

Had great memory in a beautiful park. After long long time I haven't out with my friends because of busy schedule (work and study).My best friend made a plan to go out first of allshe was using a map of BIG BUSAnd we were traveling by London bus. I was thinking that she using for route but not she was using it for where we have to go in a single day.First we chose to go to the regents park and we captured some beautiful picture/photography .1: There is tennis ground it's better to have your own rackets rather than rent it in the park2: There is beautiful lakes 3: There is beautiful flower gardens 4: There is some nice wooden bridges on the lake5: There is a lot of fountains 6: There is a beautiful water tank in the middle of the roadDrinking water from humans and as well as dogs or pets.7: There is beautiful playground for kids 3 to 5 years kids Slide and mud to play8: There is restaurants and coffee shops as well.9: There is beach chairs so you can set to the sun in winter10: There is fadel boats Which is for two or more then two people which work on your legs.It's a big park you need a full day to enjoy all.

Peacful and quiet. My favourite park in London, far away from the maddening crowds. Surrounded by some beautiful houses, it's a delightful place to walk on a warm summer evening on the way back into central London from the Zoo or Lords. I seen all kinds of sports being played here over the years, and the gardens, Boating lake and bandstand are always well maintained. My only complaint is that there's no tube station close by the North end.
OMG!!!. One of the most beautiful parks I've been in. The roses were incredibly beautiful and so many!! You could get lost in the tranquility of this beautiful serene park!!! Take me back!!!

nice park. Nice park, that's basically all it is, another nice park in the middle of London. Worth going to see? Not if you are a tourist and just want to see sights, but if you want a day to relax and read outside it is ok.
Beautiful!!! A great way to spend a Sunday . Lovely park, probably the most beautiful park in London. Don't miss the Queen Mary Gardens and take a walk outside of the park to see the beautiful houses

Beautiful Garden and Great Running Location. Take a run on the outer loop up Primrose Hill and through the Queen's garden. Excellent views from the hill. Wonderful place for a run, stroll, walk with the dog, or Picnic! There is at least one restaurant and a cafe.

One of the nicest in London. A lovely garden, perfect for strolling and viewing landscaped flower beds, especially roses in spring and summer. The café has a nice selection of meals, including scrummy cakes. Also a WIFI zone

Our Favourite Place For a Play in London. You can't beat Regent's park. It's right in the middle of London, it's huge and beutiful with formal gardens and more wild areas. There are millions of ducks and geese, boating lakes, playgrounds and London Zoo. Perfect! Read more about life in London on our blog, World Travel Family,

Queen's rose garden!. The park itself is vast, you can spend a whole day relaxing at any spot, take a stroll, picnic & enjoy squirrels if they trust you enough to come close. We were fortunate to visit the park in June when roses were in full bloom, and it was a marvelous scene! Thousands of roses from all around the world were showcasing their beauty. Highly recommended at this time of the year!

Something for everybody - a wondrous beauty.. Once you are in it, you quite forget that it is situated bang in the middle of a busy London. Quiet, peaceful, you can be totally immersed in its wondrous beauty.We spent a full day here with kids, picnicking, boating, playing and strolling among the very well laid out avenue garden (in precisely that order).We reached there around 12 noon on a warm, fortunately clouded day and made our way in from the Lords cricket ground side (where the final day of the India-England match was being played). India won it. Hurrah!!Our first stop was the boat jetty. While walking to it, passed a acrobat training display. Situated next to a nice sit out, we first picnicked with some food brought from home and ice creams bought from the cafe. Thereafter took a 1 hour family ride meant for 2 adults and three children. As we were a party of 3 adults and 3 children with one infant (below 2 years), we had to swap places. Surprisingly the infant was also counted as a child. So, at a time, two adults and three children pedaled their boat under the weeping willows, around the island, where we found the nesting fowls and swarms of geese. Two boats tied to a buoy had been given over to the gulls who had made it their floating home. What an interesting sight? The kids quite enjoyed boating around it.Made our way then to the kids playground, which the youngsters enjoyed hugely, rollicking along the wooden platforms, swinging in the hammock, sliding down the twisting slide.Thereafter, strolled our way to the Avenue garden. Extremely well laid out, with all flowers in full bloom, the gardeners had done a good job, in the variety with a well thought out colored scheme.Finally, a tired party made its way home, passing the Harley Street, Madam Tussaud and Sherlock Holmes Baker street (but more of that some other time).All in all, there is something for everybody. Play grounds for kids, adventure sports for teens, boating for all age groups and stroll in the gardens for the elderly.

Beautiful park.. Very beautiful park filled with flower gardens. Many people picnic in the park as it Is very peaceful. There is a open air theatre that we would have loved to see a play there but alas nothing was going on. In my opinion it is much nicer than Hyde Park. So much more relaxing than the rest of busy London in the July.

Chill in the park. This is the place to chill out after a hectic time in London visit early evening for a nice gentle walk through the formal gardens or share a picnic with the squirrels
The people watching is fun Time to relax and while away the time

Best Royal Park in central London. Lovely green areas, nice boating lake, great flowers at the Regents Park tube station (southern) end and less busy than Hyde, Green and St James' parks, what more could you ask for? Oh, the excellent London zoo is located in the park, Primrose Hill with its amazing views over London and the great restaurants and pubs of Camden too.

Beautiful park, fun pedalo-ing. Went here to have a picnic and hire out a pedalo. It wasn't overcrowded like some parks are in London, and was very clean. The pedalos were great fun but very poor customer service! There were queues to hire them out which I do not understand as it doesn't take long to process the transaction, so I'm not sure why the attendant was being so slow. He was obviously a bit flustered as we had to keep repeating what we wanted as he wasn't listening properly. After, we had to queue up to get our £5 deposit back. The attendant actually left the till point and disappeared for a good 5 mins with no explanation whatsoever. Very odd! But the pedalos itself were very enjoyable.

My favourite park in London. Regents Park is pretty. Lots of tree-lined pathways and formal gardens, plenty of places to sit and watch the world go by. We often go there just to feed the squirrels (no squirrels in Oz). Regents isn't as crowded as Hyde park and is a little away from the madness of Oxford street and Mayfair---well worth a visit.
Great place to walk and unwind. Lovely garden and much less crowded than other parks. Flowers were beautiful and the park was very casual and comfortable.

Less crowded than Hyde Park. All-round better experience.. One of my favourite parks in London. Excellent views of the city from atop Primrose Hill. Far less crowded than Hyde Park is. Feels nowhere near as touristy and busy. Spent several hours here just wandering around.

Nice park for a stroll check out the flowers. We came here to enjoy some fresh air and rest a bit from the buzzling of the city. The park is huge but I strongly recommend you stroll around leisurely. It sits close to the Sherlock Holmes house and the Madame Tussaud's museum both of which we didn't go.
Don't Eat. Park restaurant not very good but park was lovely and lots of lounging chairs available.. Walking paths good. Beautiful flowers.

Wonderful . On our way back to kings cross station we decided to pay a visit to the park.The Roses were in full bloom and the variety and fragrance was a Amazing.My wife and I walked round the park and were Astonished to see so many herons all together,we also indulged in the veggie cafe which was very pleasant whilst it decided to poor down with rain,we had a lovely romantic tea before heading home.
Beautiful. This park is truly enormous and beautiful. We walked and walked for hours and felt like we just hot started it was a lot of fun

Beautiful and relaxing. London is very busy place. Give yourself a break and spend time in one of many lovely parks. Sit on a bench or bring a blanket and lie about. Bring snacks and take advantage of the cafes or snack trucks. Bathrooms are nice, too.

Relaxing evening stroll. Regents park was near to our Hotel and just right for an evening stroll.If you want a drink go before 6 as the smaller cafes close then. Ideal for a picnic and proof you don't need to spend a four tune to enjoy London!

Relaxing Sunday!. The last day of our trip was a relaxing one. Regents Park was a great place to stroll and relax! Beautiful lakes and parks provided a scenic stroll. Stopped for ice cream and watched all the Londoners enjoying a beautiful day! Great way to end our wonderful time in London!

Gorgeous Park. Such a stunning park to enjoy for walking, picnic, gardens, flowers and the location is nice too. Didn't go to the zoo as its not my thing, but would recommend this park on a lovely summers day for a picnic, romantic stroll or bit of exercise.
Nice park plenty of space. Typical central ish London park but what makes it different is the zoo where an urban child can see a giraffe and tiger !

Not famous Park. Not famous Park
Regent's Park nice park and clean uncrowded
i used it to go to the Islamic Center or even to London Zoo
i want to go walking there
but every time i enter the park i do not the as my Hyde Park feeling

A miss during the winter, a hit during the summer. What a different the weather makes when it comes to visits to Regent's Park. Not that we have any problem with the winter when you can find more solitude at this Royal Park, but Regent's Park really comes alive and shows its best stuff during the warmer months. During the summer, the lake is full of waterfowl, young chicks and paddle-boaters casually enjoying their time on the water. Another benefit to summer visits is that the Open Air Theatre is in session so you can enjoy outdoor performances in the evening. Further, if you visit during early June, you can see the excellent Queen Mary Rose Garden in full bloom. This is a treat in an of itself and something that we greatly miss when passing through Regent's park during winter visits. Overall, we highly rate Regent's Park during the summer when the Open Air Theatre and Queen Mary Rose Garden able to be seen and enjoyed. This is one of the Royal Parks that is well worth spending time during summer visits to London.

Go here with your girlfriend/ significant other.. Compared to Hyde Park, Regent's has more flowers and is just more festive in general. Remember, Hyde Park is for friends. Regent's is for your girlfriend ;)

Fabulous park that is well worth a visit. We visited Regent's Park for the first time and were very impressed with it. Beautifully maintained, clean and very welcoming. The herbaceous borders were splendid. Having parted with £16.50 EACH to visit the dreadful Kew Botanical Gardens earlier in the day there is just no comparison - save your money and visit Regent's Park.
Nice park . It is a nice park for a walk in the summer, and also have some nice sitting places for a picnic or for a good read. Truly recomend it
Great park and not so busy. It is a great place to relax and completely forget that you are in a big city. When I went there weren't many people so it was very chilled.

Great city park place to take a break . This is really a beautiful heart Centrally location park in London. We didn't spend a lot of time here but took a break here while touring the rest of the city.

Surely one of the best. A beautiful urban park in the centre of London. On a lovely sunny day, this must surely be amongst the world's finest public spaces. Lovely flowers, beautiful trees, monuments, large lawns for picnicking, etc. Cafe serves nice lunches at reasonable prices. Baker Street or Regents Park tube stations are in easy walking distance. Walking distance from Madame Tussaud's, too. Delightful urban buildings flank the park, so that walking from the tube is also very nice. Don't miss this if you are nearby.

A beautiful park. Regents Park is a beautiful park to have a stroll in.The atmosphere is very relaxed and the gardens are beautifully kept.There are plenty of benches to sit down on and of course plenty of grass for a picnic.We enjoined an early morning stroll through the park and had breakfast with some very friendly squirrels!
A very nice place to relax. Take some time to relax and enjoy the atmosphere. After all, you are on vacation. The grass is green, the children are running around and the lovers are kissing.

So lovely. We were in the area for an event and walked around a bit. It's so beautiful. We got some fantastic pictures and it was a great day for it. It's definitely worth a stroll around. Very nice and relaxing :)
One of London's best parks. I find Regent's Park has one of the widest range of different areas in Central London Parks. It has so many little corners that have their own character...

Beautiful!. Really enjoyed strolling in the park. Much bigger parks than in my home country! Although that did mean longer walks. I rented a bike to cycle around the park, which made it even more fun, as you could cover more in a shorter distance. Highly recommend this! Park was very clean, lovely weather and atmosphere; a true must-go for nature lovers!
Sunday stroll. Nice park for a little Sunday stroll if you're having one of those lazy day. It's also very convenient for public transport.

Nice stroll. It's a lovely park to take a stroll. Several swan, ducks, birds and lake to see. We were caught in a storm and took cover in a cute gazebo. It's also near Baker Street, so if you'd like to check out Sherlock Museum, it's option too.

Queen's Rose Garden. The best place for my trip in early June. It is a sunny hot Friday morning but lots of people there to walk around and enjoying the songs composing by all the different roses. I may be a bit late as some of them surpasses their apex but I still have some beautiful pictures captured there. Good park!

Regents Park. Great place to experience a little peace in the city of London. Great area to walk around and to relax. Well worth the walk to get to, especially when your day has been full of sight-seeing.

Another park but close to Lords and Abbey Road. Much like many of the parks of London, pretty and relaxing and a good spot to chill but not a as specific destination.We grabbed some take away from a continental cafe near Lords, took our blanket and had a pleasant lunch after the Lord's tour before walking along Baker Street (remember Sherlock is a fictional Character - he didn't really live there)

Walk in the park. The park is in north london with loads of buses near-by to get to park there are plenty of quiet areas for you to take a picnic or have a quiet walk in the park or walk the dog whatever you feel like doing
Spacious. Very nice walk in the middle of a busy city. Sat and watched the school kids play cricket and general sat taking and people watching. Nice and relaxing

Peace. You can never believe you are in the middle of London here. The rose gardens are an absolute must in early summer, just the perfume is intoxicating and gives you a real sense of 'London Pride'. Just ambling along and people watching is reward enough for a feel good day.

I wish this was my jogging park.. Regent's Park is my favorite park by far - if only I lived closer to make it my normal jogging route. It has something for everyone - pond for paddle boating, walking/jogging paths, open fields for games, benches, cafes, and the flowers are stunning. The Queen's Rose garden is stunning, and should not be overlooked (only during late spring and summer though). Don't miss Primrose Hill which is located just north of the Zoo where you can get a great view of London.
amazing. Proper, quite, full of roses, and the london zoo very near.Pigeons and other bids all over the park.

A quiet haven. This is a proper park in the middle of a bustling city. A place where one can escape the traffic, enjoy the openness and get away from people. Less busy than Hyde Park which is a bit of a thoroughfare, from Regents Park one can enjoy the sounds of London Zoo access Primrose Hill and stroll along the canal.

Followed by geese!. My son and I took an afternoon stroll. The buildings and history are fantastic! It wasn't busy at all. However, we were followed by the geese and pigeons for a good length of the park. I think they smelled the crumbs on my child! He enjoyed it.

Heaven in central london. Go to Regents park and especially the area around rose gardens in the inner circle !!! So beautiful and roses that smell !! Some renovation at moment but never mind as there are so many little islands and areas of absolute delight ! Fountains. Statues and such a variety of plants and trees. Gorgeous. I was only passing through so didn't get to see too much of the park but the parts I did see were beautiful. Peaceful, beautiful, lovely.. Walked through the park to get to the zoo and I am glad we did. It's a lovely walk. Quiet, beautiful, lovely flowers. Maps at the main intersections, and coffee stands. Good place for a run, or a stroll. Quite beautiful.
Regents park. What a lovely park huge as we'll went with my daughter and granddaughter loads to see lovely gardens and statues and very clean.x

beautiful gardens. Although some of the tulips had gone over, the smell of the lilac was amazing. Still lots of colour in the beds we saw. Would be good if the plants were labelled, for instance there was a lovely tree with peeling bark but no lable
Beautiful!. One of the first parts of London I ever saw. Every time I go it's just as beautiful as my first time there.

a breath of country air in the heart of the city. I have been visiting Regent's Park for many years and know it in all the seasons. There are five main features. The first is the lake. Here you can see waterfowl of all kinds including tame herons and between Easter and October hire a rowing boat or pedal boat. The second is the Queen Mary's Gardens , which has wonderful roses from May to February when the roses are pruned. This also has a small lake and waterfall, a cafe and the famous open air theatre, Thirdly there is the area with the English gardens, there are walks here with poplar trees, fountains and flowerbeds . Fourthly there is the sports field , with a good dog walking area nearby.Finally there is Primrose Hill adjacent to the park, from which you can command great views of London after a healthy walk uphill. Here when it snows you can see people with sleds, sliding down. There are various events in Regents Park throughout the year, for instance the sculptures which are free, byond the Frieze art exhibition whuch costs. There are also fairs and other events. One of the better things to do for free. Beautifully landscaped gardens, gorgeous rose gardens, lakes and well maintained. One can easily spend a day here and not be bored. Highly recommend if you are an overseas visitor. Best of all, costs nothing.
Honest review. Exeptional place to visit when the weather is nice. I cannot fault it, tranquil and calm. Bit of advice, bring your own food and drinks...
Breathtaking . I've been here many times lovely place to walk or just relax you can see the regents park mosque from there and the London zoo
A beautiful park. It's a very beautiful park and very well taken care of, very relaxing with lots of squirrels, you can take some spectacular photos for the greenery there.

'Well kept, tranquil park'. Standing in the centre of Regents park you would never know you were in Central London. It really is a place to escape to. Stunning park, very we'll kept. Perfect place to spend a few hours in.

nice park. really nice park good locations with lots of little private spots! The ebst thing is its free! but the park really is very pretty the only thing is it needs to be sunny to really enjoy but apart form that really nice place!

Magnificent!. Was a sunny day today, and early spring, the tulips are beautiful in Regent's Park. The walk around the water, a splash of Earl Gray tea, and my camera kept me highly entertained on this trip! Recommend!

Wonderful!. This is simply a wonderful park and best of all, it's free! There are beautiful flowers and the park is immense, you can have a lovely walk whilst enjoying the view. There is also a zoo but we didn't get to see it as we were running out of time. Lovely!

Wonderful escape from busy central London. Beautiful park! Gorgeous to visit on a sunny warm day. Definitely worth a visit for a leisurely stroll, picnic or to just sit and enjoy nature in the middle of central London!

Beautiful Park. What a beautiful park...very clean and very well kept. Stunning flower collections with the most goregeous coloured flowers. Would highly recommend a visit to this wonderful Royal Park.

RSPB showed us the Herons.... Great little walk to see the flowers and get some greenspace in the middle of LondonBonus was the RSPB were there showing people Herons sitting in nests and explaining them allGood day out though the cafe kiosks are pricey!

Better than standing in line for "Madame Tussaud". We couldn't even imagine ourselves standing in 3 km line for 4-5 hours, so went to this amazing park and spent all day there. Pedal boats, lounge chairs (£1.50 per hour) and great playground
beautiful park. the park is a beautiful place to go when the sun is out, its so big and has many beautiful flower arrangements

Nature crave... that pull you again and again. It has something which you can only feel...if visit ever
Initially I was reluctant to roam the entire park but as moved on, was not able to stop myself
Nice Gardens. If you are lucky enough to be visiting london during spring/summer, Regen'ts Park cannot be out of your places to see. It's lovely during spring /summer

Best London Park. Hands down the quaintest park in London. Had a romantic saturday afternoon walk around the park with my girlfriend. Fed the ducks, watched an array of sports, sat on the grass by the river. The park was busy but it didn't encroach on our experience. Plenty of places to go sit down and relax. Only thing missing was an ice cream van!

Best park so far in London. I'm a New York City tour guide on vacation in London. After visiting the Wallace Collection at Manchester Square I walked up Baker Street towards Marylebone Rd. A couple blocks north beyond the huge Baker Street Station (Circle Line-yellow, Hammersmith and City Line-pink, Jubilee Line-grey, Bakerloo Line-brown, and Metropolitan Line-violet) after you've strolled by the Beatles Store and the Sherlock Holmes Museum you can enter Clarence Gate into Regent's Park. This is the southwest corner of Regent's Park. I have to say that so far Regent's Park has the most impressive blooms (both trees and flowers) of any park I've seen so far in London. The boating lake also has a wide variety of ducks and geese. If you walk past Regents University to Queen Mary's Gardens (there was a lot of work going on but not many flowers visible) there is a café with good and reasonably priced food. I ducked out of a springtime shower and enjoyed a pear salad at the café. The café is also a great place for a restroom break although there are public restrooms on Chester Road heading towards the eastern entrance/exit of the park. Rather than exit the east side of the park I diverted south through an impressive mall of flower plantings towards the south east exit. There I found the Regents Park Station (Bakerloo-brown line). At the north end of the park is the London Zoo but I did not visit. Regents Park is a nice place to get away from the urban frenetic activity and noise. It is a credit to Westminster and I recommend a visit.

Beautiful gardens, peaceful and full of all types of wildlife.. You would hardly believe you were so close to the centre of London in this lovely park, Monday morning, the time of my walk, it was an oasis of peace.

Such a massive space to do whatever you like!. So I've walked through these grounds with my girlfriend, run through them with friends, my AFL team uses one of the fields as it's training base, and that's just 3 things you can do is this massive, open parkland! Also, you can visit the zoo! It's a great place for a picnic and enjoy the sunshine, and it's a great place to just chill out! Enjoy it!

One of London's great Royal Parks. Regents Park is lovely all year round, come winter or summer. In the winer you will see runners galore... In the summer you will see families, couples and friends enjoying the sun! One favourite of mine is walking along the big lake! If you have time, take some Boris bikes around the park! A great way to explore and to take in the mass of the park!

Sunny day. I decided to walk around the park in a sunny day and I was surprised with the plenty of space and beautiful gardens that you can find in there. The park were full of people on that thay, inclusive team playing football.You must at least go through the english gardens, you will find it amazing.

Peace & tranquility - in the centre of London!. We had time to spare after breakfast on Sunday morning before the England vs. Wales game at Twickenham, so we wandered through the park.
What a great place to get away from it all - and it's all for free!

Absolutely Beautiful!. In my opinion the best and most beautiful park in London. It is an excellent park to walk through on a nice sunny day. The gardening and upkeep of the park is excellent. The London Zoo is also located on the north side of the park. All in all a fantastic destination in London to get out of the hustle and bustle.

Lovely. Lovely park to walk through on a nice day although there were vehicles in there spilling oil on the path as they were driving along, kind of spoilt it a bit having to dodge out of the way so I didn't get run over.
Impressive Park. The most beautiful park in London, especially in the springtime. Don't forget to check the Queen Mary's Gardens in the Inner Circle!
My favourite park. This is my favourite London park. I love the rose gardens here. I used to work near to this park and would sometimes visit during my lunch breaks.

Regents Park. Wonderful park to stroll through and enjoy the scenery surrounding you. Very centrally located. All sorts of wildlife inhabit the lake area and are fun to watch. The park also contains the London Zoo to the north side. I wish I had seen it during the Summer months with evrything fully in bloom. Another time then!!!

Beautiful Park in London!. I love this park, because it is centrally located and has many amenities including an open air Theatre and a Lake. My family and friends both agree that the park feels that you are in the countryside. Picnics are great....so take some food and enjoy the beautiful 'countryside' within the bustling city.
Lovely. A lovely park- we loved exploring and were especially delighted to discover the roses and outdoor theatre. Very peaceful. We ate outside and had a gorgeous meal.

Hit during the Summer, a miss during the Winter. Regent's Park is located just north of Marylebone and is one of London's largest public spaces, covering 395 acres of green space. Locally renowned for its high quality sporting facilities, gardens and Open-Air theatre, this makes one of the best park visits in the city during the Summer months. Probably one of the most popular attractions at Regent's Park is Queen Mary's Gardens, which are vibrant with colour during the warmer months of Summer. At this time, you can see thousands upon thousands of roses in bloom. A visit during June can be particularly rewarding for rose lovers. During winter months, the gardens are expectedly bare. There is also a nice lake in the park, providing boating recreation and place to see birdlife. Many varieties of waterfowl make use of the lake and they are quite active here during the summer, might be due to the number of people trying to feed them at these times. Another enjoyable activity at Regent's Park during the Summer months is the Open-Air Theatre found here. Between mid-May to mid-September, you can watch theatre performances under the evening sky and stars. This is just great fun and a nice way to spend time outside. Lastly, the London City Zoo can be found on the north side of Regent's Park along with a nice water canal and running track. Overall, there is quite a bit to see and do at Regent's Park but we feel it lends itself better to Summer visits compared to visiting during the colder periods of the year. The Gardens and Open-Air Theatre are two major reasons for visiting and they can't be enjoyed during the winter. As such, we sort of feel that Regent's Park is a hit during the summer but a miss during the winter time. Hint: Regent's Park can be accessed easily by the Regent's Park or Baker Street Tube Stations and there is a Garden Cafe near Queen Mary's Gardens. Hint: Fun activities in the area beyond the park include the Sherlock Holmes Museum, Beetles Shop and Madame Tussaud Museum.
Visit this in Summer.. I've been to the park twice, 1st time was in Summer and it's amazing with nice entrance and beautiful flowers. In winter it's normal and not as in Summer but still good.

Beautiful well kept park. Visited on a cold clear Feb morning, saw crocus, Helleborus and other flowers in bloom, ducks, heron, and walked along well groomed paths in Queens Garden. Would like to return and explore more. An excellent activity if you are staying nearby and just have the morning free before your int'l flight. You can stop by the cafe in the Queens Garden for a delicious breakfast and a warm up from the chill.

January:) walk and The boathouse Cafe Lunch. HiWent with in-laws and 2 babies to Regents Park for Walk and Lunch as the weather was brilliant that day. We loved it. I thought that in January will be dead there but surprisingly there was lots of going on:). The gardeners already were working on flower beds looking after greatest roses and you could spot some first signs of coming spring like popping daffodils . We had lunch at the Boathouse Cafe. We ordered very lovely fish and chips. Staff was absolutely great and helpful. I definitely will go back in full spring and summer with friends.Thanks
impressive park. Beautiful Park and architecture surrounding it.A nice area to have walks and enjoy the georgian architecture.

Amazing Park. Regent's Park is such a breathtaking park with its enormous size situated in the Central London. It is one of the London's royal park and it has many attraction inside it such as Queen Mary's Gardens, Open Air Theatre and London Zoo. You can decide just to walk around the park and chill out. Wonderful, relaxing green space away from the bustle of London. Heaven in London. Loved loved loved this park! We went there on a sunny day (which is rare in London:)) and enjoyed every second! I wish we had parks like Regent's in Turkey as well. I could spend my whole day there just watching the scenery.

if you live in a country with no squirrels its a mus see. if your in the area ( visiting madam Tussaud's or whatnot ) make sure you give this place a visit as in the rest of london park ull enjoy the of the urban park thing but here there were so many squirrels when we visited fun to play with pet and get harassed by

Peace in the Centre of London. Regents Park, one of the Royal Parks, is famous for housing London Zoo. However, it is a great place to walk and enjoy time away from the madding crowd.

Beautiful In December. One usually thinks of visiting the parks in summer, but this December day, I thought it was stunning.
