Summer in the City. Regent's Park is a stunning venue for picnicking, as a Londoner it is a fantastic after work destination as it is easy to reach from most areas of the city.The gardens, statues and fountains are worth seeking out, as well as a variety of food shops and kiosks.One of my favourite spots in the city, my only wish being that the park was kept open after dusk in the summer as London can remain quite hot. Such beauty within easy reach of the metropolis. Blown away by the miles of beautiful green parkland. En route to London Zoo we took a taxi from Baker St Station, a really worthwhile "scenic tour" of this carefully conserved area..Exiting the Zoo, we sat for a while to enjoy the views from a seat by the path, then crossed the inner ring and went over the bridge on the Canal, observing tourist barges and the Chinese restaurant..Experience was made even nicer by the bus driver who waited for us to catch up with him, the passenger who offered me a seat, and the further scenic journey back to Baker St Station, where the bus pulled up conveniently right outside the station door!.I would say that for anyone spending more than a few days in London, at least half a day could be usefully spent on buses or on foot, ambling around the area and refreshing the lungs, not to mention enjoying the beauty of the Park..Now I am wondering about a canal trip?
Beautiful. The park has and is kept so well. Its absolutely beautiful honestly I like it and its in london but not as central as the other royal parks so is nice

You ll like going around beautiful place. You ll like going around beautiful place .a wonderful central London park, with a beautiful pond with ducks, swans. It is close to Madame Tussauds and the Planetarium. You ll enjoy it sure .

A place of tranquility and adventure all rolled into one. An oasis in the centre of London. With lovely walks around the lake. Boating on the lake too. Concerts around the bandstand, world renowned open air theatre, and american baseball on Sundays. The flower beds are lovely at times.

just walked through on way to zoo. Wonderful park, plus Frieze Art Fair sculpture park to 20th Oct '13. A really wonderful central London park, with a beautiful pond with ducks, coots, swans. Really close to Madame Tussauds and the Planetarium.And in Oct there is one of the best art fairs in Europe - the Frieze Fair. Whilst the fair charges to see the exhibits, it is totally free to see the Sculpture Park with some really amazing artworks this year - see my pics - especially Jaume Plensa's 'Chloe' huge bronzed sculpture, whose face is perhaps the most photographed sculpture in the park. I also like the Rachel Whiteread shed, and the Jeppe Hein 'Geometric Mirrors', plus Gimhongsok's 'Love' in polished metal.Excellent art fair, though the entrance price is quite high at £32.

Different than other parks. Regents park has some lovely little areas to sit and people watch. It's also a good spot to go on a nice stroll for a clear day. The best park in London!. Since it´s not so full of tourists as the Hyde Park, the Regent´s is much more quiter and pleasant. Make sure you feed the squirrels, it´s one of the best things I´ve ever done in my life!

My favourite spot in London. I go back to Regent's Park every time I'm in London. It's such an elegant park, with new plants and flowers every season. The driving rain did not spoil the beauty of Regent's Park. The park is very well maintained and there are lovely peaceful areas where one could escape with a book on a dry summer's evening. Today there was heavy rain and apart from a few dog walkers, there was a feeling of having this huge garden all to myself. Will definitely return in the springtime

Rose Garden was Awesome!. I could not believe how beautiful the Rose garden was. Even though it was late September the roses were still mostly in bloom. I just wish we had time to visit London zoo while we were there.

Great for a walk, jogging or just relaxing. I live near the park and visit it every day. I tried to fall in love with the Hide Park but there was no chemistry... Regents park is a magic place. Variety of things that can be done there is huge ! You have a Zoo, restaurants and bars. Don't forget to visit the hill- view from it (especially after dark) is just stunning. An idyllic retreat. Easily accessible near Bake Street Station, this park transports you to another level of enjoyment, not seeming to be quite real in its perfect beauty, atmosphere, calling to nature and greenery. Beautifully landscaped and maintained, it is a well spent respite from the hustle and bustle of the surrounding city.

Expansive, Beautiful. You'd never guess this quiet, tranquil park is surrounded by a buzzing city. It's fields stretch considerably, walkways crisscross the trees, the central promenade runs as far as you can see, gardens and creeks hide among the foliage, and strange animal noises emanate from the London Zoo on the northern end of the park. On a clear day, stroll through the park near sundown. You'll feel relocated from an urban metropolis to a National Geographic spread. Come for the gardens, or the zoo, or just to get away from the city.

Peaceful retreat. I came here with friends on a lazy Sunday afternoon. The park serves as a peaceful retreat after a very stressful week. Apart from the lush greenery and the scenic beauty which is a treat for the eyes, the park also offers various activities for those looking for some thrill and adventure like the tennis court, cricket ground etc. The most mesmerizing sight is the lake, an artificial one but you hardly know the difference.

My favorite park in London. This is my favorite of the royal parks in central London, and like the others, is large enough for you to forget you are in the middle of a bustling city. I used to come here often when I was a student in London and lived nearby. The park is beautifully maintained all year round, you can also enjoy a calm moment with family or friends.

A foodie's drug. Taste of London is a mid-sized food festival that takes place each year in London's Regent's Park. It's a chance to taste small tapas sized plates of food served up by Michelin starred chefs, as well as buy artisanal produce. It's a foodie's dream. Stalls are dotted around the park, each with taster plates from dishes each chef serves in their respective restaurants. Le Gavroch (the famous Michelin restaurant started by the culinary royalty that are the Rouxs) were there serving up some of their classics like Pork Belly with Black Pudding and Tomato spiced Jus. The festival works on the principal that no money exchanges hands. Instead you buy crowns. The value of a single crown is 50p. Dishes vary between 6 and 16 crowns so you need a good amount of crowns to get the most out of the experience. I'd say around 30 per person could work. So effectively each dish averages at around £6. It's not cheap, so it's fair to say that you have to be very food orientated to part with £6 for 4 spoons of food.We had a variety of things but we didn't go crazy. My husband loved the White Chocolate Pannacotta from Alyn Williams restaurant The Westbury. He also liked Alyd's Braised Beef Cheek, which was very rich but tender as hell. We did think the fact they said it lay on a bed of Baked Potato Foam was a little pretentious (it was just mash), however what do you expect when eating dishes from some of the worlds best restaurants?Other things we enjoyed were the seared Scallops from Theo Randall and the Monkfish Kebab from The Savoy.The weather was typical. It started off relatively warm and towards the end was a little windy and cold. Nonetheless it's a real experience and a joy if you want to taste food from restaurants you may otherwise not have the chance to go to.Taste of London10/10Regents ParkLondonhttp://london.tastefestivals.com/london/default.aspx

The Most Beautiful of the London Royal Parks. This is my favourite of the royal parks in central London, and like the others, is large enough for you to forget you are in the middle of a bustling city. I used to come here often when I was a student in London and lived nearby. The park is beautifully maintained all year round and has a variety of scenery all within fairly close walking distance; lush grassy areas, a rose garden in summer, lakes with little scenic bridges going over them, an open air theatre in summer (book in advance as tickets are hot!), a boating lake, a separate (and very large) area for people who want to play football and other sports. Perfect for picnics, lazing around reading a book, playing football/frisbee/rounders etc with friends, romantic (or other) walks, walking your dog, jogging, cycling around the rounds that run around the park.Regents Park Zoo is also nearby. (A paid attraction. Also recommended for a family day out.) Primrose Hill is within walking distance (allow 15-25 minutes) for a great view of London from the top of the hill.In terms of access and amenities, there are two tube stations fairly nearby (Baker Street and Regents Park stations) and there are shops near those stations where you can pick up snacks on the way. The park also has public toilets and a cafe, and maps near each entrance in case you get disorientated. Note: As I recall, the cafe is small, so if you want a proper meal and havent brought a picnic with you, you will have to venture outside of the park to a restaurant or supermarket.On hot sunny days the park can get incredibly busy with sunbathers out en masse. But this is the same for all London Parks and Squares and you may need to go out to Greenwich or beyond if you want a bit of space to yourself. I prefer the park when it is less busy in misty Spring when the buds are opening and the ducklings are out or in golden, crunchy-leafed Autumn when the squirrel are gathering their nuts. The park is particularly beautiful when the seasons are changing. You forget you're in the middle of the city and can enjoy a miniature taste of the glorious English countryside.

Lovely place to stay if i had more time!. Have to walk ? to "queens mary gardens" portion to get a more beautiful scene of the place and it can get quite hot under the noon ? sun! Nice place to relax where there are beautiful flowers ??? with big patches of greenery! Worth a visit if you are coming to madam Tussaud or Sherlock Holmes!

Beautiful Well Groomed Park. We were surprised when we visited here mid September that the flowers were so beautiful. In Texas, because of heat, our summer flowers are gone. Everything was so well groomed in the park. The fountains and greenery were so gorgeous. It was peaceful to stroll and meander through. There is a nice cafe with restrooms.

Something to be proud off... Had a lovely morning stroll around this park - never been before always been to Hyde Park. Surroundings of the park are fabulous with the large mansions facing the park and if your a keen cyclist its the place to be as there's lots of them using the road around the park. The park itself is very well maintained and lots to look at as you walk around the park. Gets very busy around lunchtime but you'll always find a quite spot to relax in. A park you must visit and enjoy.

Lovely!. Having seen the movie dozens of times I wondered how I would enjoy the stage show. Not disappointed! This was a lovely production, brilliant vocals, great acting, amazing setting, very intimate venue. Loved it!

A great afternoon. When I’m in London I usually like to visit Hyde Park. This time, in taking a break from the bustle of Camden Markets, I found it was a short walk to Regent’s Park and saw for myself how much it has to offer. One of the highlights is Queen Mary’s Gardens. There’s also the London Zoo, and the Open Air Theatre. Plus of course there’s plenty of open space with about 100 acres for soccer etc, in fact it has the largest outdoor sports area in London.There are also cafés and other places to eat. I found the Honest Sausage off the Broadwalk to be really convenient.If it’s good weather on a Sunday afternoon and you’re looking for somewhere to take the kids, or just yourselves, you would be well served to go to Regent’s Park.
Afternoon visit. Lovely walks very relaxing. Limited quality eating places. Gourmet sausage in centre poor value and limited choice of options.

Beautiful Park. I love Regents Park. Its much more quiet than Hyde Park, with some private gardens as well as a public space. If you are looking for a beautiful central location to go and have a picnic on a sunny day, I would highly recommend this for a visit. Sound of Music - Open Air Theatre Regent's Park. Think :- Primary School production on their bad day.The production, direction and performances are pathetic. Started very very late - perhaps to allow more food and drink salesHad to walk out at intermission, only to find most of the exits locked - with 1200 people locked inside? - a disaster waiting to happen no doubt with lessons to be learned?Amateur night at the Operatic Society meets Fire Officer's nightmare

Play area great well maintained park. never been to regents park before and found it to be brilliant, took 2 kids who are good at moaning not a peep out of them entire time here. Play area brilliant all clean plenty of things to play on. Gardens well maintained the children loved looking round them. When back in London will be putting this on the list for places to go.

Tranquil Oasis. Our second visit to this park and it's still as beautiful.We strolled through here after a visit to the Zoo and it was so lovely walking through the different garden "rooms". There are plenty of shady areas to sit and places to buy food. Of course, it's just nice to sit and watch the people go by. So relaxing after rushing around sight seeing.

another great park. lived in Regents but never went to the park till this summer .. I have to say I need to go back again and take it all in .. an amazing park too .. loved it .. everything about it is relaxing .. great for families or simply for your own time off to enjoy greenery or even read .. a must see

OPEN AIR THEATRE. Great location in fab !!! regents park Fabulous production of "Sound of Music" Sadly the theatre is very tired and needs some money thrown at it, also very very hot "great" but no shade and my daughter was nearly passing out ! need some big sails for shade or protect against showers, like Kilworth House open air theatre.Otherwise fab !!
An oasis in busy London. A place of quiet, with well kept formal flower beds and fountain. Good for a lunchtime stroll, with plenty of seats.

Take it.....Take it......Now smell it.. Sensational place. Truly lovely walks and strolls. Great flowers and trees. Excellent for a coffee and cake. What a fantastic open space in London. Somewhere not to be missed.
Beautiful gardens. Wonderful place to stroll around and enjoy the flowers. If you're visiting in the summer, the rose gardens are spectacular! Also lovely perennial and annual displays.

One of the 2 best open spaces in London. Along with Hampstead Heath (wild), one of the 2 best open spaces in London. Whereas Hampstead heath is wild, Regents Park is refined. Especially worth visiting are the canal (lovely yo walk along to Camden Lock Market) and London Zoo. Favourite part thoggh, and possibly the most romantic place in London is the Rose Garden in late spring and early summer - perfect place for a date ...

English gardens are a highlight. This was by far our most favourite royal park in London, really loved the English gardens immensely, immaculately manicured with the fountains and lovely colourful flowers, even got to feed a friendly squirrel so my youngest teenage daughter was impressed (always keep some nuts in your pocket when you go for a walk in the London parks). The Queen's gardens were also in full bloom. with many different varieties of prize winning roses, each labelled with their names. There was also a beautiful lake upon entering the York gate, to the left, with many different birdlife, benches to rest on, and beautiful landscape, We walked across the park to get to the exit at Gloucester gate, this part of the park is an empty green space, where many groups of people were playing football/volleyball/rugby, taking their dog for a walk or jogging or just lazing around- it was a Saturday, so there were many locals out and about. There was also a wedding ceremony being held, as there was a beautiful looking grey church just on the boundaries of the park; very lovely for a stroll, a ten min walk gets you to Camden Lock markets from here, which are also worth visiting.
Beautiful Park. It is a beautiful park and we enjoyed walking through the park. Lots of picnic area. It has a beautiful garden. It is a must see. Don't miss visiting the park.
great!. Wonderful, big park. Great play area for kids and the theatre is a stunning, magical place hid amongst the trees and bushes. Had a great time here, will definately visit again.

A nice place to wander.. Fairly busy park but is a nice place to wander around to find a quiet spot.
Walked around this nice central London park after an afternoon at London Zoo.
Fun for all. Playgrounds for kids (and a zoo), beautiful terraces, space to play cricket & football, beautiful rose garden. You can spend the whole day there, and even more...

Perfect when you´ve got ice cream. We missed the restaurant we aimed for and ended up with organic milkshakes and ice cream. What can go wrong when you´ve got ice cream? Walked from Zoo to Baker Street.
Uplifting. A group of us went to see the open air production of "The Sound of Music". It was a fantastic production, enjoyed by everyone.

A lovely walk in the park. Regent's Park covers 395 acres and includes Queen Mary's Gardens, which features more than 30,000 roses of 400 varieties, which perfumes the air, As the park contains the Open Air Theater, Boating Lake, London Zoo, Primrose Hill, the country's largest free to access waterfowl collection and has excellent sports facilities (including the largest outdoor sports area in central London), many visitors to the park come for alternative reasons, but adding a walk around the park is actually highly recommend. The free to enter park is open from 5am everyday, and closes between 4:30pm - 9:30pm depending on the time of year. Within the park deckchairs are charged per hour, but all park benches are free, and you can sit on the grass during dry weather. Although fires and barbeques are strictly prohibited, picnics on the grass are encouraged, so do bring a blanket and basket.

Disappointed. The park as a whole is fantastic - however the information on the website is not up to date.We had planned a visit to Regent's Park in order to go boating (rowing boats) as part of a birthday celebration. Having located the boating lake and boat hire area we tried to hire a rowing boat only to be told that they only have pedalos. When I commented that the website listed rowing boats (checked only the day before), I got a rather unexpected sarcastic response 'well the website says a lot of things'. Not helpful! Next time we will fork out the higher price and go to Hyde Park instead.

spectacular rose Garden in summer. Great for a stroll, to relax for a while reading your book, or even going to the London Zoo there.was there in July and the Rose garden was most impresive, never seen so many roses in my life!
A walk in the park. The gardens are beautiful. We walked all the way from Oxford St. to Camden Market through the park. Great scenery.

Huge Park, Lots to See. Went on Saturday and this park is huge, lots to see and lots of people enjoying themselves in the sunshine. Lots of little nooks and places to sit, a lake and wildlife to watch and enjoy. Well worth a visit.

Always a treat. The park is large enough to allow variety and corners to retreat to, even in summer.The real delight is the Rose Garden, which offers a wide variety of roses some fragrant some not, but when in full bloom it is an experience to cherish.The other real treasure is the open air theatre where Shakespeare dominates, but a musical usually appears in the programme each year.One of the joys of London.
Quite Big. The Park is quite big, i think it took us 45 mins to walk from one end to the the other in a straight line. The Zoo in it is also worth visiting, you'll need a full day to see it all.

A Park worthy for the Queen!. What a spectacular park with gardens so beautifully laid out, a show case of a true English garden! The place is also tranquil and peaceful, in the middle of the city of London! The park has spectacular topiaries, fountains, pond and flowing water! There is a separate garden devoted solely to roses - of breathtaking colors and varieties. I was lucky enough that my cousin, Florrie, her husband, Danny and their two beautiful daughters, Esse and Bekka, live not far away from this park. I not only enjoyed this very lovely park, I also had so much fun with the girls feeding the birds at the pond!

Lovely walk. After visiting London Zoo me and best mate decided to walk back to Regent Street Tube Station. So we took a leisurely walk back, so so peaceful, quite, amazing. Always something happening in the park. Very nice walk about in almost perfect weather
Huuuuge but beautiful park. beautiful park with nice gardens, a lake, and plenty of grass with deck chairs (charged) to chill or for the more active ones: sports ground as well.
relaxing. full of flowers, clean, lots of space and nice to walk in it. The park is well care and once in a while there are classical music performance free of charge.

Beautiful park. What a beautiful and large park this is. Particularly enjoyed the rose garden. All the roses were out when we visited on a sunny day and the smell was just wonderful. Have visited so many places in London but have somehow missed this park before. Will definitely be visiting again (with a picnic this time!) Great place if you have children but also for couples - something to suit everyone. We travelled up on a Saturday afternoon and had no trouble parking for free on the outskirts of the park.

Open air theatre. Set in the beautiful surroundings of Regent Park, the sound of music is now playing, with it's timeless collection of songs. Accompanied by a live orchestra, and outstanding performances. A must see!

Tranquility in the City. We walked here from Camden town, just lovely to sit and enjoy the amazing space, lovely to meander through on a hot summers day, walked past the open air theatre where they were rehearsing the Sound of Music for the eve performance, sounded brill.

Beautiful park in central London, but away from the hub-bub. I live on the outskirts of London, but rarely go in to town. But today we visited Regent's Park, Regent's Canal, the open air theatre and Camden Lock. Absolutely loved them all and would highly recommend. On the canal we used the London waterways bus (note, no commentary, whereas I think Jason's Trip services do have a commentary). Took this from Maida Vale to Camden Lock. Lovely scenic, very peaceful, journey. A shame that the graffiti along the way isn't cleaned off, as this could be such a beautiful trip. A very easy walk too away from the crowds and the roads. Camden Lock - well worth a visit, very eccentric. Every sort of food to be sampled! Lots of craft stalls. Regent's Park was the highlight for us though - lots of different areas, beautifully planted borders, huge open spaces with people playing sport or picnicking. Lovely boating late, the rose gardens were so fragrant and beautiful - and almost the entire time if you did a full 360 you could not see a road, or a building - you could be in the country side! Lovely to watch the world go by. We went to the theatre in the evening - our first time - and it was magical. Stunning setting (we saw the Sound of Music, which was amazing), beautiful evening, delightful. I'd go back in a heartbeat. If it's rained the night before though, take a plastic bag to sit on as the chairs have cushions and they are wet! All round, a really beautiful and interesting part of London.

Great place for a stroll. Loved strolling around and walking into the Queen Mary's Garden. If you want a cheap view of the zoo you can do that from here. I was able to see a couple of zoo exhibts, and the size of the zoo from here. The zoo is not that big and it gives you a chance to see if you really wanted to pay to see it.
Delightful. Lovely place to stroll in the evening light - flowers, music, trees - a great contrast to the busy roads outside.

Open air theatre, what a treat. I went to see Pride and Prejudice. Mr Darcy was very lovely but sadly no wet shirt scene, still the whole evening was brilliant. The stage and seating very comfortable and as it was a barmy night I didn't need anything to protect me from the British sky!The bar was set in a green area with twinkly lights which made it a magical setting, and though I didn't eat there the food smelt and looked good. A great place to visit for Londoner and visitor alike and you will all take away good memories. I will be going again! Hope to see you there.

Huge Park. This is a huge park and on a glorious sunny day when we visited enjoying walking on the pathways and pedalling on the boating lake. Had been to the zoo before so didn't visit that this time but the park is great to have a meander through.

A trip highlight. We've been to London many times, and always focused on visiting historical and other sites. We walked and rode past Regent's Park, Hyde Park and Green Park many times without ever bothering to explore. We fixed that on our recent trip. To cover as much as the parks as possible, rent a bike from one of the Barclay's Bike Rental locations -- perhaps the best travel and tour bargain in all of London. We rented at Green Park, then rode through Hyde Park and Regent's Park, stopping along the way to enjoy flowers, gardens, statues, swans, people watching and much more. We ended our day with a walk along nearby Regent's Canal and Little Venice -- another surprise and wonderful discovery for us.

Regent's Park has a different character to the other large London parks. Regent's Park has a different character to the other large London parks. Like the others, it is large and well kept, perhaps busiest at the south side where access from public transport is easiest. If you are approaching from Baker Street then it is possible to get into the park and have a short walk and still get away from it all, if time is pressing.

A few metres from our digs...a lovely escape from the BUSY city. Conveniently located smack dab in the middle of it all that is central London, and only a few 100 m from our digs is Regent Park. A lovely escape from the BUSY ness that is London. if there is a better park any where we'd like to hear about it. Live theatre all summer! Brilliant. And our highest recommendations.

Best park in London. Regents Park is by far the best park in London. The flowerbeds are immaculate, the rose garden the best i have ever seen, fountains, bridges, swans, ducks, boating, sportsfields, plenty of quriky cafes, jogging track. From some parts of the park you can also get a peek into the London Zoo.Primrose Hill which is a part of this park has the most amazing skyline view of london and is a very tranquil spot, perfect for a picnic.

An escape from the city. A great park to relax and read a book in the grass in the avenues of trees and flowers or by the lake with the ducks. A great escape from the city. Very clean & peaceful. Still get a kick that a small part of The Kings Speech was featured in this park.

Why did I never explore here before?. In all the time I have spent in London, I never took the time out to really explore Regent's Park. What a gem! There a boating lake (and a great variety of beautiful water fowl), an open-air theatre, tennis courts, a really top quality garden restaurant and absolutely fabulous garden areas to stroll through. London parks are a wonder--there is every kind of experience of park land in London and I never tire of exploring them!

Absolutely beautiful!. We stayed at a hotel near Regents Park and we really enjoyed walking around there! The rose gardens were beautiful and the English gardens were immaculately kept. The park is a great place to have a picnic, people-watch, or just sit down and relax. I was very impressed with this park!

Equally as good as Hyde Park, if not better!. I truly enjoyed Regent's Park, maybe even more than Hyde Park. The garden is the most amazing you will see; far better than any other park in London has to offer. The Open Air Theater is a plus if you catch a performance there. Even if you don't see a performance there; just hang out in the park, sit down, have some lunch and enjoy the day.
Amazing Rose Garden. If you like roses don't miss the rose collection. Never seen so many roses in bloom in one place. Absolutely stunning and I'm not easily impressed.
Most Amazing Garden Ever!. This is one of the most beautiful gardens I've ever seen. Go when the flowers in the inner circle are in bloom. Not to be missed!

Get some better loos. Well done Regents Park for a fantastic production of Pride and Prejudice. But what would Jane Austen make of the queue for the loos. Women were practically backed up to Baker Street tube. Only go to this theatre if you enjoy the humiliation of standing around for 20 mins beforehand in a loo queue.

Jane Austen!. Regent's Park is a jewel! We went to see Pride and Prejudice at the Open Air Theatre and loved it! Such a beautiful setting to see a play. Years back we saw Wind in the Willows there--too perfect. These are gorgeous plays in an amazing setting--GO!!

An amble around Regents Park. This is a really beautiful park to visit especially the Inner Circle which has a magnificent rose garden and a large fountain. There is also a good café in this area. The park is well way marked and has many varied areas to explore including a large lake with some unusual water birds and bridges and waterfalls. While there it is worth taking a stroll up and down Primrose Hill from the top of which is a good view.
glorious. A lovely, varied park, especially delightful in the evening when the band is playing and locals are walking their dogs.

Lovely green paradise. A beautiful and well maintained garden very close to Lords Cricket ground. Lots of green spaces, small water bodies and lovely flowers. A great place to spend your afternoon if the sun is out. Lots of open spaces for kids to play and run around. A nice coffee shop for a quick bite or a hot cup of tea / coffee.
fun. this park is great, they have lots of grass and ponds. My kids love to run through the park to the other side. Great little coffee shop in the park great for cold rainy day!!!

The most beautiful garden I've ever seen. It's fantastic! If you like gardens then you must go to this London Park, especially to the inner circle. I've never seen so many roses in bloom. And there's lots of other flowers too, all very neatly planted and arranged.

have to go!. to finish in great and calm style a big trip.
Beautfull small places and gardens, zoo...
Wish you a luck sunny day, that´s perfect!

Great Park to Escape the Busy City. Regent's Park is a lovely park and a bit of an oasis in the city. Easily accessed either by tube (Regent's Park) or bus or even walking distance for those like us who like to wander, the park is a great place to relax or take a weekend stroll. Very handy for London Zoo which is at the north end of the park, there are plenty of seats and little pathways to follow if time is on your side and you don't need to rush.

Pride and Prejudice. Brilliant setting to watch this play which was well staged.It is a very civilised venue ,we took a bottle of wine into the auditorium and two glasses. You are at the mercy of the elements and we were lucky so had a great evening.

Fantastic park when you need a break from the hustle. Regents park is a huge green space to the north of the city. It contains classical gardens, a lake, beautiful plants and flowers as well as myriad of paths and trails. It is home to London Zoo and has an outdoor theatre in the summer. Whether you want a pleasant stroll or an energetic jog this is the place to go.

Open Air Theatre. We spent a wonderful afternoon at Regent's Park Open Air Theatre at the beginning of June. After coffee and cake in the well stocked café, we took our seats and found them pleasantly comfortable with a great view of the stage. {I think there would be a good view from anywhere in the auditorium!} The cast of To Kill A Mockingbird were fantastic and we were transported to the Deep South...they received a well deserved standing ovation come the end of the production. We were full of praise for the whole experience.

Worth a stroll. Went for a walk through Regents Park on my visit to London. What a lovely time it was!There is a lovely vibe/atmosphere to this place. There's a cafe or two in which you can have a bite to eat or a drink from. A massive lake, plenty of grass to sit on (for picnics), lots of trees and stunning flowers. Even tried a go on the pedalos which was fun!
A great get away. Original hunting grounds for the royals. Green house of the city. Huge park, Must spend some time for relaxation.
Great relaxing place. We walked through the park after visiting Madame Tussaud's Museum. It is a very lovely and huge park. We strolled though it and enjoyed the afternoon time there.

Aaaaah space ... In central London. Lakes, walks, runners, bikes, huge open space, trees, roses, cafes .. A great space to deflate and just hang and enjoy green open space for all ages, be it on bike, foot, running shoe or with a soccer ball.
One of my favorite parks!!. You must check out this park..quite lovely and the London Zoo is so close. THis was my favorite pak in London...very serene and stunning!!

Beautiful park, even on a cloudy day. Visited in June 2013. Short walk from Baker Street station. Lots to see including many ducks and flowers. Though the roses weren't all in bloom, it was a lovely spot. Wish it was warmer so I could've brought a lunch and sat for a while.

Lovely place to have a picnic with the family. Has a Sunday off and as the weather was nice decided to pop down for a picnic in the park. There is a lovely play area for the kids - although it gets busy, and feeding the ducks and squirrels was great fun for the kids. A nice safe and free way to spend a sunny afternoon.

Fabulous production of "To Kill a Mockingbird". Even tho it had rained all day, it finally let up and the play was presented. Robert Sean Leonard and cast were superb. However, it was freezing cold after the rain...and 3 people in our group got sick. ...but the theatre and play were amazing. Hopefully better weather will follow in June.

Best Park in London. This is by far the best park in London. Make sure you include on all visits to London. The gardens are beautiful and there is so much to do. You could spend a day exploring. Make sure you include a visit to the lake to hire a boat or pedalo especially if the weather is nice. Lots of little cafes/restaurants around as well to see and London Zoo is in the park as well!! What more could you want from a park?

One of the best parks in London. London is a great city with a lot of sights and greenery. In fact, the greenery is one of the things that attracts me to London so much more than so many of the other great cities in the world. Of all the great parks, Regent's is arguably the best. While the park does have the usual playing fields that you see in others like Hyde, it also has beautiful well maintained gardens where you can quietly stroll and enjoy the colours. There is a lake that meanders through the west and southwest of the park, filled with ducks, geese, swan and herons. Part of the lake also has boating for couples and families. There is also the zoo at the northeast end of the park, and a theatre where they show Shakespeare and other plays in the summer. Along the top of the park is a canal that winds up through the zoo and into Camden.We enjoy taking walks through Regent's every chance we get.
Beautiful Park!. Birds, flowers, trees, lawns, fountains, ponds, winding paths, and benches everywhere - Regents Park is one of the best parks in London and great place to relax and refresh.

As good as all the others. Regent's Park is as beautiful as the other parks, and you can be walking for hours and not realise you have walked into another park. Only lacking more visible signs to direct you,

Beautiful park. The trees in Regents Park are abundant. It is a beautifully kept and a relaxing retreat. There are several venues for food, mostly coffee and snack type treats. Extra special to have the zoo in park.

Be enchanted in the rose gardens. Regent's Park has just about everything! Wide open spaces to wander, play and picnic; the Serpentine for the energetic; the wonderful performances at the Open Air Theatre which are an absolute MUST - every year is different, every performance is enthralling and the sets are brilliantly professionally innovative! We saw "Ragtime" last summer and were moved by the moving performance. The rose gardens ... on a warm summer day the fragrance is heady and the roses wonderful ... a sea of glorious blooms - heaven! Of course, there are play areas and lots, lots more ... you'll just have to go yourself - it's free and there's always something different to see ... and there's so much more (the Zoo for a start)!

The greatest of all London Parks. You can walk from Kings Cross to Westminster practically without leaving a park,try it some day.Some people think of the Zoo when Regent Park is mentioned but the Park is large & glorious .Start your visit by going to Canden or Chalk Farm & get away from the gross bits of Camden Market come down Regents Park Road which is lovely, and walk up Primrose Hill and just survey the Regents Park from thid birds eye view.Then go and lose yourself in the green idyll! welcome.

A beatiful park. A lovely oasis with so many beautiful fountains, statues and floral displays. we fed the squirrells who came down from the tres to enjoy some nuts. plenty of places to sit and enjoy the sunshine, a tranquil and lovely place.

Roses. When you are in London in late May and if the weather is has been friendly all through the year you must visit the REgent's Park to see the veriety of roses. There are hundreds of kinds of roses that bloom in May with name tags on them. It is a magnificient sight to see and photograph. Regents Park is also a quiet and pleasant place to take a long walk and spend the day. Easy to reach: 10 minutes walk from Baker Street tube station. I heartily recommend to those who like spending time in the open.

Very near the Zoo. This park is very beautiful with many trees and flowers. There is a children play area, also a lake where you van have boat ride. If you go there on weekend or in sunny weather the queue for the boats can be very long. Regents park is an ideal place for picknick with friends. Just take your own packed lunch and drinks and sit on the grass in the wonderful nature. The toilets on the day were temporary as they were fixing the facilities in the park. Great for football, or just a walk.

An oasis in the heart of the city!. Very pleasant, lots of space, no matter how many people there are. Gardens and lake very picturesque. Ideal for walking, jogging, sitting etc. food, drink, toilets available and mostly suitable for those with disabilities. London Zoo adjacent. Could be a million miles from anywhere, never mind in the heart of the city.

Wonderful place to just walk around. A wonderful place to just walk around and enjoy the sights of ducks and assorted birds congregating on and near the Boating Lake. Takes you away from Central London. Toilet facilities are good, and the infrastructure seems well maintained. Well worth a visit to relax and chill out.
Beautiful park, Great atmosphere. Beautiful park, Great atmosphere, many beautiful trees, flowers, fountains.Looks pretty much like a royalty park.Well worth the visit.

Splendid in any weather. This park is huge! And every season brings along a different set of delightful flowers. I have been there on a hot sunny day, on a snowy day, on a misty day, on a rainy day, and it it is always a lovely place to be. To get some fresh air and people watch. And it is right next to the London Zoo. You can see some of the animals from the park border with the zoo so perhaps you don't even have to pay the entrance fee for the zoo ;-)

A Paradise in Central London. Located not far from the city centre this park was beautifully maintained and clean.It was so quiet when in the park you couldn't hear any traffic outside of it, you could forget you were in London
Cricket, coffee and flowers. A great way to spend a couple of hours strolling through the park, watching the many cricket matches and stopping at the café.

Beautiful. This is a huge park with so much to see and the gardens are kept so nice, it is a must see when visiting London, especially to get away from it all. At one point you can see into London zoo to the giraffe's, a real surprise! Walk upwards through the park and cross the road to Primrose hill to be rewarded with a great view of London.

paradise. perhaps the most beautiful park i've ever been to! flowers and fountains makes you feel like being in heaven! go to boathhouse cafe to grap some tea and relax after long waiking in the park!!

The "Other" Park. This is my favorite park in London. The landscaping/flowers are amazing. I used to go here years ago just for a pleasant place to get away from the city. Bring a good book and relax. Or walk around and explore the many 'hidden' nooks.
Perfect summers day.. Take in a play or visit the zoo, theres a lot on offer and even if you just picnic it's a lovely park. Please take your litter with you and keep it beautiful.
Central Bliss. I love going for a quick run around Regent's Park. Lovely flower gardens, always buzzing with couples and people having their lunch and you have the Zoo too!!

Forever spring. There is an interesting atmosphere here in Regents Park.I use to work and live at both ends of it for one year! My trip to and from work was just fascinating!Felt that was a spring, whatever weather is, whatever season was.Every tree, every single flower(There are hundred thousands, specially at inner circle) wispering you words of love and perpetual spring, and laughter.

Fantastic park. This was my 14th time visiting London but my first time in Regent's Park. What a fantastic park. The flower beds where beautiful so was some of the Fountains. We went for a stroll in the park and I went running a few times while in London. I ran up to Primrose Hill and the view was fantastic!Antoher amazing thing is that you can run around the zoo which I think is amazing.We also went to the Zoo which both my brother and I was impressed by. We have a fantastic zoo i Kristiansand, Norway, so we are a bit picky when it comes to Zoo's.I will defenetily visit the park again.
perfect place to have a rest. perfect place to have a rest. its in north of london and from oxford street it takes 15 min. to walk. there is a london zoo inside and mosque.

Glorious!. Visited today (May Day Bank Holiday Monday) - weather wonderful, got better and better as the day went on. We came by bus and entered the Park by the gate near the Mosque. Hadn't visited for many many years and forgotten how lovely it is. The blossom and flower beds were glorious - each part of this huge park has a different character and we weren't able to visit and appreciate all of it in the time we had. It was so good to see so many people and many families out enjoying the good weather. Will visit again soon now that we have rediscovered it!

Favourite!!!. It's sooo beautiful ! I was pretty surprised how nice and HUGE it is!!!For you it won't be enough to spend one day to observe everything!Each part of park is unique. Different places-different impressions.It's ideal for all of your familyIf you want to have a great time-this is the best place for you!!!!

Great space. Another great park in London with beatiful flower beds, and an open air theatre. We had tea at the Organic Sausage cafe where there are toilets. There are lakes with lots of birds and a boating area.

Refresh yourself. Great place for a picnic. Even greater place to see the outdoor theatre and anything that happens to be on the afternoon or evening you are there. We've stopped many a time, or made time to stop over, just to catch a picnic in the delightful green of the park and to see some of the best inexpensive theatre in London on a beautiful summer's eve.

oasis of peace. Regents park is a firm favourite for whiling away a summers afternoon. Wonderful rose gardens, lovely water features and everything to make you feel that you are far away from the city

Feeling like a kid, feeding ducks in beautiful Regent's Park. There is no better place for a stroll on a beautiful day in London than Regent's Park. I confess I have not explored half the vast park, but everywhere I have been is beautiful. At first I was a bit disappointed to be missing the rose garden in bloom, having remembered it as a beautiful spot on a previous visit, but that disappointment quickly turned to fascination at the beauty all around. You will leave your cares behind in this tranquil setting.

It's got the lot. Gorgeous, gracious, grand park. Wander along with a smile on your face. The architecture of the buildings lining the park are some of London's finest.There's a good play park for the kids, boats to hire, and an ok cafe (if you order the homemade pizza)

Memory Park!. I spent an enjoyable couple of hours relaxing and walking round Regents Park. Sitting and watching the variety of bird life was fascinating, especially watching the herons and heronry. As a very small child, my mother used to take me daily round the outskirts of London Zoo, as we lived nearby at the time. I remember seeing Love's Labours Lost at the Open Air Theatre in the 1960's and was pleased to see that the theatre is still active.The park is very clean and well kept, an oasis in the middle of busy streets.

Lovely park in London. This will be a definite return on our next trip to London; a lovely park with plenty to see and do. The playpark at Marylebone Green appeared to be undergoing renovation so we walked further round to the playground at Hanover Gate which was a lovely walk past the boating lake.The weather wasn't great, bitterly cold and began to rain so the Boathouse Cafe was a welcome sight and worth a visit for a scone and a hot chocolate! Great views from the cafe and no doubt would be lovely in the summer months. Would also be a great spot for a picnic!

A large and well kept park with its own special character. Regent's Park has a different character to the other large London parks. Like the others, it is large and well kept, perhaps busiest at the south side where access from public transport is easiest. If you are approaching from Baker Street then it is possible to get into the park and have a short walk and still get away from it all, if time is pressing.If time is not so pressing then exploring the entire park could take several hours. The Open Air Theatre is well worth visiting and unique in London.
Lovely Inner city space. The walk through the park to the zoo the bike hire and the space green green green in central london so much going on
Lovely green space. This place is lovely in the summer, it gets crowded but there is still plenty of space for a picnic.
Open Air theatre performance was magical. We saw a turn by the Jersey Boys which happens to be one of our all time favourite musicals and then Jamie Cullum who was brilliant

Forgot we were in the capital city. We visited this beautiful park recently while we were in London to see a show. Our hotel was opposite the park so we took the opportunity to go for a late afternoon / early evening stroll.There was a slight covering of snow which made the area seem even more pretty. The pathways are neatly laid out with perfectly manicured planted wide boarders. Even during this winter period, the paths and boarders were teeming with plants and shrubbery.This is a true oasis in the middle of a big city. As you wander further into the park, the traffic noises and hustle and bustle just fade away.Look forward to returning here, maybe for a picnic, in the summer when we do a couple of days break with the kids.
if the weather is nice take some time to relax here. after visiting the town you must rake some time to relax here with a basket full of thinges tha make a picknick a Britisch pleasure

The best park in London. Regent's Park is a wonder. It has something for everyone, from the central lake and bandstand to the open air theatre in summer and of course the boating pool, the ducks and geese and miles of walks in some of the loveliest surroundings in London. My favourite place!

The nicest Park. We thought this was the nicest park to wander around of all the London Parks.Perhaps because it was away from Buck House and so fewer people .Zoo next door as well,if into Zoos or have small people to visit with.

Can't wait to go when the flowers are in bloom!. With the gardens, outdoor theater, zoo, and many walking paths, what's not to love about this park? I went in the winter, but will return many times in the spring and summer to see the flowers!

Great place to relax. Whenever you will go there it is always a great place to relax and empty you mind.Do not expect much like 100 different kinds of flowers etc. but it is big enough to have a lovely walk for hours.
Frenchie Walkies. Go here every month to meet other French Bulldog owners. Amazing park, awesome location, kept clean and tidy. Perfect for walking dogs as space to play/run.

Relaxing and Peaceful. It was hard to believe we were in London whilst walking around Regent's Park, it felt like we were out in the countryside! Unfortuntely it was a gloomy and rainy day for us, but we can just imagine how wonderful this park would be on a dry/sunny day. Plenty going on with joggers, dog walkers, tennis, football and various cafes dotted around to stop for drinks or a snack, but the park is so large there was plenty of space for everyone to enjoy.

The art exhibition was missable but the gardens are not. We were interested in attendign an art exhibition in Regent's Park but belive the entry fee (with little explanation of what we would see) rather a shock. So we walked in the gardens - and what a delight they were. During summer I can see them becoming a regular feature of our weekends.
Regents Park.. Nice place to visit to have a walk and get away from the crowds,would go again sometime.The weather was not ghreat the day I went,but if you can ut that to one side it was good

Best park in London. For those who likes real gardens and wants to enjoy a real countryside experience in central London, this is the place.
I truly recommend hiring a bike and follow the marked itineraries.

Peaceful in winter. l have been to Regent park before in summer and it was very beautiful. This time l just crossed it to go to Camden Lock.It looked so peaceful and mysterious under the grey sky !The lake was full of birds and a lot of squirrels were around.

My favourite park in London. Great park for running - so much to see. It is a community park for those who live near. See children playing cricket, young people playing soccer and LOTS of people walking their dogs. Rent a Barclay bike or walk through it to get the full experience.
Regent's Park. Loved seeing all those roses in bloom! You can actually rent a deckchair and stay amidst these beautiful flowers

nice park. in a middle of london it is a park which is posher than others, there is nice attraction there a zoo and flowers and very nice people
just beautiful
Lovely. Great place to go for a stroll or a run in the warm weather. This place is very big and most times has some sort of show going on.

Expansive and something for everyone. We love the ponds, the playgrounds, the cafes, the zoo. Having a picnic. Having a wander. It's easy to get turned around though and parking is steep. Easily accessed by plenty of buses.
Well Maintained. This Park used to be a hunting ground for Kings and you can certainly feel that when you stroll through the park, beautiful surroundings and right near London Zoo.

Magnificent. One of the most spectacular places i have Been
Very good room size
Nice deco & art pieces
Very good location

Well kept, peaceful park.. As title.Pretty area, good open green space. Contrasts nicely with the metaphorical concrete jungle surrounding the park.Allow around half an hour to walk from one side to the other at a slow/moderate pace. You could walk it quicker, but then you won't have time to take it all in.A couple of places to get a light bite. Not much cover should you get caught in the middle when it rains. If the weather looks threatening, take an umbrella.

Gorgeous in Autumn with the leaves. I loved walking through Regent's Park, all the leaves were falling from the trees, the manicured gardens were just exquisite. So much colour! i'd love to see it in Summer!
Lovely!. Lovely, huge park! I would imagine it must be even nicer in the summer. Great for morning walks, jogging, just spending time or having a picnic.
Regent's Park. One of London's greatest parks! Great way to spend a couple of hours after a shopping spree on Oxford Street or after a visit to the Sherlock Museum on Baker Street

Great Picnic Spot!. Once the hunting grounds of kings, Regent's Park now welcomes visitors (and even ghastly Americans!) and is a perfect spot for a picnic as we enjoyed on our last visit. Lots of space to get lost if you prefer to do so.
:o). extremely beautiful park, very well kept with lots of decorative gardens, definitely worth making the time to visit

Beautiful, but not the best of London. It's definitely a beautiful place, but if you are going to London you must enjoy Hyde Park, St. James Park and Green Park. I went to Regent's because I Already knew the other parks and it was cute, I was almost on winter and the grass was beautifully iced, and also the water bodies where the birds walked over the ice giving the park a nice touch.
A nice walk. A very nice way to spend an hour or so in a big city. You can walk all the way round, looking at the wildlife and birdlife, the flowers and trees and the people.

A very special Park. Do go in late May to early July, when the world-famous Rose Garden is at it's best. Take a gamble on the weather staying fine to see a Shakespeare Play in the middle of the Park.If you are fit, walk up the hill. out of Central London, to see Primrose Hill, with fantastic views back over Central London, then maybe look up the legends of the Druids in nearby Parliament Hill Fields, or rent a rowboat, on the lake.Also, walk to the top end of the Park, to enter London Zoo, or take the guided canal boat through to Little Venice, or to Camden Market.If you are not super fit, bring plenty of stale bread, and feed the massed throngs of Ducks, Geese, and Swans who will assemble at the lake.

Regent's Park in Autumn time. Beautiful, peaceful park, great colours.We had a nice walk not at weekend time. It was quite empty. It is a short walk from Camden market. Hard to believeit is in the centre of London.Don't miss this oasis!!
A great place to relax. Regent's park is a green oasis in bustling London. It is great to come here during lunch time on a sunny day.
A beautiful park for a walk on a sunny day. One of London's beautiful parks, Regent's Park is a very pleasant place to spend a few hours on a sunny day.

One of favorite places in London. Love this park. The walkways around the lagoon are gorgeous. You'll enjoy the landscaping and waterfowl. The zoo was fun with adorable little monkeys running free--quite unusual. Soccer and cricket matches were going on all over. It was a pleasure to see a park in use by locals enjoying their weekend, a nice contrast to other parks where you'll see as many tourists as locals. This is a huge area, though, so plan ahead as to what you want to see and which gate is the most convenient to enter.

Autumn, leaves change the colours, nothing to explain much.. If you love the park, the quite atmosphere, people-watch and fountain. This is the place. Not a picnic park but wood chairs are around. My sister loves it so much she went there two days in a row just to take a photos.

An oasis in the city. The calm, the tidy and orderly layout, the squirrels which are so tame they'll run up your arm for a tidbit, and the relaxed atmosphere. if you are lucky you may be able to see the wolves in the zoo's outdoor enclosure which abuts the park. In fact, when last we visited the zoo, we had a good view of the wolves from the park but could not see them at all from inside the zoo!

My favourite park in London. Vast and green, You can hire out pedalo's for a very reasonable price. Feed the ducks, lounge by the band stand, watch a football match or play at the park.Make sure you visit Primrose Hill, it has a fantastic view of London and some nice pubs/restaurants.

Great View. Great Park. It is amazing that this huge park exists in the center of London. The park is picturesque and huge. We had a quick picnic here when we were visiting the Maddame Taussaud's museum. The park is a short walk from the museum.I will highly recommend this park.

Chilled afternoons in the sun. Wine, cheese, grass between the toes, beautiful company. Always so much going on. Even when it is covered in snow it is just so beautiful. One of the great parks of the world.

ZOO is here. Lovely Park - with the Zoo to the north side - nice for a chillout and breather away from the madness of london!! If you go into the zoo go to the Rain Forest bit - it is very educational - and even i found out things i knew nothing about - good for grownups and even better for kids I expected the overall zoo to be better (ie more animals) - but i suppose they are not as popular as once upon a time and possibly a thing of the past one day!!ANyway back to the park - another lovely green space in london!!

Escape from the hustle & bustle of the city. We went to the park for a couple of hours on a summer's afternoon to have some peace & quiet & to walk the dog. We parked along the side of the road at a parking meter as we didn't want to take the dog on the tube. The parking for the meter was £2.40 per hour (August 2012 prices) so expensive if you want to stay in the park for more than a couple of hours.The park has plenty of space to roam in & it is great for walking dogs or for children to run around in. There is quite a big lake in the park with loads of ducks on, so a lovely pastime for small children. Watch out for the herons, they are as tame as the ducks & we couldn't get over how close to them you could actually get.We walked along the back of the zoo & could see a couple of meerkats in their enclosure.........a great free way to compare the meerkat!

A great park. Easy to access from many tube stations - there's a different feel in different areas so walk / cycle around and experience as much as you can. There are 'Boris Bike' stands here as well.

Been there several times. With relatives living close to this beautiful park, we'we been there several times. Nice for a walk when tired of a busy/noisy town (but when tired of London, you're probably tired of life!). North is the area of St. John's Wood - visit the Highstreet for great shopping! South is Madame Tussaud's - also worth visiting!

Very relaxing but gets dull quickly. Regent park is quite beautiful, very tranquil, very peaceful - signs weren't very good there and while it is a great place to just relax, take long walks, eat lunch etc. but it gets very boring very quickly and if you have you kids expect none of the aforementioned peace and quite. Nice place to go if you're near by but nothing too spectacular.
Relaxing. Lovely to walk about in-view the Zoo animals.A good time to go is when the roses are out in the Queen Mary Rose Garden-heavenly smell!

Fab park especially on a sunday. This is a superb place to visit especially on a sunday so much going on. Teams playing football, american football, baseball etc. loads of sights especially various sights jogging in all manner of shapes and sizes lol! Lovely fountains, gardens and bird life of the feathered kind.

Great For Tourists And Locals Alike. Enjoyed a very nice stroll around Regent's Park which, although we live less than an hour's travel away, we hadn't done before. It's a stone's throw from Baker Street tube station, and you quickly become detached from the hustle and bustle of London and enter leafy green surroundings. We did more or less a full circuit of the place, taking in the boating lake (nice little café there by the water's edge), and Primrose Hill, which is well worth the climb to the top, where there are superb views of Central London with the usual landmarks. There are plenty of places to stop off, have a drink and watch the world go by. The Zoo is also very handy if this is your thing. We liked it so much we came back a week later and made a slight variation by walking along the Regent's Canal which skirts the northern edge of the Park. This area is highly recommended on a fine sunny day, especially if you're staying in the West End and want to "get away from it all" for an hour or two.

A lovely park to wander round in the sun. Regent's Park is a lovely park to both walk round and sunbathe in. It is very well cared for and well used. There are beautiful manicured areas for photos and great expanses of grass to sit on.Lovely when the weather is good.

Nice Space. Regent's Park filled a gap in our tour itinerary in between Abbey Road and Madam Tussauds. And it was a pleasant diversion!I suppose that I expected London parks to be regal and Regent's Park didn't disappoint with all of the expected inclusions like lakes, streams. pedal boats, row boats, manicured lawns, deck chairs and the proverbial pigeons and ducks. It helped that we enjoyed brilliant sunshine and no crowds - almost good enough to enjoy the deck chair and watch the world go by!A relaxing experience before the clamour of Madam Tussauds!

Great for the day. Beautiful park. The Queen's Gardens are very nice. Lots of squirrels and birds, vast green areas. Lots of peace.The London Zoo is at one end of this park. We walked to the Zoo from across the park, but the distance between signs is misleading. At several points we arrived at forks and didn't know which way to go.If you're going to walk from one point to another in/around the park, make sure you navigate properly. Suggest you use the offline Trip Advisor Guide to London and let it help you.

Another of London's fantastic parks. London is blessed with fantastic parks and this is no exception. Direct access from here to London Zoo it also has an open air theatre. With good weather, this is a great location fo a family day out with a picnic.

Great park. Paved trails weave through vast open greens, stunning rose gardens, open air theatres, boating lakes, and even a zoo. And with all of the football, rugby and frisbee that is being played, inspiration is readily available.I'm not quite sure how a park can make running romantic, but this is certainly the case at Regent's Park. I most enjoy coming in the early mornings when I feel I'm a part of a secret runners society -- puffs of breath can be seen beckoning each fellow runner's anticipated step, and it seems that the park was built just for us. Perfect for a 6 or 8k jog, there is something amusing to stare at around every turn which makes the time fly. Just be aware of this running euphoria or before you know it, it will backfire with a nasty stress fracture from all that pavement pounding. Nothing romantic about that, now is there?
Hard to believe was once "outside" London. Now in middle of ceentral London. Great oasis with green spaces and away from traffic and hustle of museums, palaces, etc.
regents park. had some great days in the park,walking running,swimming,watching the horses,the zoo,great chinness on the canal next to the zoo entrance,

A park which can surprise. Regents Park sits between the Euston Road and the Regents canal. At the north of the park is London Zoo. It is also the location of one of the largest Mosques in London. With several lakes and the usual swans, ducks, moorhens and coots, it is great place for families to picnic or play games, particularly of spring and summer weekends.

Outdoor Theatre. See a play in the open air theatre in the park and book a barbecue with your ticket or have a picnic on the lawns nearby. Look out for Jazz concerts at th bandstand near the boating lake, the Zoo and ducks in the pond. Something for everyone in deklightful surroundings.
Regent's Park:. Nice green park. Hoping to visit it again next time I am in theUK. We in Uganda are also working hard to get green spaces
Don't miss this one!. Enchanting laid-back atmosphere and very nice look. Not to mention the numerous Fat Hens (woodpigeons) providing high-quality free entertainment.

My favorite park. While all the royal parks are worth visiting, Regents Park is certainly my favorite. This park is full of beautiful flowers, often hidden in romantic inlets. When the sun shines there is no better place to visit and relax with friends and a glass of wine. Reagents park is a must!
The biggest one!. Calm and quiet park, the biggest of the city, in the Spring there are many flowers. A nice place for the kids, for a rest or a sandwich on the grass

Regents Park - A "must". Regents park is just "out of town" but so worth a visit.So much space. A wonderful zoo. Plasces to eat. Places to walk.Worth a good 1/2 day - where the pace can be a little less than in central "town".

Fabulous Green Space in London. I love this park, one of my favorite in London. The gardens are beautiful and it is a great place to relax or have a picnic. I enjoy the layout of the park and proximity to the Zoo.
Beautiful Place to Run. Had a blast running through this park while staying in Euston Square. Beautifully manicured, but crowded on weekends

Beautiful park for a weekend stroll with family. Whether you have a picnic here, play 5 a side football, visit London Zoo or just have a stroll with family - this is a great setting and you're not far Marylebone for a well-earned lunch afterwards.
a very nice park. Most parks in London are very nice, it's good to see so much green in London. Every park has it's own specific special flowers etc.

An oasis, and do visit the Garden Cafe. We had such a nice walk in Regent park after visiting Mme Tussaud, you can hire boats or just strall around, many birds, swans ect. quiet atmosphere and beatiful scenery, and we had lunch at the Garden cafe. They had excellent food and the best service you could imagine, do go there, I truly recommend it!

Beautiful park. We had some spare time on a recent trip to London. We tried to get in Madame Tussauds but it was a very long queue of 2 hours and so we popped round the corner to Regents Park. Absolutely beautiful. the gardens with the roses and ponds are wonderful. It was even better because the sun was out, but there are so many wonderful elements to this park and of course the zoo.Make time to go!

Simply wonderful with children. A very wonderful park - very nice to stroll around or to picnic.It is great to walk along the Regent Canal, to let the children enjoy the space, and to have a hot dog and ice cream at the Honest Sausage.
tranquillity in the heart of London. Lovely open spaces, Zoo, boating lake and formal gardens all in the heart of London. What more could you want!

Best family day out in London. What a great place to take the family for a free day out. Providing the weather is nice it's a great day out. Excellent amenities. Great play areas, nice gardens, brilliant boating lake including one for little kids. Plenty of paces to eat and drink. Best park in London.

Regent's Park. From all of the parks I have been to this is my favourite. You are in the city centre and you feel like you are in some calm and beautiful place. The gardens are simply gorgeous in different forms, it's a pleasure to be there. I only regret that I couldn't gone to the zoo, because it was closed when I was in the park.

My favourite Park in London. Maybe as I work near and visit it a lot but the flowers are beautiful along with the ducks and swans and it's a great park to run in as well as picnic. A good running route is to head to the London zoo side and run up Primrose Hill, it's a killer but a good workout!

Go to the theatre here. It's magical!. On recent years the theatre at Regents Park has become known for to excellent standard of their productions, which are always fun and magnificently staged. It's a proper outdoor theatre, with comfy seats. At least one recent production has transferred to the West End -these are great productions which use the setting and gathering darkness to great effect. I've seen both Ragtime and Midsummer Night's Dream this season and they were both terrific. Take a jumper, a blanket for your knees and a raincoat, just in case. If the play is totally rained off, you get a ticket for another night. There is a hog roast and a bar. You will never forget seeing a show here. I'd particularly recommend MND this season, but it would is a bit racy for small children. The set transformed incredibly... A great evening out.

Great kids area. Went to the Hanover gate adventure playground near the boating lake with my children and they loved it! Lots of things to climb and a great and clean sandpit. The boating lake was also nice as we could see ducks and wildlife etc. one of London's best parks!!
Brief visit before visiting the Zoo. We saw the park only briefly enroute to the Zoo. It looked lovely idyllic and green with lots of areas to walk in. Nice place for a picnic and to relax.

Got Wet. Decided to go Wenlock hunting in Regents park part of the the Stroll series for the olympics.Got half way round and the heavens open and had to abandon the rest of the walk.However will definately return so quiet and peaceful and the wildlife just bimble past you as though your not there so you can get very close to them.The squirrels are great if you stand still they will wander around you not frightened in the least or look at you from head height from one of the many trees.For a tranquill location must give it a go and for a bit of fun hunt the wenlock or Mandevilles spread around the park for the olympics

Has it all. Wide green vista where you feel you are out in the country, tailored avenues with formal rose beds exploding with color, fountains, lakes with ducks and geese, an outdoor Shakespeare theatre, a zoo, a paddle boat pond, canals, wandering paths through leafy woodlands, it's so many parks in one. I ran here most days on my recent trip to London. I'd move to the city just for this park.

Lovely place for a calm wander. This park is one of my favourites in London. There are lots of gardens to admire and plenty of areas to find a tree and watch the world go by. As soon as you wander off the main paths it can be suprisingly quiet for the centre of London (until you hear one of the Lions in the nearby zoo roaring). If you're in the area it's definatetly worth a visit....
Great wildlife. A lovely park to wander and observe the different types of wildlife. Wear comfy shoes, it is bigger than it looks.

Tennis Courts and Row Boats and Music Oh, My!!!. Near Regent's Park you will be thrilled to find the following wonderful places to visit: Madam Tussaud's wax works, The London Zoo, and the Wallace Collection. In the park Queen Mary's gardens with so many beautiful roses it takes your breath away. In summer the open air Shakespear theatre and the Park Cafe'. There are several nice cafes in the park and a band stand for lovely music in the warm months.

Lovely walks on a nice summer day. This is a little outside the usual tourist stops, but if you have the time, it's a good break from museums. There's a zoo, fields for sports and so on, but I like the top of the park, where you can walk along the canals. In fact, you can go for quite a while. Just above, and connecting to the park is Primrose Hill, where you can get beautiful views. Right off Primrose Hill, you'll get to a 4 or 5 block crescent street with small, casual, but very nice cafes and shops.

'A Mid-Summer Night's Dream'. I saw on the television this week that there will be open-air performances of Shakespeare's 'A Mid-Summer Night's Dream' on at Regent's Park, London during the Olympic Games season. In the summer of 1946 (that's right), my parents took me to see the same open-air production at Regent's Park. It was unforgettable and I strongly recommend parents visiting London to take their children for an experience they will remember throughout their life. Needless to say, the adults will enjoy themselves too. When we went we were accommodated on chairs placed on the ground. I think seating arrangements are such these days that more people are provided for. Interestingly, unknown to us a photograph of us had been sent to a newspaper in Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) which had published it with the caption 'Indian family at open-air play in Regent's Park'. (I am marking that our visit was in August 2011 since 1946 is not provided for!)
Calm. If you like going to gardens this is a lovely one to see.

Large, well designed and very well maintained.. One of the real delights about Regent's is that if you keep exploring you will find a new little treat around the each corner, from gardens, to ponds, to fountains, to sculptures. The key features to see would be the Hub, Queen Mary's Rose Gardens, the Inner Circle and the Avenue Gardens. The park is a runner's paradise with constantly changing scenery and easy ways to navagate. Sportsman abound everywhere. The gardens are well manicured and there are multiple features to see throughout the park. The cafes are nice, and I especially liked the one at the Hub and the Honest Sausage. You can catch a play at the open theater if your timing is good. Don't miss the chance to see neighboring Primrose Hill for the best natural view of London in the city, by my opinion. There are two institutions that are located on the grounds, Regent's College (a private college) and the LZS Zoo for a look at some wildlife. Not quite the scale of New York's Central Park (Hyde would be closer), but well worth a Sat. afternoon stoll.

Perfect running spot. Located about 10 min run from my hotel, this was the perfect park for a nice morning run. Well groomed park with a ton of small walkways where the Londoners walk with their dogs or take their Sunday run. There are beautiful flower areas as well as a lake we plenty of birds and small bridges where you can cross. Would also recommend if you just want to go and relax from a busy London for an hour or two.

My favorite park in London. My second visit here was during an extraordinary run of sunny warm weather in April no less. The park is beautiful and a fun place to wander. The bathrooms (always a concern for the traveler) were pristine.

green and flowered, birds every where. you feel you left London and walk in english country side. Flowers are just superb and the birds very friendly. a paradise with kids after a visit. don't forget to bring few bread to feed the ducks...it's permitted

beautiful flowers. Been there many times have lunch in the garden cafe and go for a walk and admire all the beautiful flowers specially the roses and the perfume around you, hopefully the weather will improve.
Wonderful Rose Gardens. Don't miss the Queen's Gardens in the Inner Circle. Its a huge rose garden that is absolutely gorgeous rain or shine.
Lovely park. A great park to walk through, very pretty and relaxing. we walked across to London zoo, we were very lucky with the weather, the boathouse cafe was a welcome stop!
great day out. lovely place to go.need a nice day.very relaxing.very busy traffic though

Perfect for a stroll and picnic. What better to do on a warm sunny day than pack a picnic and go for a stroll around Regents park. Boating lake and cafe help keep people entertained and fed. In the Summer they have a number of events such as taste of london and also have an open air theatre. Be sure to use a search engine to keep a track of the events going on.

Beautiful rose gardens. On a recent visit to London we visited Regent's Park. The day was wet and gloomy but the roses in Queen Mary's Garden were blooming and absolutely beautiful. We had a snack at the cafe near the tennis courts which was tasty and reasonably priced and we did not have to wait unlike at the other cafe nearby. Unfortunately due to the inclement weather we have deferred exploring the park further. That and a visit to the zoo will have to wait until the next time we are in London.

For flower lovers. Regent's Park is my favourite London park. The Avenue and Jubilee gardens are highly recommended to those that love flowers. And those come in addition to the wonderful rose garden, which is right next to a duck pond. You can spend ages here walking, having a picnic on the grass or watching the birds. There is also a boating lake, an open-air theatre, a canteen/restaurant/bar, playing fields, a children's playground and London Zoo. You can also see some expensive property inside the park. Very pleasant on a sunny day and more quiet on a rainy day. Enjoy!

Elegant, beautiful gardens. This is a wonderful visit year round. Something is always in bloom. Of course it is best in the Spring, especially May. Nice cafe in the garden. Great for macro photography of the blooms.

excellent. Went on a girly weekend with three friends and stayed in a hotel near the park. Albeit was late in the year it was a lovely day and we walked through the park, stopped and had a bite to eat and a drink and sat on a bench and watched the world pass by and carried on strolling through. We were really pleased at all we saw.

Beautiful. The regents park is a beautiful park with lots of gardens. Plan for time and enjoy the tranquility of surrounds which in middle of London is amazing. Be prepared for long walks as the park is huge!

2012 Taste of London festival in Regent's park is as good as always. The lovely surroundings of Regent's park forms the perfect setting for London's biggest foodies festival. We've been to the festival for the past 5 years and I'm happy to report that the selection of restaurants and dishes is still as good as ever. Some of London's best restaurants are on display and it shows. For me the stand-out dishes this year were: - Le Gavroche: braised beef cheeks, with olives and creamy polenta- Barbecoa: Pit Beef, Smoky Baked Beans- Pollen Street Social: White chocolate and coconut panna cotta with mango, kaffir lime, pineapple and pistachio oil - Gelupo's icecream
Beautiful kept park. Very well maintained (almost immaculate actually) park / gardens. Lovely for a walk or a picnic, before or after shopping.

One of the best city parks anywhere. London parks are always incredible. This one is just so beautiful with so many varied paths and environments. The flower gardens in particular were immaculate when I was there. Just stunning.

BEAUTIFUL GARDENS. Went for a walk in this beautiful park. More then a 100 different varities of roses. The lake is beautiful with a wide variety of fauna. Went there on a beautiful sunshine day and enjoyed every minute off it. And it is free.
