My favorite in London. This is my favorite park in London, lot's of fauna, a beautiful rose garden, several facilities to make your visit more comfortable, a nice lake, several artistic chairs. Just perfect!
Fantastic Park. Fantastic park, graet fauna & animals for kids. Enjoying eveytime I go there.

Queen Mary's rose gardens in mid-summer, beautiful. We are very fond of this place, especially the rose gardens, a visit here mid-summer is very nice and quite romantic. The scent on the air is something else indeed from the 100s of different varities of roses and it is a joy walking along taking in deep lungfulls of scent from individual blooms, ambling along the many paths admiring their beauty, or taking the weight off and relaxing on one of the many benches, or perhaps tea and cake in the cafe... :-) If in London during mid-summer this is something you must try to experience at least once.
Great place for a run. early spring morning, nobody around, just the birds, insects and animals in the zoo for company. Perfect place to run away from cars.
Strolling along!. Great park which is amazing in the summer, look out for the outdoor concerts and plays that are often put on.

relax. Sit down, chill out, have a picnic, unwind, sunbathe (if your lucky), read a book and enjoy the beautiful surroundings of this lovely park. Considering its in the middle of London its a very quiet and relaxing place to be.
Park your self and recharge.. Need to unwind, pop into St James and do just that. Lovely park for a stroll or a run.
zoo in the park. its a place you want to come again and again theres a boating lake and in the summer they put on open air concerts. easy to get there buses and the tub go there
good nothing exciting. bit boring to be honest but very good for the alder people not young kids
Lovely place to relax. Its a great place just to chill out with friends and have a picnic. Its also a great place to walk dogs and go for a run.
A WELCOME 'LUNG' IN LONDON.. This provides a great opportunity to get away from the hustle and bustle of London traffic.

Love this park. Expected busy busy as its half term, but it was quiet. My children had freedom because it was quiet enough that I could see them and the play area (which is lovely) was empty- there were literally about half a dozen other kids in there. Even my 11 yr old enjoyed the play area, which is saying something as most are not challenging for older kids. Used the cafe by the boating lake and thought the prices were very reasonable for coffee and ice lollies, especially considering we were in London. Toilet facilities are good for a park, and there are plenty of clear maps everywhere - although I do always manage to get lost in Regents Park - doesnt stop me loving it though! I have been on much busier days too and it is always good, its big enough that you can always find space somewhere.

Lovely gardens fantastic walks. A delightful and pleasant experience. Lovely flowers and shrubs on display ideal for wheelchairs and buggies to get around. I would like to see dogs kept on leads and more visable security.

A great park. I had a lot of fun in this park. It's clean and organized. There's plenty of space and shade, so even in its crowdy days you can find a spot of your own.The park is beautiful and is the home of many birds and animals. The lakes are beautiful and the park is a great way to spend an afternoon with a book, or just chilling with friends and family.

A nice clean park. This is the best , clean , quite park in London! There are many different stlye gardens ...and a great walk .. In the winter they hold a big event ....called winter wonderland witch is great !

Most Relaxing Place in London. Regent's Park is probably the best park in London. There are vast, wide-open green spaces where you can see people playing at least a dozen sports. The ponds and canals are full of waterfowl. Overall is it a very peaceful place and a great place to go to unwind from a crazy day.

Kids Love It. Not only kids but grown up kids do too! It is beautiful in the spring and summer. Our hotel was very close and we could see bits of it from our room. It is a hard day to see and do here. There are many vistas with resting places. All the facilities here so you can make the most of your time and be able to "see everything".
Good for a relaxing stroll. Worth a visit. Also take a look at the surrounding architecture

Great place for a walk. Beautiful park near central London and a great day out for the whole family.It has a big pond full of duck and swan which you can feed. You can also rent a paddling boat to ride around in the same pond, a bit on the expensive side. There is a cafe next to this which again is on the expensive side.You can also play football etc... On the open green spaces, I have also seen a few tennis courts which must be rented. There is also a children’s activity playground which includes a couple of swings and slides, a sand play area and little toilets for small children.There are many beautiful flowers and flower beds within the inner circle which is separated by big circle road in the middle of the park.The best thing is to bring your own picnic and a blanket and just enjoy the park with all the green spaces available and chill out with a glass of wine.Parking is available all around the park including the outer circle as well as the inner circle and just a note that is paid for even on the weekends. If you drive out of the park on to local roads parking is free during the weekend if somewhat hard to come by then a few minutes walk back into the park.

Great place to chill out and relax. London is full of many wonderful parks, Hyde is great but Regent's takes the prize as the best park to relax and explore. From children playing or watching a football match or just getting away from the city life, Regents offers everyone a little something. From a rainy day stroll to a sunshine drenched walk, make sure you spend some time at Regents and enjoy it's beauty.

Beautiful. I am currently studying here and it is absolutely beautiful. There are people everywhere you turn. It is amazing how so many people are active in London. It is a big change from being in the United States where most people's thought of exercise is walking to the mailbox. It is clean and there are so many things to do -- there's a theatre, a cafe, and so much space for activities or to lay out on a blanket, or sit on a bench and read. It is huge though, so be careful -- but there are maps in case you get lost. Definitely worth a trip to see. It is absolutely gorgeous and the gardens are magnificent.
Beautiful Park. Regent's Park is a beautiful park to walk through and around. It is really peaceful and an easy walk.

Lovely open space near the heart of the city.. A welcome relief to the hustle and bustle of the city but near enough for a short visit. We had a young child with us who was less interested in sightseeing than the rest of our party so it was nice to find a playground to let him have some fun.

Getting away from the city for a bit.. One of London's famous parks...works for me, even on a cold February day. With the sunshine "on": a wonderful way to get a little break from the busy city. Quite a few "things" go on there as well - their open air theatre is really worth it, check to see that what is showing is "your cup of tea" - it is also the home to the "London" part of the London Zoo(logical) Society. (See seperate listing) (I will leave you to find out where else the "London Zoo" is - hint: not in London, and yes, that is worth a trip.) too

Beautiful park. Cleanliness, greenery, everything. It is big and beautiful, you can find plenty of fun especially if you take your children, and the zoo is there. The lake with swans and ducks, educational centre for pupils, the open air theatre, and many more... I doubt that there is any city in the world that has a park like this one.

Roses are everywhere ....... Going to London will not be complete without visiting Regent's Park .... roses are everywhere particularly in mid Summer. There are ducks and swans in the lake; there are benches in the sun and under the tree for visitors to sit in peace. There are everything you need ... it's just captivating.

Refreshing. Yes, it's "just" a park, but how peaceful it was! It's not packed, and you can relax without lots of people around. The gardens are beautiful, the lake and the ducks give it a nice touch, the bathrooms are clean and the café is small but nice. Don't miss it!

Nice walk. Beautiful park with a nice walk. It looks like you can go paddle boating on the lake, and the Zoo is right in the park! We were just passing through the park and we walked by the Giraffe enclosure without having to enter the zoo.

Have a nice quiet moment in London. To let the soul rest a little bit, take a walk in the park, and see the statues and waterfountans in Regents park, we do it every time we visit and its great.The squirrels are really friendly, as well as all the dogs that runs free, and we didnt see any dogs at all getting angry on eachother.No food for sale, so bring something to eat, but leave the litter in the bins, so it is clean as you found it.

Escape from the city. Regent's Park is in the middle of the city but allows you to have a break from it. Queen Elizabet Gardens are always well manicured (no matter the season) so go for a bug walk, look at the flowers and feel good. The lakeside is also wonderful and deserves a cone of ice cream to go with it.

Beautiful Park. Regents Parks is wonderful, a sanctuary to escape to away from the hustle and bustle of London. The Rose Garden, in the Inner Circle, is especially beautiful & restful - it is exceptionally well maintained. As well as the famous Rose Garden, with a wide variety of Roses, the rest of the Inner Circle has been beautifully landscaped with many species of flower beds, waterfall and fountain. There are lots of lovely spots to have picnics. The Cafeteria and restaurant are okay - not great, but handy for a soft drinks / ice cream for the kids, sandwiches etc. Queen Mary's Garden is also lovely, it is in the OUTER circle, there are lots of benches to sit on, rest and relax. There are areas in the outer circle to play football, frisbee etc. ( no ball games allowed in the Inner Circle). During the summer the bandstand plays music most afternoons and there is a boating lake. The Outdoor Theatre is virtually all Shakespeare plays, when the weather is good it gets completely sold out - so always best to book in advance. The Theatre is lovely, nice food and a great buzz... albeit a bit too busy for my liking. It's nice to take your own picnic. It's best to get there using public transport - there isn't a lot of parking, however if you must go by car - then make sure you 'pay & display' as the wardens are pretty vigilant and parking is expensive.

A right royal park. I love all the royal parks in London. Each one is special in some way. Regents Park is special for the Nash Terraces around it . . . It was a speculative property development which went bust in the early 19th century, or there would be more terraces and villas. The rose garden is out of this world in the spring. There are big public spaces and smaller spaces for lovers. Great for people watching.

Beautiful walk in the twilight. Regents park is always a good place to wander and you may even hear the animals from the zoo as you walk by in the evening. Easy to walk from Primrose Hill to Marylebone road.. even Regents Street!

Spectacular. It was amazing to walk along the trails in such a beautiful park and stroll to the lake. I had just finished reading my Grandfather's memoirs of his time as a soldier for the Canadian Scottish Regiment in WWI and he described how he and his brother took a row boat for a spin at Regent's park. Being able to do that as well was so special. What a magical place!

Amazing space in the middle of a huge city. London amazes me with its dedication to open, accessible green spaces. Regent park is a delight. Lots of open space, good bathroom facilities that are clean and felt safe. Lots of wildlife, swans on nests, and coots galore. Beautiful well kept gardens. We went twice and just loved it. When you are in the park it is remarkably removed from the city bustle.
Lovely park. Lovely park to wander around and forget you're in the middle of a city. Good birdlife to watch and plenty of benches hiding away to relax on and read a book.

boat ride for families. we had a fantastic time on Sat afternoon going on a pedalling boat in Regents Park. our kids did all the hard work of exercising their legs whilst my husband and I appreciated the lovely weather and views of the park! £20 well spent!
Regent's Park. It is a nice park in the centre of London, but it gets very busy when the sun comes out and it can be difficult to find somewhere quiet to sit.
Its really Grand. Go to the open Air theatre after yoy can walk to the canal and pop to Camden. needless to say the London Zoo is worth a day out
Nice flowers. Very nice flowers, but overall I didn't quite feel safe there don't ask me why. Green Park is much prettier

best peacefulness place. its a place where i get most peace when ever i use to get bored and felt alone i use to go there as i always live in baker street which is just walking form the regents park...miss it now days but will be back soon.
beautiful park in the summer sun. beautiful park in the summer sun and a great break from the hussle bussle that London can throw at you

Large Park. Very large park with a nice area with many flowers in the middle and surrounded by huge grass fields, perfect for playing football or picnics. However, I wouldn't go there, if I would be in London for a short-visit.
nice park , but thats it ..... just a big park ,, nice if its sunny and you have time to spare
Wonderful views. It's a beautiful park, you can see wonderful landscapes (like the photo), and the London Zoo is inside this park.

Beautiful!. A must visit park in the heart of London! Includes the stunning Queen Mother's Gardens.Couple it with a visit to either London Zoo, Camden or Madame Tussauds. Start at the south side of the park - walk through and continue on to whereever!There is also a very nice eatery in the centre where you can get gorgeous real sausage hot dogs - highly recommend!

Huge Park in central London. This park is amazing, right in the centre of London, it's big and has lots to offer, people cycle round it, run, there are football pitches, rugby pitches for hire - there's a rose garden, out door theatre (season depending) and lots of cafes and public toilets.Really nice to visit if the weather is good, gets you away from the hustle and bustle of central London.
nice park. i think this is a very nice park.we all had a very good time

Take the kids!. Take the kids and visit the Zoo. It's so worth it! The animals welfare is paramount and a lot of conservation work is done here. Not too fa from Madame Tussauds and The Planetarium so fit in all 3!
Nice location. Lovely central park. Great for a quick picnic over lunch or simply a lazy stroll

Great park in a great location!. This park is great in size, very well maintained and located near Camden Town. You can have a picnic until afternoon then after dusk go to Camden Town for a couple of (more) drinks and good music! You can find out what's on in London Zoo or the open air amphitheater in the park or just walk to "Little Venice" and have a canal tour!
Beautiful Gardens. What can I say like all of the Royal Park's it has beautiful gardens and you could spend the whole day just walking around and relaxing. Take a picnic and enjoy your visit.
Best park I've seen. Amazing park. Happened to be there at a very nice day. Many things to do and see. A drawback was the London Zoo which we didn't know was so expensive, so we didn't see it.
London park. Have always enjoyed this park used to sit there Lunch Times eat sandwiches and watch the world go by
Lovely Park. This is a nice little park to pop into. Near Baker's Street station
Summer Picnic. This is just the best place for a picnic in summer. Wander up Marylebone High Street and buy all the makings of a picnic and 'voila'. Definately worth it.
A bit of green on the edge of the West End. This park has some lovely flower beds and cheeky squirrels and is a great place to waste away a sunny afternoon
Lovely park!. Great park for an afternoon stroll, a cup cake and a bit of sun
Regent's Park. A lovely park in the middle of London with great floral displays.

Go visit in the rain. We did! At first we thought we were crazy but then there were people walking around others were playing rugby, Little kids too. It's amazing to see that people arent't affraid of the rain. The park as a quiet ambience and if you get sun take the basket and do a piknik.

childhood. I used to live around the corner from this park. It is massive with many different areas. What ever you mood there is a part of the park to suit. If you are feeling down take some bread and feed the ducks, no matter you age, you will feel better.
A hidden gem. Do Discover the hidden garden in this beautiful park.

A great place for recreation and tranquility. My favourite part of Regent's park is the gardens - the flowers are almost always perfect! The rose garden is beautiful during the summer. Bring your own coffee though, the cafés aren't great. Don't miss to walk along the canal!

London's nicest park. I think this is the nicest park in London, with lots of variety. There are delightful formal and informal gardens, a lot of open parkland and some wild areas, a delightful lake on which you can take little boats, and something to see at every time of year. The rose gardens in the summrer are truly spectacular.  There are several pleasant cafes in the park, offering good value and nice food. IYou could easily spend an afternoon wandering around.   If you go to the part near the zoo you can peep through the fence and see some of the animals!  But if you are in the West End, this is within fairly easy reach and just the place to take a picnic on a summers day.

Try the Rose Garden. The large lakes and open spaces are often packed with people. For a more relaxed and calming vista I would suggest the rose garden. It has a very nice lake and lots of different wild fowl. After the rose garden, turn right after the cafe and go for a walk along the inner circle. Great open space for any time of the year.

My favourite park in London. This is a really beautiful park in London, definately my favourite. Has a real Italian feel and has some great features for kids. We enjoyed boating on the lake and strolling amongst the fountains. Also close to the zoo and Primrose Hill.

Pockets of beauty. The southern half of Regents park has some beautiful formal gardens, especially the rose garden. The lake is definitely worth a stroll around, to watch the waterfowl, and people watch too! The northern half of the park is largely given over to playing fields, which is great if you want to play sport, but is of less interest to tourists and day trippers. The park is close to central London, and makes a pleasant contrast to the hustle and bustle of the main city streets.
Zoo. The home of London Zoo which is great, take time though as its not the largest zoo in the world. try and pick a nice day as most attractions outside

Gorgeous much of the year. The best floral display in London. There's also a zoo and an open-air theatre (the best place to see Midsummer Night's Dream ever). Look for the hidden garden just outside the perimeter!
nice. nice place to have a picnic.on a nice sunny day and a nic bottle of red to go with and relax with a good book heaven.

Cosmopolitan and beautiful. This is, without doubt, one of the best parks in the country. You can also see every race in the world in it, either visitors or locals. Give a miss to the zoo, you will be disappointed, guaranteed.
Regent's Park. Lovely park in itself and there's the zoo if it interests you
A park on the north side. NIce strolling. See the zoo, beautiful gardens, the Regent's Canal and Primrose Hill. Good place to run.
A throwback to the more gentile private parks of previous centuries. A good place to stroll and picnic. A bit "manicured" and formal but worth seeing in each season as the changes manifest themselves
Peaceful. An oasis of peace and tranquillity in the middle of a bustling city.

one of the inner-city oases. The City of London is blessed with many great parks, of which this is one, inviting tourists and residents alike to come for a stroll, or to relax on the grass - yes, that's allowed - provided you catch a warm and sunny day. Lots of imposing trees offer shade when necessary - a peaceful oasis of relaxed tranquility away from the hustle and bustle of the city, and yet right in it.
Take a stroll. Not just grass, it has a beautiful rose garden, bridges over the canal and modern sculptures.
Relax and watch the world go by. wow what a place fantastic in the summer from May onwards..In London have a look in and relax....
Great park not far from central London. It has artistic exhibitions and is very well maintained.
Lovely peaceful place. We visited in October on a damp drizzly day but we sat by the lake watching the water fowl and strolled along the many paths, a must to visit on a fine summers day!

Catch an Open Air Play. The park itself feels old-fashioned - open space with formal flower beds and a rowing lake - but the Open Air Theatre hosts a variety of theatre in Summer and, if the weather is warm, it is a magical experience to sit under the stars hearing the lions roaring from the nearby London Zoo whilst watching "A Midsummer Night's Dream".

Vast, varied beautiful park - full of wildlife. Regent's Park, London is a wonderful world all its own. I can't believe that such a vast, varied and breath-takingly beautiful oasis of serenity exists within the heart of one of the busiest cities on Earth. Also it is full of wildlife, particularly wild birds. I've only seen a corner of it and I am bowled over by its beauty and variety.
City Park. Peaceful haven in a bustling city. Well maintained and relaxing walks.
oasis in the heart of london. not just a park. beautifully kept with fabulous gardens and dont forget the zoo is near here.
free. The best thing about the london parks is they are free and they all have a different character.Always nice to walk through the parks as a cut through

WE LOVE THIS PARK. Whenever we go to London, we always stay near Regents Park, we simply love it there. Beautiful gardens, masses of roses, and quite peaceful. We always feel safe as there are police and rangers on patrol. Plenty of places to eat, and great for a picnic. London Zoo is there, and if you walk north you will be on Regents Canal in no time, and you can walk for miles along the tow path.Spend the day here! Wonderful!
Something for everyone. Well worth a trip as there is everything from sunbathing spots to manicured gardens to football pitches

Beautiful and Refreshing City Park. Look for the Rose Garden when the season is right as the roses look and smell lovely. There's also lovely bird life here, the lakes and streams are very pretty, and very pleasant to walk around or sit and picnic by in the summer. Try going mid week as it gets busy on a sunny weekend.It's also home to the open air theatre (though its prime location doesn't always mean it has great productions!), the zoo is there and you can see a few of the less exotic animals from part of the park, and you also have some stunning houses around the park perimeter.It's a massive park though, so if your time is limited maybe enter near Baker St or Hyde Park tube stations and stick to the bit with the lake and stuff.
Lovely rose gardens.... Been here a few times. Lovely large park, you could be in the country. Best in June for the roses.

Salubrious suburbs in the City. Competes with St James' Pk as London's classiest and also possibly the trendiest.Just south of sloane Primrose Hill and west of the ever popular Camden Town.It hosts a large, friendly mosque where I once bought a wall hanging of the Kaaba and the Shahada in arabic - later to be trashed by an assinine philistine visitor.Well ensconced is Regent's College which must be the most stimulating college environment in the heart of London.Excellent for alternative health, business and languages - the free japanese classes are highly recommended.Very popular with the host of London's ethnic communities.Also hosts one of the country's most popular zoos.Various sports played and I'd personally recommend the golf lessons.I must add that I am in no way religious - just have an open mind!
a romantic walk. really lovely park thou cold when we visted so most flower beds were not at there best
Beautiful Park. Its a very beautiful park... Peaceful and green.. Love to spend time at the park.

A green oasis in the heart of the West end. The Open Air Theatre takes place here in the summer, a delight if the weather is kind. There are restaurants, and a beautiful rose garden. Lovely well maintained gardens and green spaces. It is possible to walk from here down Baker Street, to Oxford Street, and it's well known stores. Also the home of the zoo.

Loved It. We went to Regent's Park on a gloomy day and still found it beautiful. I'm also from New York and can't stand Central Park because of the crowds, but Regent's Park wasn't crowded at all (maybe because it was mid-day and mid-week). The grounds and the flowers were beautiful and it was just a wonderful way to get away from the hustle and bustle of the business and tourist areas and relax. If I lived in London I would go walking here every day!
Beautiful. It's a beautiful area to walk around. All of London has fanastic parks and gardens and this is one of them. Not two look alike so you do want to find the time to see them all.
Fave park in London. Further away from the tourists, great boating lake, nice playgrounds. Primrose hill and London zoo are amazing. The Hub in summer is fun too.

Beautiful. This is one of the Royal Parks that is beautifully maintained. 400 acres of greenery in Central London is a bonus and it is divided up into many factions so that visitors dont just have one flat green space. The Rose Garden is beloved by the middle easterners; the Secret Garden (next door to the Sultan of Brunei's summer palace) is sensational. There is a wonderful vegetable and herb garden that can be visited; Queen Mary's Gardens is full of unusual plants; the Open Air Theatre regularly puts on wonderful plays and musicals. We saw "Crazy for You" there before it transferred to the West End. The lake is great for hiring a skiff and rowing up and down. It is full of migratory birds that spend their summers and winters here. Some of the varieties of ducks and geese on the lake are stunning. There is a Heronry and a tree that is a bedroom to 58 Cormorants (where do they go to during the day?) The country walk is full of wild flowers and fruits and Cricket corner is home to an apiary that produces Regent's Park honey. Only downside are the two cafes - The Honest Sausage and The Hub - both places have dreadful service and very grumpy staff. Someone please tell them that service with a smile brings in revenue. London Zoo is nearby and if you stand on the north corner pathway from the small monument, you can watch some of the animals that are roaming in their pens. You can hear lions roaring and the lemurs making their plaintive calls to one another. Its a magic place to have a picnic, stroll and enjoy some fresh air.

Best park in London!. I LOVE Regent's Park. It is by far my favorite park in London because it has everything! It has flowers, a lake, trees, benches, and lots of green space for picnics! However, if you come for a picnic make sure you get snacks elsewhere because there aren't many grocery stores close to the park! Enjoy :)

Christmas Day in Regent's Park. Due to a misunderstaning of flight times our "Christmas lunch" was a walk through Regent's Park rather than lunch with our son!What a way to spend Christmas Day: it is a beautiful park & Londoners are so fortunate to have it on their doorsteps.
Reent's Park. One of London's quieter parls, although the zoo and the canal are unique.

It's great that London has places like this. I was impressed just how much was in bloom when I strolled through Regent's Park in late Autumn. This is one of those special places where you can chill out from the urban world, up to a point. This time I walked on to Camden Market (along the canal) but there is plenty to do in the Park itself. Great to have a picnic if the weather is OK.

Stayed at hotel nearby. We stayed at a hotel nearby and I loved walking down to the park. It is beautifully landscaped. Nearby is the Beatles Museum Shop which is small but with great Beatle merchandise.
Park what else can you say about it. Park nice enough.Can get lost.Nice in the Summer.

Great place in good weather. In any season, the park is a great place to enjoy being outside, whether you are strolling through autumn leaves or walking around the lake in the spring when the young ducklings are learning to swim. The park offers acres of space and you won't feel like you are in the middle of a city of millions, you will feel out in the country.
Beautiful. My favourite park in London- especially in spring when they flowers are out.

lillian the entertainment reviewer. This is a nice park near to center London take a walk through it stop for a coffee and a cake or just sit and relax and take in the lovely gardens , then keep walking through to the end of the park turn left keep walking and you will find London Zoo and for those people who like a walk keep going and you will eventually come to Lords cricket ground .

Leisure pleasure on perfect Sunday afternoons. If it were not for the interminable queuing, we would take a boat out on the lake every sunny Sunday. It is so relaxing and time takes on a different quality as you row gently around in the water, close to the ducks and swans. They generously admit you to their world which might be just as stressful to them as our world is to us, but they serve as a wonderful metaphor for how life could be lived and enjoyed (when in doubt, stick your bottom in the air and come back upright having caught a tasty morsel, or spend time preening and grooming until you look sleek and gorgeous!)  There is an outdoor swimming lake reserved for women, and one for men. Plenty of food on offer, or space to have your own picnics. Many years ago, I did the Race for Life in Hampstead Heath and in the 90 degree heat it felt like every part of the path/track was uphill. Since then, I have switched allegiance to the Regents Park track and this is far more civilised, seemingly all on the flat. Still work up a healthy appetite for the picnic our men have prepared, though!This is a beautiful Park, with manicured expanses of lawns and carefully tended flower beds, in which it is a pleasure to spend one's leisure.
Massive. Oh how i wish we had parks like this where i live. Great place to just people watch. Relaxing but also so much to do, with little cafes dotted around to take a break.

Wonderful park!. Fantastic park filled with flowers and beautifully landscaped gardens. In the summer months, there are plenty of sun chairs around the lake - perfect for a break from 'big city life'.
Open space in busy city. I loved the statue of Peter Pan, and also the fact that the park wasn't too manicured - a park and not a garden. Lovely.

Winter Wonderland.. People visit Regent's Park in Summer but it's always so busy. We go in Winter when it's frosty and you see nature in central London through different eyes then. Wrap up warm and give it a whirl.
Great park to visit. Lovely park to spend a good afternoon having a picnic or for a walk.

Bring some nuts for the squirrels. Big fat squirrels just come to you to check for food, better bring some! A part from that, the walk around is lovely, it's a quiet place very well looked after, I enjoyed the winter compositions. Didn't walk as far as the zoo is, but still was worth it.
Amazing. I liked everything, you can walk through the history
calm oasis. wonderful expanse of green in the centre of london. vibrant with community activity as well beautifully tended gardens
Put on your walking shoes. Brilliant colors in Nov/ Dec and great pathways. Instead of taking the tube, walk through to get to your next destination. Lots of signage and room to move

Surrounded by Gnashers!. Er, well, the famous Nash Terraces in fact, Georgian neo-classical architecture in abundance on the Outer Circle. London Zoo is here, Regents Canal, and the Open Air Theatre - great for a warm and dry summers evening. Full of grass, trees, flowers, bushes and stuff - just like a Park should be!

This park is not just for walking.... You can do anything from jogging, cycling, yoga, roller blading, walking in this park. In particular because of the perfect cycling/rollerblading path I'm going to give this park 5 stars.
Others have already written how well groomed this park is and there are also inetersting festivals. Highly recommend a visiti.
Great for feeding the ducks. something for everyone, London has some excellent parks

our favorite. Not as much to see in winter as in the glorious summer, when Queen Mary's Garden is a flood of roses, but what a charming setting, with the houses on the Crescent, and there is always something of interest in the gardens themselves..

Beautiful park, great location, amazing theatre, great cut through route!. Regent's Park is brilliant. There's the grassy stuff, haha, with a lake and loads of spaces to play ball games, chill out, sunbathe etc. The Regents Canal goes through the top which is a nice walk too.The open air theatre is just brilliant in the middle and such a lovely vibe. Drinks and food are a bit overpriced but hey its London!And if you're driving I have no idea why its not busier but its a brilliant cut through from Marylebone Road to Camden and north london and NEVER busy. Brilliant!
Well worth a walk. Stayed nearby and went for an early morning walk, simply stunning.

What a beautiful place!. Strolling through this stunning park on a crisp Sunday morning was a real treat! The beautiful fountains provided much amusement and fun for my son. Living on the south coast we are spoilt with open spaces but I found myself envious of the people who get to stroll through this park on a regular basis...Roll on summer for a visit to London and a picnic in Regents Park!!

Regents Park and London Zoo. Had a very pleasant afternoon in Regents Park and London Zoo however London Zoo does look very 'Tired' and could do with sprucing up, considering this should be the Premier Zoo of the UK Investment is urgently needed , Animals did look very well looked after

Dream park!. There's everything at Regent's Park. Meadows to play at the ball, refined gardens and beautiful flowers, a pond to rent a rowing boat, paths to go jogging, bars to have an ice-cream, artworks and people.Look at the park map and you'll see what I mean!It's a lovely, quiet place within walking distance from King's Cross station, Madam Tussaud's Wax Museum, Sherlock Holmes's Baker Street and Bloomsbury.
Lovely Park. This is not my top park in London, but it is lovely all the same.Like all the wildlife and is good for a nice walk, I especially love the small lake area.

Exceptionately beautiful park. Queen Mary's Gardens within the Park is a beautifully display. Expertly maintained throughout the year.Walk around the lake admire the settings, feed the ducks, and end up at what should be the perfect cafe in London. But why is this so disappointing. Expensive and restrictive. This has to be a perfect setting to have one of the busiest cafes in London throughout the year. But the fact that there are so few people enjoying this place outside of the Sundays, when it may be busy, should be enough for the large coffee shop in such a perfect setting wake up!
A beautiful park. This park has featured in the film 'About a boy' and during the summer the open air theatre is well worth a visit.

Large and rich in attractions. The Regent's Park is one of my favorite in London. It's not as crowded as Hyde Park or St. James's Park and offers some great facilities. The Northern part is home for the London ZOO, while the Southern accommodates a big boating lake. There's a lot of free space inside and while on the borders you can enjoy strolling by the canal.
Best Park in London. This is by far the best park in London, way better than Hyde Park. Check out the rose garden if you can. Great in the summer for a picnic.
A "must place go" in a sunny day. Even more beautiful than the Hyde Park. The Regent's Park is a must place to go in a sunny day. It's a delightful stroll the area around the boating lake.

my fave. spot for a walk esp on sunday morning. flowers do change very often and the park is well kept. the rose garden is the best ever.
you can take hours to walk around. close to baker street...u can also pass by the museum of sherlock holmes.

Beautiful. This park is probably the most beautiful one in London. I have been there in the spring and the fall and it was beautiful both times. It is well-tended and the flowers and plants are so beautiful it takes my breath away.

Hidden gems within a beautifully groomed park. I used to go jogging around this park, yet it took another friend to point out some of the hidden gems within the park. There are pockets of gardens that aren't obvious to get to, but that are absolutely beautiful and serene...perfect for quiet picnics with friends.During the summer, there are free open-air jazz concerts by the rotunda on Sunday afternoons, and you can sometimes hear the musical voices coming from the open-air stage musicals inside the park. It'll take more than a day to fully appreciate this park, but definitely have a wander around the grounds and explore.

Escape to the Country. Wide open spaces, wonderful Trees and the Canal. Best way to see it is to go from the Euston Road end then walk through to Camden. Only downside is lack of anywhere good to eat, though a few Cafes dotted around.

Best park in London. Beautiful, exceptionally well-maintained and in a great location. Love, love, love. Not as crowded as Hyde Park and also nicer lawns. Could also say it's a more refined park, calmer and more relaxing. Perfect for running, a picnic or a stroll, people & dog watching. Note: no cycling /. rollerblading permitted.
Super in Summer. Lovely gardens to sit in when the weather is warm. Very big and beautiful
Beautiful park. Beautiful park with the Zoo within walking distance
Nice place to roam around in central london. Nice place to roam around in central london, its quite close to Marble arch station
Best Park in London. This park is very tranquil and has huge open spaces.

Winter Wonderland ! ACE. What an excellent day, great christmas market, fantastic atmosphere, loads of things to see and do, rides for all of the family. We also went to Zippos circus, which the kids enjoyed, it was like an old fashioned circus from years ago, down to earth and fun for the little ones, probably not for teenagers !
Great to get lost in. Put on your walking boots, and get lost in the huge park. The zoo at the corner is not spectacular, but OK if visiting with kids in good weather.
Love this place. Love this place, I can not wait to go again, beautifull,relaxing and somuch to dowhatever the season

Beauty in the city. Come here, cloudy or sunny-the fresh air, beautiful flows, and greenery will make your day special.
Go roaming around the park and try and find the inner circle with the rose garden-what a treat!
LOVELY. Lovely park to go and look around, get for letting the little one to run free and use energy up.
A really beautiful park, wonderful to get lost in.. I love this park and especially Primrose hill which is quite near to it!
If you like parks and nature, you have to visit it!. In fact I would reccomend you to visit every big park in London. They are different and worth to visit.

Visit the Open Air Theatre. The times that I have been to Regents Park is to watch the Shakespeare productions at the Open Air Theatre which is a must in the Summer. This year there wasnt anything good on but when there is something worth watching I would recommend it. Cant bank on the weather though
Marvellous parkland. Regents Park is amazing. Beautiful trees and flower plantings, it is a joy to spend time in it. We had a lovely picnic and my son was thrilled to see squirrels.
My favourite London park. A beautiful park in the middle of a concrete jungle!

Beautiful vistas much bigger than I imagined.. First time ever ther; came in from Camden Town area. Gardens and displays fantastic; had no idea the the park was split by 'main roads' and you really go through three parks. Walked for about 3 hours and eventually landed in an area of london I did not know. Couldn't walk back as too tired; happy to get the tube back to Camden. So well worth a vist. London is not all shops. Try it.

Great!!!one of the best in the world. I love to go for walk,every time i go i love it more,The rose gardens,the lakes etc...Its amazing...everwere....I just recomend to all London visitors.I am very blessed to walk there regulary.

Beautiful - Wonderful for flowers and blooms. This is a beautiful park. Ideally if you are going to the Zoo with kids walk back through this park afterwards. Stop for a coffee etc. Its one of the best parks I've been in for flowers and beautiful trees.
Good for a long walk, not good for toilets.. If you have bladder problems, beware, this is not a good place to be. Beautiful park otherwise.

Too much space with little going on .... I went to visit Frieze Art Fair and took a walk round the Park while I was there. I loved the flower-beds dotted around, but found the spaces between each section vast and empty - hence ideal for displaying modern art statues. The zoo had animals more on the domestic side than the wildlife side, so was a wash out for me. The theatre setting is lovely though! I guess summer time is best to visit!

One of London's Gems. Normally you get what you pay for, but not here. All this space, grass, lakes, the bandstand and on the North side the fantastic Zoological Gardens and the canal. Something for everyone

London's best park. I used to live near Regent's Park and proposed to my wife on Primrose Hill so perhaps I'm biased but even now, living in South London, we visit the park and area several times a year. It is most beautiful in the summer when the gardens in the centre circle are in bloom and the open air theatre is open but to be able to stroll around one of the most stunning regency landscaped parks, have a coffee or an ice cream, then glimpse exotic animals in the zoo (you can see quite a lot from outside the fence) and then wander up Primrose Hill for the most inspiring view over the city, is a privilege and something everyone should "waste" time doing at least once!

Beautiful Park. I went to this park on autumn, it was really cold but none of these changed my mind from thinking this was a lovely park. I loved all its colors and its simplicity. I really recommend that you take a few minutes to walk through this park and you will experience a lot of peace and relax.

Best park in London. In my opinion it's the best park in London. There are a lot of little shops where you can buy something to eat, and the flowers there are amazing as well. It's in a really nice area of London. That's why I try to come there everday in the summer.

Great park for walking. A summer time walk through Regent's Park is one of the highlights of visiting London. The city revoles around the parks when the sun is out and there are so many different things going on. A must do for anyone visiting London.
Too close to miss. Near our hotel and just lovely. We walked there often.
lovely park. love to walk in the summer lovely flowers, lawns are well kept lots of family use the park lots of open space for children to run around
Heaven on earth. very nice and majestic park. It is different than Hyde Park in many ways. It is more unique in plants and gardens.
Dead and depressing. As just about every park in London, a dead and depressing landscape sparsely interspersed with trees and greenery.
so close to Melia White House. One must spend some time here, a great walk, and so many things to see. Plus teh area around it is also something to discover
An oasis in teh city. Surround yourself with lovely green taking a gentle stroll

My favorite London park. I was fortunate enough to spend a college semester at Regent's College in Regent's Park. A return visit 18 years later brought me back to the lovely greens, lively birds, and lush landscapes that I remembered.

Breath of fresh air during a London visit!. I love strolling in Regents Park during visits to London. Go in the spring when the flowers are blooming for a real treat. Maybe not a must see for the first time visitor to London, but worth a trip for regular or repeat visitors.
Zoo. Great walks, great flowers, great ponds, Zoo on top

Boats and Roses. This great park is a true lung for London, stretching from Baker Street up into Hampstead. Apart form the zoo, there is so much to see at every season of the year. My favourite time is in June as the roses start to bloom and it is warm enough to take a boat and drift on the lake.

Ok park, catycorner to Hyde's. Regents is an ok park that is catycorner to Hyde's park. Overall its an ok place to visit with some interesting scenary. But if you skip it while in London, you won't miss much. I would recommend just sticking to Hydes.

one beauty among many. the London parks are wonderful, havens from the hectic life of the city. Regent's Park is one of the most glorious, whether it's flowers, birds or simply solitude that you seek. A wonderful, well-kept and less-crowded park it is well worth a visit. If you go in the summer months then take a picnic and enjoy the peace.
Fabulous park. Fabulous park to go in the short British summer. They keep it clean and nice to walk around.

Simply massive. I did not really get a feel for just how big Regent’s Park is until I starting walking around it. Just walking from the edge into the Queen Mary’s Gardens was quite a trek, then to walk around and see some of the park itself could have occupied hours. The park is huge! The park has a little bit of everything – amazing flower beds, long wide pathways, tumbling water fountains and even a lake. The colours in late November were amazing. Despite being in Autumns relentless grip, the park was very clean and well maintained. A brilliant park to suit all visitors – sporty types can run, cycle or row, feed the birds, enjoy the flowers or picnic on the lawns. A massive park with unlimited opportunities for entertainment.

Open Air Theatre. Feed the ducks, go on the pedalos, or just stroll. Definitely go to the Open Air Theatre which is magical in the evening. The park can get a bit crowded at weekends though with unsavoury characters.

Regents Park Experience. My oldest daughter got her masters at Regents University in inner circle Regents Park.The gardens ,pond ,birds and school offer a kind of surreal atmosphere.It is a place we enjoy returning to for a stroll.Simply beautiful!

A lovely place to take a stroll. Every time I go Regent's Park I discover something new. The rose garden is lovely. The park itself is laid out well. I love being able to walk between Fitzrovia and Camden just by going through the park. It's not overcrowded or overrun by tourists. It's just a nice place to be.

beautiful park, well laid out.. this park is gorgeous. loads of places to sit and have a picnic and the flowers are amazing. its huge with various entrances and it doesn't seem to be as crowded as some of the other london parks. definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful Walk. We walked through Regents Park from the Station to get to the zoo. Beautiful well kept park and could not believe how many and how tame the squirrels are they just come up to you. Great experience seeing as I live in a deser town and don"t see these things.
A real green space. Love all London parks, well looked after and surprisingly peaceful.
Fun shopping area. The kids loved Hamleys' and the Apple store. Large modern stores in classic buildings. Lots of good restaurants in the area. Fun place to hangout after dark.
Under construction while I was there. The park was under a lot of construction while I was there but it looked like it is a very beautiful place to see any other time!

BEAUTIFUL!. Absolutely amazing. I wasn't sure a 'park' would be worth site-seeing, but the rose gardens alone were breath-taking. There were little benches strewn about & people just enjoying the sunshine - even a bachelorette or wedding shower or some-such-thing going on. Lovely walking paths.

Great place for children and families; some construction at present. This is a great example of an English park and they have some great features for families. There is a wonderful playground along with toilets for children only; a couple of cafes for tea, and a boating lake in the summer. Very well maintained and a great place to take a walk when the sun is out. Some construction going on at present but that does not hamper anything.

Another world in London. We strolled in September, a wonderful time to explore - a very, very large park. It does help to study the maps at the entrance to ensure you don't get lost - if you do - just keep going, plenty of seats, places for coffee & snacks.

Another wonderful park in London. I just love this park which is close to our daughter's flat in Marylebone.On any dat is lovely to go there to feed the huge amount of birds and of course the squirrels.But walking among the trees and flowers is relaxing and makes you feel you are so far from the crowds.If you have children they will love to go on the boats on the lake and in Spring or Summer is great to rent a chair and just stay there to read a book in the centre of London!
A real space to get away from it all. Just a great place to walk, relax, play and amuse the kids
well it was nice. but not such a big deal.. i didn't understand why people make such a big deal out of it
Not so good in winter... no flowers :). It is a nice park to see in Spring! In winter the flowers are dead... no colour in the park.But it is a nice place

Beautiful Flowers. This place is fantastic in summer, fantastic flower arrangements and the lake with the London Business School at the back is very scenic. A great place to run through if you're staying nearby
A boring garden. Nice for sport people, but nothing special, I would rather go to Hyde Park or St James
Love!. You have to take a walk around, it's well worth it.
Peace amongst the mayhem. Escape the hustle for a little while and stroll around the park

Beautiful Romantic park in central London. London is excellent for walking around and Regents park is a perfect getaway from the crazy, busy streets of the commedrcial city centre. Its perfect for a couple thats travelling together and wants to slow down and find a bit of romance in a super busy city like London.

A little gem. when planning a trip to London, Hyde Park wouldnt have been at the top of my list, but as our hotel was on one side, and our destination (the natural history museum) on the other, we decided to walk through it with the kids. There was a lot to see and it was a little piece of calm away from the hussle and bustle. The Princess Diana Memorial was surprisingly emotional and the kids loved it. great 1/2 hour walk to get away from the traffic!

The best park in London I think. I work near Regents Park and run round and through it a few times a week. Its away from the real tourist trails so is not as busy as some of the other parks which really makes you feel you have escaped the city. Saying that on weekends I imagine it can get very busy with sport happening as well.Good toilet facilities and some good food options make this my choice of park. Plenty of runners and cyclists cycling round the park. The zoo is also part of the park.

perfect masterpiece. I had lots of walks thru the park along an dwith my wife. There was no one ordinary day, and I liked any minute of being there. The most exciting thing is the ability of the local gardeners to keep it tidy and wild at the same time. thanx a lot.
Worth a detour if you have time. Close to Madame Tussauds, this is a large park which never gets crowded and yet has a lot to see, such as the flower beds and the lake.
Strolling. Nice park with some good playgrounds. Good for walks. Near to London Zoo.
Beautiful park!. With its fantastic gardens and water features, Regent's is a truly lovely park. Try to visit the Open Air theatre for a lovely summer night of Shakepeare.

The best park in London. Between Marylebone and Camden .. who could ask for more, it has the open air theatre, brillint cafe, boris nikes at every entrance, the gardens are spectacular and you can hire a boat and row the lakes at a bargain price .... sorry Hyde Park ... you don't come close .....

winterwonderland. visited Regents Park 21 11 11 to see Christmas markets, quite suprised to find a gaint fair ground with a few log cabins selling Christmas Fair, a bit disappointed and left after half an hour not my cup oftea at all
Beautiful. Wonderful place to slow the pace of visiting London. Great for a picnic break.

Great Zoo!. Great zoo, lots to see and do, we all had a brilliant time. Words of advice, book tickets in advance though as queues can be horrendous and take a picnic if you can, as at busy times getting a seat in the 'foodie' areas is hard and not great value either!

yes!!!. My absolutely favourite London park! With all its beautiful trees, palms, yuccas, bushes, flowers....football grounds (yes!), huge lawns for playing frisby etc....Outdoor theatre outside which you may - if you are lucky - hear some live music for free... - it's a perfect place to spend a summer evening till late at night...until the guards ask you to leave cause they're closing....:D

Visit the zoo!. We went to one of the Zoo Nights (held on Fridays in July), it was lovely to hear the talks on the animals, especially seeing the penguins new home too. You can book a picnic if you want, there is plenty of beer and food to purchase too.Really enjoyable evening.
HUGE park!!. This park is huge! It has many places for sport (football fields and so) lots of places to relax, and it's very nice just to walk around! It has a nice surrounding area also.

Never get tired of this park. I love this park. Ive had many specials days here. The flowers and rose gardens are amazing. The atmosphere in this park is so happy and relaxed. Can't wait for next spring for more picnics.
Stunning. Please take the time to stroll through this lovely park.

Amazing roses. Even though it was November, many roses were still in bloom. This park is beautiful. It has lakes with interesting birds and ducks, fountains, benches,and walking paths. I think it is the most beautiful out of all of the parks in London.
Beautiful. Even out of season the park is fantastic. Flowers, trees, birds, lots of people. The cafe is also very good. Go to the zoo you will love it

Picture perfect. Though I lived round the corner for 20 years and I should be more faithful to my local park, Regents park is overrated in my view. It's crowded, quite dirty and full of pretty landscaped flowers..
Lovely walk. Lovely walk in the parc especially in nice weather.
Huge park. Just a lovely park to be in you would never think you were in the city of London

Regent's park - something for leisure relax. We come to this park and instantly was charmed by it natural beauty, various birds that you can find there ( be ready to bring some bread crumbs ) and beautiful rose garden - shame in november we can't see it in all its beauty but those roses who still was there gave us an idea how lowely it must look in spring . In park itself yopu can do lots of activities from laying on grass and listening music to play sport games or simply jogging .Strongely advice anyone to visit.
wonderful, timeless. a beautiful feature of London, may it never change

Great place for anyone!. Go to Queen Mary's Gardens! So beautiful, and displayed over 50 types of different roses. It was a lovely walk and had MANY different features: playground, football fields, cafes, restaurants and more.

Great place for relaxing for all kind of people. It was my first outdoor experience in London in the neighborhood of my hotel.It is a suitable relaxing place for students, business people, old people and children alltogether.
Green Haven in central London. So lovely what ever the season, what ever the weather. One of the best things about staying in Marylebone .
Spring. Not the best London park but still beautiful and best in April/MayLike any park, a good choice away from the shopping and bustle!!
The country in the City. We hiked up Primrose Hill and always enjoy the park
Beuatiful. A lovely stunning place, just reminded me of films when I was little, and it's only a 5 min walk from tussauds so it helped to kill time for us also.

Visiting Regents Park. A college friend's family lived across from the Park in the early 70's. I stayed there my first two times to Europe. I went back to visit the site where there townhouse was for a little bit of nostalgia. The Park was so quiet with very few visitors (we did not visit the zoo). A great place to get away from the hustle and bustle seems to me.
enjoyed the walk. enjoyed the walk and the princess diana play ground my daughter loved.
Nice park. We wantered through and really liked it. The day was lovely and it was peaceful

Stunning Gardens, Immaculately Maintained. When we visited Regent's Park in early July, the gardens were in full bloom and immaculately maintained. The inner circle was laid out in such a way that there was a sense of discovery and something new to see around every bend. A sense of artistry and little discoveries along the way make for a lovely park and the perfect setting for a casual stroll. Exit to the south toward Marylebone High Street for excellent shopping and sidewalk cafes.
afternoon te. nice place to have afternoon te, but look up if you are staying there in late afternoon as they look many exits
It is always a pleasure. To walk in a sunny day near the zoo , watching yougsters playing and pets strolling with their owners. To visit Camden Town nearby makes it all more interesting
Very Pleasant. Nice free park, especially busy on sunny weekends but very safe and pleasant. the London Zoo is next door, a bit pricey but wirth a visit.

Great discovery. First time in Regent's Park and I had no idea how good it was. It is absolutely huge and we took a pedalo out on the lake and then had a lovely lunch in the boathouse cafe. My daughter really enjoyed the playpark. You could have a whole day out here for free, if you brought your own picnic. There are lots of activities to do if you want them, but probably better to book these ahead to ensure availabilty. A calm oasis in the heart of the city,
Such colors. Such a great park to visit... Recommended for everyone

Absolutely Beautiful !!!!. We visited the park on the last morning of our trip. We were so amazed at how beautiful it was even in October. There were 80 different roses still in bloom and the landscaping was amazing. We wished we had visited it earlier in the trip so we could have spent more time there.
Another chill zone!. Another opportunity to sit back and relax - remember to take something to feed the squirrels!
Excellent Park. As all parks in London go - lots of stuff to see and do!

During the Frieze Art Fair in october... The Frieze lasts only 4 days and it's a great exhibition of contemporary arts, collecting all the galleries in the World. The give a "free aperitif" of the fair by installing some sculptures inside the park, then you will be guided into the real exhibit (27pounds, but it's worth the value!)

Greenery in London. The Park is wonderful, we went through the rose garden, wish I had been there earlier because the smell would have been fantastic. It was peaceful and thoughly enjoyable just walking round the grounds.
Second to none. A wonderful park with probably the best zoo in the world. So mutch to see so make sure you allow a full day.

Splendid. lovely atmosphere and scenery , spent the afternoon laid on the grass. Would recommend this for families or couples wanting a nice relaxing day out . make the most by bringing a small packed lunch or even a picninc.
Nice Park. Nice park having beautiful rose garden with various types of roses
Beautiful gardens and lake. Rose gardens were lovely - we were the most entertained by the beautiful water fowl, so many ducks and geese, many we'd never seen before. Wonderful afternoon spent there.
Lovely. Wonderful park and from there you can wander the canal pathway.

Peace and quiet within the noise and fast pace of London!. My wife and I spent 8 days in London between crossings on the QM2 and decided to see Regent's Park for the first time in many visits to the city on a sunny Sunday outing. It is convenient to get to from a couple of buslines and the Baker Street tube station. Unlike Kensington Gardens and Hyde Park, it is away from the noise and relatively uncrowded. It's a great place to unwind. Just stay away from nearby Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum, particularly on a weekend. The crowd out front was huge. In the park there are numerous areas to stroll or just sit on comfortable benches and watch the people go by. There was an outdoor Hindu wedding going on when we were there with singing and colorful costumes. The Garden Restaurant was an unexpected high point - the prices were typical London - you know, same numerals but in pounds instead of dollars. That said, my wife and I had probably our best meal of the trip there. I had a ribeye steak dinner that was fantastic and she loved the sticky toffee pudding. Don't miss the park or the restaurant.

Don't Miss Queen Anne's Garden. Regent's Park is my favorite park in London.Most tourists go for the London Zoo (which is fine), but they are missing Regent's best.In the spring, Queen Anne's Garden is one of the most beautiful spots in London. The flowers & colors are unbelievable.This is probably one of the best small gardens in the world.Don't miss this free Regent's Park treat. You'll never forget it.

Love Regent's Park.. There are little nooks and crannies one can find in this big park. Romantic. Out of the way. Feels like you're far away someplace---other than bustling London:) The roses bloom beautifully in May. Lots of feathered friends to feed here, specially by the water.
`lovely and tranquil. A beautiful place to walk and admire the flowers, ponds and trees. If you like parks, add this to your list while in London.
Charming!. A special destiny for sundays. It's a good idea to know this park by boat on the way to Camden Town. Take a London Waterbus in Little Venice to Camden Lock or to the zoo.
Lovely. I have always loved this park. And it's very near Camden Lock, which is worth visiting. If you go with children, they will love the zoo, although you'll have to pay to go in.

Beautiful Location. This park certainly didn't fail to impress. Once you are in the park you completely forget that you are in the middle of such a big city. I was visiting from the States and staying in serviced apartments London that were close to the park which meant i could go more than once. Luckily it was sunny and the usual English weather wasn't a problem!
Lovely Flowers. This is a wonderful park with lovely flowers. Its is quiet and a great place to relax and enjoy a little bit of tranquility in the middle of a big city.

loved it. We were very impressed by Regents park-everything about it didn't disappoint.A very relaxed outing in a spectacular,clean and well maintained park.Well worth a visit to see the planting and fountains etcWe carried on past the zoo to the canal and walked along the tow path to camden lock.What a surprise to find such a huge trendy market.From there we took a canal boat trip.We had a lovely relaxing day out in London.The only thing we paid for was the canal trip.
Great Park, Huge, Beautiful Gardens. Run along the canal and you'll come across Camden Market which was neat. Great place to relax.
Stunning. Visited Regent's Park whilst on a holiday to London. Went on a beautiful day and had a picnic. Truly beautiful place.

Forgotten gem. We have visited London on a regular basis but have never re-visited Regents Park for a very long time.I had forgotten how wonderful the gardens were - very colourful formal flower beds which were in immaculate condition. Well done to all concerned. This made a very pleasant afternoon stroll away from the hustle & bustle of central London. Cafe's provide a welcome pit stop catering from a sausage bap to a good quality meal.In my view, this must be one of the best (if not the best) park in central London.

Regent Park is filled with unique beauty.. We spent several hours in Regent Park on a recent trip to London. It was spectacular. I have never seen so many gorgeous roses in one place. It is simply breathtaking! The grounds are manicured and so pretty. There are small lakes and brooks and waterfalls throughout the park. We had a wonderful cup of tea and dessert as we watched others enjoying paddleboating. It was a highlight of our trip and it was free! By the way, the zoo is there also but we enjoyed the nature so much we passed on it.

Beautiful, something for everyone.. A trip to Regents Park is always a treat. It never ceases to amaze me that there are 410 acres of beautiful tranquil gardens right in the heart of London. The Park is situated in the middle of St Pancras, Marylebone, Paddington and Primrose Hill. So it’s an ideal place to visit if you are spending time near Baker Street, Madame Tussauds, London Zoo, Camden etc.I would highly recommend viewing the website before you visit, as I find this quite informative and you will be able to plan your trip to suit your preferences. Personally I like the south side of the park, which you can easily access from Regents Park Station or Great Portland Street Station. On the South west side of the gardens you have the boating lakes, on the south side of the garden there are Queen Mary’s gardens, which are lovely and on the south east side of the gardens you have the Avenue Gardens and the English Gardens. All of these areas are extremely pretty and you could easily spend a few hours just in these places.For me one of the best ways to spend time in the park, is to wonder down Marylebone high street first, pick up some food from one of the lovely deli’s and go and have a picnic in the park. If you sit around the more popular areas e.g. the boating lakes, then it can get quite busy. However if you find some of the quieter tucked away gardens, you can end up without seeing other people for ages, which is lovely and tranquil.Regents Park is a lovely place for everyone to visit, whether you are exercising, walking, relaxing, looking for garden inspiration or even specialising in photography, there is something for everyone.

Awesome London Experience. We attended the Children's Shakespeare series - his plays made kid friendly - of Pericles. It was a great afternoon and everyone enjoyed themselves thoroughly. the ticket prices are reasonable, they sell snacks and beverages, you well as they allow you to bring your own.The price is reasonable and the experieince memorable.

Oasis in the middle of the city. Regent's Park is located in central London, very close to Baker Street underground station. The attractions in the park include London Zoo, but the main attraction is the park itself. It is a very popular picnic spot for the locals and on summer weekends there are usually a few wedding couples having their pictures taken among the roses in Queen Mary's Gardens.The roses are in bloom during the warmer months (normally May-July) and it is wondrous to walk among them, noticing the smells of all the different varieties represented. In the norht part of the park, there are sporting areas where local football leagues will have their matches on Sundays.If you are keen on aquatic activities, you can also rent rowing or pedal boats and go around the boating lake.There are also a couple of hot dog stand-type places to eat and the Garden Café, which is a proper sit-down café and restaurant.All in all, a marvellous place to spend a sunny summer afternoon.
A delight. A great place to wander around with lovely flower beds

Behold, the London town!. London is really a great town if for anything then because if you get tired of all the life bustling and boiling in it you can move away from it for a hour or a two and in the same time not leave it. To do so you just have to visit a park, and a good choice would be Regent's Park and especially the Primrose Hill just next to it (or you can take it as a part of it).Regent's park is a great green peace of land to take a stroll, have a drink in the cafe, play sports and so on. But the best experience for me was when we climbed the Primrose Hill (don't let this CLIMB word scare you, there is just about minute or two climbing), the hill provides a view on the whole town, you can explore the panorama of a huge town in one peace, and for a town as big as London this sure is a spectacular view.Primrose hill is a great place for a picnic or just sit on the grass (or on a bench) and relax... and enjoy the view over London.
Beautiful Park. I think Regent's Park is the most beautiful park in London perfect for having a picnic and spending the day reading!

CAN'T SAY ENOUGH!!! LOVED PRIMROSE HILL!!!. This is a WONDERFUL place to visit! You can sit around and catch an impromptu football game, have a picnic or just take a serene walk. I especially would suggest going to Primrose Hill to spend a restful afternoon or just to catch a wonderful view of the London skyline.

Beautiful park. Regents Park is definitely Londons most stunnung park with acres of grassland. It is a lovely place to have an ice cream and a stroll especially on a hot afternoon. We walked through it after visiting London zoo.

Just think about nature... Just think about trees, flowers, fountains, grass and it's already beautyful.Now add the playgrounds, the tennis courts and the squirrels that sometimes pass by..the park is sooo beautiful and I was happy to see passers-by not trowing but picking up some of the trash found in the bushes..It makes you feel good when you realize just how many people care about the city.

My favorite park in London. The most beautiful park in London, and, probably in the world.Offers many activities - several kid's playgrounds, boating lake, botanical garden, tennis courts, rugby and soccer pitches.Zoo is right within the park bounds, but it's a subject of it's own review. Also in the summer London open air theater, also located inside the park, is an absolute must. Enjoy a Shakespeare or Oscar Wilde play preceded by a champagne picnic. Does not get any better than that.A few Boris bike stations are scattered around the park, which is nice, although there is no cycling on the park paths.If you're into running - a run around the park is about 5k, a very enjoyable run.I had lived in London for 3.5 years with kids, and now I come here 10-20 times a year. Not having grown up here, we had built our experience by trial and error, so I consider myself a bit of an expert on London, and Regent's park is at the top of the list of London parks.

Just like heaven. the regents park is from my favorite places in London. it has a very relaxing ambiance, people of all ages, although i haven't watched anything in the open-air theatre, but i'm so sure that it is great! i love this lovely cafe in it, i love everything in it!

Great place for a morning run and awesome place for a picnic!. I spent a semester in London and was lucky to live just across the street from Regent's park. When it started warming up it was great place to go for a morning run! It is also an amazing place to people watch and to have a lovely picnic on a sunny day!

An Oasis in the city center. London is a compact busy city. But Londoners do appreciate their green space. Regent's Park is one of several Royal Parks that unleashes new beauty as the seasons progress. Regent's offers paddle boating (fee based service), an excellent place for photography and a great place to sit and relax (fee based service). Regent's is a large park. There is a rose garden, an entire university, an open air theatre and a cafe within its limits. It is a very peaceful place and is always full of people. Like the rest of London the feel is very safe!

We must go back in the summer!. We visited Regent's Park in mid October and found our way to Queen Mary's Garden. Wow! This place is so peaceful and relaxing, it's hard to imagine that it is in the middle of London. The garden was filled with roses of every color and shape that you could imagine. My wife said that you could just float on the smell of the flowers. I can't imagine what the garden must look like in the middle of the summer with it being still this grand this late in the year. We made our way to a little tea shop in the garden and although it was cold and cloudy we sat outside and enjoyed a hot cup of English Tea. This was my wife's favorite spot during our trip to London.

OPEN AIR THEATRE. Dispite the dreadful weather, if there is a dry day the Open Air Theatre in Regents Park is a wonderful place to visit. The Park itself is an excellent place to wander around and have a lazy afternoon. This year the programme seems interesting with A Mid Summers Nights Dream and Alice in Wonderland being part of the session. Don't forget there is London Zoo close by, as are Madame Tausauds and the Planetarium. And not very far is the Wallace Colletion towards Oxford Street, which has recently been renovated including a fine cafe and restaurant. I've been converted to the place over the last three years and have always had a brilliant time. But, take a brolly just in case !
Open Air Theatre. Had a wonderful time at the open air theatre on Bank Holiday Monday watching Into the Woods. Great Atmosphere - would highly recommend seeing a show/performance here.

A true delight in the midst of a big city. I you have a few days in London and are tired of the city views, check out Regent's Park! Especially, go to the Queen Mary's Gardens - it is very peaceful there. If you are pressed for time, go through the York Gate and it will take you straight to the gardens. Another thing you could do is pack a picnic - grab your favorite wine, tasty snacks, and a blanket to sit on. Enjoy!!!!!!!!!

Regents Park and Primrose Hill - A green oasis and a fantastic view. I have been to this park twice this year, both times on sunny summer days, once in the evening and once in the afternoon. On both occasions the park was beautifully maintained and well used. We witnessed several small groups of people playing games and people relaxing on both visits too and there was a really great atmosphere. On my second visit we walked up Primrose Hill, which I would highly recommend for the views of the City. You could sit in certain locations in this park and not believe you were in the centre of London. I would recommend this park for the views and for relaxation.

A lovely way to combine City & Country. I admit it was on a perfect Autumn day that my husband and I strolled around the park, but to see the trees in their Autumn colours, the delightful and well-tended gardens, it was a sheer delight. The walk along part of Regents canal was so peaceful and at one stretch of the canal, there was only the 2 of us walking along! I found that unreal on a sunny Saturday afternoon, and in London too!Just to sit and people watch was fun - joggers, strollers, dog-walkers, volley-ball players and a rugby game, was just the perfect way to relax and unwind before getting ready to hit the chaos of the rest London.

gorgeous gardens, whatever the season!. Regent's Park is my favourite park in Central London. It makes for a gorgeous day out, whatever the season! Different parts of the park look different and have their own particular charm, which is something that draws me back to it again and again. The Avenue Gardens with the rows of pretty flowers and fountains are brilliant to stroll through, and Queen Mary's Gardens with the roses and ducks are really pretty as well. Do bring some bread if you would like to feed the ducks, geese, swans etc that are to be found in the ponds/ lake here! It's lots of fun, especially if you have kids (though that's really an activity for all ages!) You can go on a paddle boat or row boat on the boating lake. Going on the boat before noon will give you about one pound discount (they count the fees per head on the boat, so you could make some substantial savings). There is an open-air theatre in the park, which i haven't been to, but from all accounts it's pretty good (stages Shakespeare stuff etc). The London Zoo is also located in the park, which could also make for a very nice day out (it really is a good zoo!), combined with general park strolling. Near the London Zoo at the north end of the park is Regent's Canal. Following the canal, you will be able to walk to either Camden Town (for Camden Lock Market- quirky market stalls and great atmosphere!) or Little Venice (this is near Paddington, it's rather nice but i didn't find it overly impressive), depending on which direction you take. The Canal Route is clearly marked. At the north end of the park, across a tiny road is Primrose Hill, and there is a brilliant panoromic view over London from the summit. It's not a very tall hill, really, and it's an easy climb to the top! Rather worth the (little) effort. All in all, there's good reason why I love this park! Do make time to visit it, especially if you happen to be in London longer than the time it takes to cover the basics (big ben, london eye etc). I ought to let you know that at the moment there is a little project called the Treehouse Gallery up near the boating lake at the park. This consists of a creative little space where volunteers host events such as puppet workshops and poetry readings. There are also 2 treehouses up there at the moment, and a number of swings/ net rope thingies. Great for kids and for adults as well! At the moment the Treehouse Gallery is due to be dismantled in September 2009, so do swing by there if you get the chance! it's something really different and fresh, and a brilliant idea and initiative. helped a man make his twig puppet for a puppet show to be held there in a couple of weeks. really enjoyed myself. :)
GREAT PLACE TO SIT/WALK/GO ON LAKE/WATCH HERONS WHEN WEATHER IS GOOD. As above and located to the north of Marleyborne this is a good place for a picnic

Lovely place!. A piece of tranquillity in London! I have never seen that much of roses. It was quite impressive to see the black swan. See http://www.royalparks.org.uk/parks/regents_park/ for a more information.

My favorite park in London. Don't miss Regent's Park. It is a gem! It has a prefect balance of large and small formal gardens, ponds and fields and it has an outdoor theatre. The London Zoo is in the park as well, if you are interested.

A beautiful park. Regent's Park is such a wonderful park. When I was there, it was raining, but I still found it beautiful, nonetheless. If you're in London and want a nice walk around one of the most beautiful parks in the city, this is something you should not miss.

A great place to relax in the heart of London.. A beautiful sanctuary in the heart of London. I have visited the park on three visits to Londonin January. Even in early winter, the beauty shines. Roseswere still on the bushes, Take a relaxing walk to escape the hustle of the city. Or just hang out reading the paper.There is the London Zoo, an open air theatre,a bird filled lake, and Regent's College locatedthere.It must be gorgeous during the warmer months.It is a short walk from Madame Tussaud's,Marlybone Road, Baker St., and Park Rd.Enjoy.

Green Space Delight. Despite having lived in London for years in the past I had never visited Regent's Park while there: a weekend break and a stay at the Danubis Hotel enabled three days exploring (including one full day at London Zoo).The park is an oasis of calm in the city: a superbly maintained, huge open space with several small cafes and facillities for runners and other sports people. The park team must be dedicated souls, tending to some formal gardens while resisting the urge to cut down wild plant reas, thus encouraging insects for the benefit of the park's huge range of bird life. I have never seen so many heron anywhere, a bird you normally associate with wild spaces in the UK.Definitely worth a visit: take in the Honest sausage for lunch or a late breakfast, organic fayre is served.

Lovely way to spend an afternoon. Well I am not sure what exactly "tourist pollution" is in the heart of one of the biggest cities in the world, but I can tell you that despite large crowds on some days this is still a beautiful way to spend your afternoon. Lovely gardens, pretty lakes, open fields, lots of trees and fine little cafes make this a less hectic London diversion.

Regents Park. I was born very close to this lovely park. Unfortunately these days it is spoilt by tourist pollution. If you really want to enjoy this park (tourist or not) go early in the morning before the masses arrive. In April there are so many beautiful cherry blossoms and October can be very pleasant. The park is well kept with beautiful flower displays (the gardeners should get a big bonus) and the ponds are very nice.As I said it is spoilt by tourist pollution (as the whole of London is) but if you go there early it is a really beautiful park.

outdoor theatre. The place to see an outdoor play in the summer. Comfortable seats, all good. Great food available in the theatre grounds for a pre-play picnic. Don't bring your food, it won't be as good or cheap as what is offered. This is a don't miss if you're spending 3 or more days in London.
